PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Joint Select Committee on Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the president and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Calvert (from 237 citizens), Harradine (from 256 citizens) and Watson (from 177 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 260 citizens) and Calvert (from 425 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Casino, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill of citizen initiated Constitution and legislative referenda, and voters' veto.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will pass said Bill so that a national referendum can be held on this matter simultaneous to the Government's four referenda questions, with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Vessels in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and senators in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, believe:
that Australia should not host nuclear weapons in its territory or in Australian waters; and
that the presence of nuclear armed warships makes a priority target of the ports being visited; and
that the safety precautions for handling and deployment of nuclear weapons are inadequate to guarantee safety from accidents; and
that the malfunction of the reactor on board a nuclear powered vessel could irradiate a large area of the surrounding environs.
Therefore call upon the Australian Government to:
prohibit the entry of nuclear weapons to Australia; and to
deny access to Australian ports of vessels which are nuclear powered; and to
deny access to Australian ports of foreign warships unless an assurance is received that they are not carrying nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgement that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crichton-Browne (from 30 citizens), Knowles (from 48 citizens) and Panizza (from 21 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: How to Vote Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

millions of dollars of taxpayers money is spent at each Federal election in Australia in the drafting, production and distribution of How-to-Vote cards which are unnecessary and pollutant and that this waste is not desirable or essential in assisting the electorate to vote informatively for their parliamentarians.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

urge the Government to introduce legislation which requires that the registered How-to-Vote cards of all political parties and candidates for political office must be placed under glass in every polling booth within obvious sight of all voters, thus making it unnecessary for How-to-Vote cards to be distributed at future federal elections.
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Vessels in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, strongly urge that the Australian Government prohibit the entry of nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered vessels into Australian ports or waters during our bicentennial celebrations and at any other time in the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Powell (from 200 citizens) and Vallentine (from 1,223 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
the gold mining industry is a vibrant expanding industry which provides employment for many Australians;
the gold mining industry provides valuable export income which contributes to a stronger balance of trade and Australian dollar, and thus a higher standard of living for all Australians;
the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining represents a threat to an industry which is vital to Australia's future; and
we call on the Federal Government to withdraw its proposal for a tax on gold.
As in duty bound, your petitioners, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aborigines: Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that Australia is one nation which comprises people from many different racial and cultural backgrounds;
that a Treaty with one of these peoples-the Aborigines-would be divisive and would be equivalent to the setting up of a separate nation;
that a Treaty could lead to the introduction of a national system of land rights;
that we are totally opposed to the signing of a Treaty with the Aboriginal people.
As in duty bound, your petitioners, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing, Shark Bay Region, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strongly oppose the proposed World Heritage listing of the Shark Bay Region in Western Australia, either partially or in its entirety, believing that all conservation values of the Shark Bay Region will be fully protected under the Shark Bay Region Plan, developed over three years by conservation authorities; and we respectfully request the Parliament and Government to remove the threat of World Heritage listing for Shark Bay by making a firm decision not to proceed with any further consideration of it.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the World Heritage listing of either a part or the whole of the Shark Bay Region.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: War Crimes Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

The Australian Government's proposed War Crimes Amendment Bill is seriously deficient. It is discriminatory. The attention of the Bill is focussed exclusively on political refugees from the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and Yugoslavia. It is bound to result in hostile political stereotyping of refugees from Communist countries and will be profoundly destructive of Australia's multi-cultural society.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that, if the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled are minded to support the War Crimes Amendment Bill, the following nine provisions be guaranteed:
(1) Entitlement to legal assistance for the defendant so that he can conduct a proper defence.
(2) Financial compensation to any persons cleared of war crimes allegations, so that innocent people are not financially ruined in the course of establishing their innocence.
(3) That Soviet, Yugoslav or other similar evidence should be totally disregarded unless corroborated by independent evidence clearly beyond Soviet (or similar) control.
(4) That the defendant should have adequate and equal access to archives and site visits, as well as the right to select and interview witnesses from overseas, in the preparation of his defence.
(5) No affidavits, videotapes or audiotapes to be admissible as evidence. Witnesses to appear in person and be cross-examined before an Australian jury.
(6) No ex officio indictments. Nobody should be put on trial for any offence under this Act unless there has first been a committal or preliminary hearing.
(7) No extradition to occur before trial or after verdict.
(8) Any information tending to identify the ethnic origin or nationality of persons charged with war crime should be suppressed until after verdict.
(9) The word ``omission'' to be deleted from s.6 (1) (k) (iii) and s.6 (5) (c).
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Vessels in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:

Noting that nuclear armed warships have been invited to Sydney Harbour in September 1988, we the undersigned citizens of Australia, strongly urge that the Australian Parliament prohibit the entry of nuclear armed vessels into Sydney harbour this year or at any other time in the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

(b) notes that the result of the Government's attempt to entrench Labor policy platforms on an unwitting electorate has served only to bewilder and confound Australian voters and to intensify irrational conflict; and

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988 INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Senator Tate:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Government's Industrial Relations Bill 1988 and its proposal to change the face of industrial relations in this country. Many of my colleagues have already spoken on the Bill and have expressed the objections the Opposition has to it. It is fundamentally flawed in a number of respects. It does not provide for the enforcement by the proposed Australian Industrial Relations Commission of its own rulings. It does nothing to prevent compulsory unionism-and I shall come back to that-in the face of a government which says that it does not have compulsory unionism in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the report in the Canberra Times this morning of two chefs who have been evicted, thrown out of their jobs, from this very building because they are not members of a union. The article says that the head of the Joint House Department said that it is not a closed shop, but I would be interested to know what he thinks is running here when two chefs from this building have been told to find work elsewhere because they have refused to join a union. I have other material on that that I will refer to a little later.

This legislation also attempts to override the State legislation. It proposed the amalgamation of smaller unions into larger unions. As I have said, there have already been a number of speakers who have dealt with these matters. The reason I wish to speak is that being a representative of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) it is interesting to look at what has happened in five years of Australian Labor Party Government in this one Territory where it has the sole responsibility for industrial relations. Other areas also have State legislation but that is not the case in the Territory and it is reasonable to look at what has occurred here when we examine the Government's proposals for the future. In passing, we had the absurdity last night of one of the Labor senators suggesting that our attitude to industrial relations indicates a dislike of workers. That is patently absurd. Our attitude to industrial relations reflects our concern for workers and their families, and for their ability to get on with their lives and not be disrupted in their employment in the way that so many of them have.

I spoke earlier this year on a matter of public importance relating to industrial relations in the Australian Capital Territory. At that time I listed-and I was criticised by Senator Robert Ray, I think, for doing so-the strikes, the bans, the interruptions to employment that had occurred during Labor rule in the ACT from March 1983. Incidentally, industrial relations is not the only area where we have been change and chaos. We have had five Ministers for the ACT in five years. That also gives some indication of the Labor Party's real attitude to the Federal Territory. We are about to get the fifth Minister coming on board tomorrow. A less suitable time to change Ministers one could hardly imagine.

A vast number of disputes, bans and strikes have occurred in this Territory and the list is very long. As I said, I do not intend to reiterate them all today because there are other things I wish to talk about. It is significant because it causes increased costs for the rest of the community and disrupts the lives of the workers concerned. We are in a unique position in that, until such time as there is self-government in the Australian Capital Territory, the Federal Government has the capacity to influence industrial relations in the Territory. In the States and, since the granting of self-government, in the Northern Territory, governments are able to legislate in the field, but in the ACT the Federal Government has the field to itself.

There have been bans here which have caused closures within the hospital system; strikes have closed the garbage dumps, endangering public health; and disputes have closed down building sites, resulting in the unemployment of skilled workers. Ultimately, it is the Federal Government which has had the power to be involved in the area of industrial relations. Two hundred and sixty thousand people live in the Australian Capital Territory. The Federal Government has shown, by its attitude to industrial relations and its inertia, here and across the nation, that it has had a total lack of willingness to provide meaningful solutions to the problem of lawlessness and standover tactics. It has had an effect on the workers concerned and on the population at large. The people of Canberra know all about it. They know what it means to have a government that is so spineless that it will not get involved in finding solutions to these problems. It has meant inconvenience for householders, the sick have suffered, and it has meant the closure of businesses and unemployment for workers.

Wives of workers have had to queue outside the Department of Social Security to claim benefits for themselves and their children while their husbands were on strike on this very site, the Parliament House site. Surely, it is hard to expect these people to understand why the Government has not been more active in the area. Many of the workers have had no wish not to be working, but what could they do about it?

We have a system of compulsory unionism in the Territory which the Government has allowed to flourish. There has been no protection for any worker who wishes not to be a member of a union. There is provision in this legislation for this conscientious objection nonsense. There is no provision within Labor philosophy for a person to have a job and not be a member of a union. I again refer to the newspaper article in which it is reported that two chefs from this building are now out on the street because they do not want to join a union. The article reads:
The assistant secretary of the Joint House Department, Mr Fraser Bradley, confirmed the incident yesterday. He said union membership was `actively encouraged'-
I would have no objection to that if the term actually meant what it said-
and the House had a collective-style of management, where unions were included in decision-making.
They certainly are! They run the place. The article continues:
He disagreed that the House had a `closed-shop' arrangement . . .

I hope that someone will enter the debate later and tell us what sort of arrangement operates in this building if it is not a closed shop arrangement. The first incident of this kind on this site that I knew about occurred some years ago when a carpenter lost his right to work because he did not want to be a union member. He not only could not work on this building but also he was driven out of the Territory and was not able to obtain a job. Since work on this building has run down, the heavies of the union movement have been moving into the housing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —They talk about freedom of religion, for goodness sake!

—I will refer to freedom of religion a bit later, because it is interesting that this Government should seek to include in this referendum a proposal of this nature, just as it sought to inflict on us a Bill of Rights a couple of years ago. What about the right not to join a trade union if one wishes not to be a member of a union? People who are misled by this fourth referendum question this Saturday ought to remember the Bill of Rights debates a couple of years ago. They ought to look at what is going on in the ACT at present. They should look at what has happened in this Parliament House within the last few days. Two chefs have been thrown out on the street because they did not want to belong to a union. There is also the case of the roof tiler who was told he could not work if he did not join the union. He has worked on his own as a subcontractor all his life. But it was not just his having his job affected. The whole job would close down if he did not join. It was a dispute whereby in the end the builder himself paid the fee in order to have a quiet life. Protectionism of this kind has been rife in Canberra for some considerable time. I have pages of stories here that I could recount in relation to this. What about the hire car drivers who were told, about two years ago, that they would get no more Commonwealth work if they did not join the Transport Workers Union of Australia? Mostly they were owner drivers.
—Self-employed too.

—Self-employed and they wanted to stay that way. What advice could they be given, other than that while there is a Labor Government in this country they had better join the union or they and their families will starve on the streets? That is Labor's real attitude to people who want to work in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been incidents of this kind at the Australian Capital Territory Community and Health Commission and, as I said, now there is hardly a building in Canberra which has not been totally unionised in this fashion. There are a few single house constructions which may still be immune, but anything in the medium density area, any multiple construction, is now classified by the union as an industrial site and on they go. Everyone on the site must have a union ticket including the subcontractors and the small businessmen who are the backbone of this society. All the conditions have to be met: rostered days off, severance pay provisions.

The housing industry in this country has been attempting to pursue a policy of more affordable housing. There was a contest in Canberra. There is a site at Calwell which is being built on and every effort is being made to build attractive, well-designed houses in a way which makes them affordable to those in this community who have been in these enormous queues waiting for public housing. How on earth can one even get an affordable housing program while daily the fees go up as a consequence of the money that a builder has to pay to the union for the right to be able to continue to build his house. The people who are working there do not want to be involved in this. They just want to work. They just want a fair days wage for the work that they put into it and they want to be able to get on with their lives. But they are being constantly interfered with. Their jobs are being constantly disrupted by this attitude of the unions towards not looking after workers but getting money into their coffers. The rights of subcontractors are being totally denied and this Government has sat back and watched it happen.

Canberra is isolated. It is a landlocked island city from that point of view and it is easy for the unions to conduct these tactics under the watchful eye of a Labor government which is quite happy to see it happen. As I said, I have numerous instances and stories of what has occurred and many in Canberra could tell honourable senators of other instances as well as those which I have mentioned. I have referred to the referendum. Do not let anybody listening to this debate today think that the referendum is other than what it really is. When one looks at the erosion of rights in the fourth question and when one looks at the Bill of Rights one sees that unionism is to be included as a right but there is no right for one not to join a trade union. I think it is time that this Government's real attitude to workers was exposed. It allows these black bans to take place. There is nothing that it will do to permit a job to continue in this situation.

Employers who do not toe the line find that they are likely to lose the job that they had. There has been an instance recently of a contractor winning two contracts for construction in Canberra. Because he did not have union labour he suddenly found that both of those jobs disappeared and went to someone else. That is the sort of lawlessness that is being tolerated in this community of Canberra. There have been some comments about it by one of the Arbitration Commissioners earlier this year. There was a dispute on the Quadrant site and Commissioner Baird made some very telling comments. He described the Australian Capital Territory building industry as in a state of anarchy and I wonder what has happened since.

What has the Labor Government done to try to sort out the problem? What input has it had? In the Canberra Times last week there was a small article headed, `New unit will settle disputes'. `Ah', I thought, `Maybe the Government at last realises that there are problems in this Territory and it is going to do something'. The article reads:
A de-facto labour department has been set up within the ACT Administration to help settle industrial disputes and meet the needs of a growing workforce.
Nothing in the article indicates that the Government will seriously do anything to allow people to work at the jobs they want to work at. The article continues:
The unit would create a structured approach to industrial relations, which would reduce the duration and number of disputes and stoppages in the ACT.

What would do that most would be the introduction of policies which allow people to get on with the jobs they want to carry out. I referred earlier to the garbage dispute. People may think that such a dispute would not really affect people, but it occurred in January of this year when it was particularly hot in Canberra. I recognise that the garbage collectors have a right to have a dispute with their employers or the Government, but they blocked the tips altogether. They dumped things in front of the tip gates so that Canberrans who would otherwise have been able to deal with their own garbage were prevented from doing so. This also affected a number of small businesses in the waste removal and gardening industries which were not able to get on with their jobs. The people of Canberra, in the warmest part of the year, were prevented from taking their own rubbish to the garbage dumps because the Government sat back and allowed this to happen. There was some relief eventually when the small business association realised that, because the Government would not do anything, it would have to, and the garbage dumps were eventually reopened. How does any government sit back and explain this sort of thing to a community, to people who pay their rates and expect their garbage to be collected? It is one thing for there to be a dispute; but the Minister sitting on his hands and allowing the garbage dumps to remain closed gives an indication of just how bankrupt this Government is.

TALK.START.PARA: —To leave it without an effective remedy.

—Canberra was left without an effective remedy. I referred to that briefly when I started my speech: the main failing of this legislation is that it does nothing to provide for the enforcement by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of its own rulings. Even when earlier this year Commissioner Baird referred to the fact that the building industry in the ACT was in a state of anarchy he was not able to do anything about it and get people back to work-people who for the most part wanted to work and who wanted to get on with their jobs. In sorting out these problems the Government seems to be tongue tied because of the precious relationship it has with the union heavies.

SPEECH.PARA: The new unit that is being set up will do nothing to change the situation in Canberra. I wonder whether the unit will demand that unions allow people to work without a union ticket. The Minister might be able to tell us that later on. Will this new unit that has been set up in the ACT Administration actively pursue the cause of a worker who wants to work but who does not want to belong to a union? Will the unions be counselled and advised by this unit that they should allow these people to work? Will the chefs be able to go to the new unit set up in the ACT Administration to present their case: that they were driven from their jobs by the employer-who virtually is the Labor Government-because they do not want to join a union? I shall be very interested to find out whether that is the case. It seems that the compliance issue is the one thing that the Government will not recognise as a fundamental part of any new industrial relations system.

The other matters that have been referred to can be debated, but unless the Government is prepared to accept that enforcement of its rulings is a fundamental issue there is very little likelihood of there being any significant change. The Industrial Relations Bill 1988 does nothing about compliance. At the Quadrant site in Canberra more recently the dispute was between the builder and the owner of the site, but it was on that site initially that the Commissioner made his comment about the state of anarchy. Commissioner Baird has been involved long enough in the Territory to know exactly what he is talking about. It is clear that the Government has no intention of putting in place any provisions that would resolve these sorts of problems, that would enable enforcement of the Commission's rulings in relation to both employers and unions.

The lack of action, the lack of commitment at the ACT level which I have referred to today, where the Government has direct involvement and responsibility for industrial relations, is reflected in this legislation we are now debating. Nobody should be deluded as to what the Government is about. The Government is prepared to see businesses suffer; it is prepared to see jobs sacrificed; it is prepared for the people of the ACT to be severely inconvenienced or even placed at risk. This legislation will cost jobs and it will hurt businesses. It will provide no protection for people who want to work and get on with their lives in this community.

In the one part of the country where the Government has the power and the responsibility to do something about industrial relations we have seen over five years and five Ministers exactly what its attitude to industrial relations really is. It has failed in the ACT and it will continue to fail at the national level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devlin Sen A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the Industrial Relations Bill 1988. The Bill is a continuation by the Hawke Government of the reform of industrial relations. It is radically different from the approach adopted by previous conservative governments, including the Fraser Government, and from the present policies of the coalition. The central objective of the Bill is to settle industrial disputes before they start through a process of consultation and conciliation. The Government has consulted widely with employers, unions and industry in developing this Bill. The Bill is representative of the views and wishes of many organisations and individuals. It does not please everyone, nor does it pretend to. The Bill is not, as has been intimated by the Opposition, simply a repeat of the wish list of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-far from it.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing this Bill, I shall confine my comments to the maritime industry. I have worked in this sector all my life and have witnessed many changes. Changes are still occurring. Several weeks ago a number of daily newspapers reported Mr Ian McLachlan, then President of the National Farmers Federation, describing Australia's waterfront industries as `the garbage on our doorstep'. Mr McLachlan reportedly suggested that waterfront issues might be exploited by the National Farmers Federation by provoking disputes to encourage contributions to the Australian Farmers Fighting Fund. Many Opposition spokespersons have echoed these words and continue to promote the confrontation line. This confrontationist attitude is not only irresponsible in terms of industrial relations, but it is also unjust and ill-founded given the contribution made to date by the maritime and stevedoring unions in attempting to solve the problems of the Australian shipping industry.

The maritime industries presently employ some 4,000 to 5,000 seamen, and many other jobs are provided in related industries such as ship repair. Complementary activities such as stevedoring employs perhaps another 4,000 to 5,000 workers. Australian seagoing unions have painstakingly worked for two years on the Maritime Industry Development Committee. Their achievements include reduced crews, flexible labour, no demarcation disputes, and dual purpose crews who are able to work anywhere on a vessel. Crew sizes have been reduced by one-third between the 1960s and the 1980s and this trend is continuing. Most vessels will have crews of 20 or less by the 1990s. Five years ago there were seven maritime unions. Today, through voluntary amalgamation, that number has been reduced to three and the rationalisation process is continuing.

Industrial action in the industry has been dramatically reduced. Ship days lost through industrial stoppages reached 1,953 in 1982 but only 14 days were lost in 1986. The Government, seagoing unions and employers have together developed industry strategies that will meet technological changes in the industry on an international scale. The stevedoring industry is also responsibly addressing a whole range of issues pertinent to employment in the industry. The Waterside Workers Federation of Australia is contributing in a constructive and responsible way to the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee with a view to developing an agreed industry plan that will deliver improved efficiency and productivity. The Opposition will never give the unions credit for this, but that is understandable because to do so would not fit in with its confrontationist line.

The vastness of Australia and the wide distribution of population, industry and natural resources place a high priority on an efficient transport service. For Australian industry to be competitive Australia needs a viable, competitive coastal shipping service as part of the national network. Australia also needs a competitive international shipping service. With only four per cent of our vital imports and exports presently being chartered in Australian vessels important earnings are lost and the Australian trade deficit increased. The maritime unions have shown a responsible attitude to reform of the Australian shipping industry. This should be recognised. Improvements have been made and will continue to be made. The future of the industry depends on cooperation, not confrontation. This Bill will further aid this process.

Senator Fred Chaney, in the Age on 16 August 1988, defended the Opposition's industrial relations policy and stated that by no means all those people who have publicly lent support to the Opposition's policy come from employer ranks or the conservative side of politics. He said that Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon, former General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation and a member of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, wrote recently:
There is nothing impracticable in the coalition's industrial relations policy document and nothing that cannot be practically introduced.

Let me say that Charlie Fitzgibbon was General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation and led the union to many major reforms on behalf of the industry and its members. He has often been quoted by Liberal politicians, including the ex-Liberal Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, who has said that he would prefer having negotiations with Charlie Fitzgibbon than with other major union leaders. I presume he was talking about industrial relations. When in office Fraser and his Government Ministers slammed Fitzgibbon and the union. Fitzgibbon was the representative of his union and members when in office. I find it strange that the Opposition can now befriend Fitzgibbon and quote him, but still hammer his union. I have often said the Opposition does not understand unions or industrial relations and this proves the point once again. I have never been satisfied with the answer to why Charlie Fitzgibbon was elected to a further six-year term but served only a few months of that term and retired to greener pastures. He is still enjoying the fruits of life through his experience gained as the General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation.

However, I have also worked under the present General Secretary, Tas Bull, whom I consider as equal to the previous General Secretary, but in a different environment. He has a much harder task in guiding his membership through retraining and restructuring and the consistent attacks on the maritime unions. I am confident that Tas Bull is a competent industrial leader and representative of his membership. It is strange that Opposition members quote the former or ex-leader and can only criticise the present leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you ever hear criticism by me of Tas Bull?

—I have never quoted Senator Chaney. This Bill provides the framework to continue the reforms of the industrial relations system in this country. The reforms already in place and the policies of the Hawke Government have already delivered results. Since coming to office, over one million new jobs have been created and the level of industrial action in the form of strikes has been more than halved. Much more needs to be done. It cannot be done by the Government alone. It can be achieved through cooperation, and the Hawke Administration has the record that proves it can win that cooperation. I commend the Bill to the Senate and look forward to the committee debate on this most important Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to enter the debate on the Industrial Relations Bill 1988. If ever there were an area that Australia needed to rectify in order to re-establish its position in the world, it is the area of industrial relations. This is an important Bill, a big Bill. I welcome this opportunity to speak on it. The Bill was rammed through the House of Representatives with about three and a half hours of debate. There was no opportunity for amendments to be moved because there was no committee stage. It is only in the Senate that we are able to have a proper examination of, and proper debate on, the Bill. It has been an extensive debate, with many speakers, which is an indication of its importance. We have the chance to move our amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The thrust of the Bill is concerned more with union power than with improving industrial relations. This fits very well with the current Government's policy of establishing big government in association with big business and big unions, which is basic to a fascist state. That is not a bad way to run a country if one does not mind being told what to do, but it is very un-Australian. Back in May Mr Willis brought in a Bill which was to block access by people to sections 45d and e of the Trade Practices Act, which were the provisions used in the dreadful strikes we had at Mudginberri and with Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd. There was such an upsurge of public outrage at what was proposed that Mr Willis decided to withdraw the Bill. Now, at this much later stage, he is bringing in this Bill as a belated response to the report of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems.

Despite Mr Keating's reassurances that Australia's economy is on track-I dispute that-the economy is in a parlous state. If our overseas commodity prices do not stay high, we will be in an even worse and more fragile and dangerous position. The only way to rectify that is to increase production in Australia and the way to do that is to have a proper system of industrial relations.

The history of industrial relations over the last couple of centuries has been checkered. Last century it was the employers who disadvantaged the employees. This century it is the employees who have been disadvantaging the employers. We have now reached a new age of enlightenment with regard to industrial relations. There is no more the attitude of `them and us'. We cannot afford any longer the specious arguments about the advent of technology, mechanisation or automation because all they do is delay development and make employees dependent on trade union activity.

Often people have to change jobs two or three times in their lifetime. Most honourable senators would have had to do such a thing. Technology creates jobs; it does not destroy them. It is only the jobs that are different. For example, we could not possibly have kept up the old telephone exchanges with tiers of girls working on the switchboards or have condemned housewives to years of persisting with washing boards. Those things had to go. Somebody has to invent and build the machines. Technology only makes for a difference in the jobs. People do not have to sit around any more like limpets and scream out, `Somebody help me.' They can be far more in control of their own destiny. No longer are people born into one job and have to keep that job, or even say that they are entitled to that job and kick and scream when the job disappears. My father was a mining engineer. Mines have a certain life. When the life of the mine is gone the miner has to up sticks and move somewhere else. That is becoming the norm with employment today.

People have to keep abreast of changes. Certainly management can and should help them keep abreast of impending changes-even train them for those changes, that is, if they both agree to them. People might want to change their jobs. Management needs to meet with unions regularly. Every Monday morning there should be a meeting of management and unions. They should discuss their problems, the changes and any developments that are proposed, and particularly the state of the business.

Right now there is a move by trade unions to fast track their representatives on to the boards of companies. But that is not the proper locus of activity for trade unions. Trade union activity should be at management level, not at board level. The functions of a board are entirely different from those of a trade union. Now the trade unions want a say in investment, in development, in mergers, in financial figures, and the management of the business, which are all functions of the board, not functions of the trade unions. But not only that, they want the information presented to them in a form they can understand. Then, on top of that, they want a say in investment decisions. They do not want to invest any of their own money in the business or to have any responsibility for the results of their actions. This would be a recipe for disaster in a business.

The recommendations of the International Labour Organisation (ILO), which supposedly this legislation was based on, have not even been followed by the Government, but they are certainly founded in the old confrontationist days of `them and us'. They do not, for example, recognise the costs of exploration, development, licensing, environmental impact studies, investment decisions, taxes and royalties, borrowing to fund projects or the decision to farm in or farm out a project. I realise that in other countries, for example Japan, a person can rise through the trade unions and get on to the board of the company. But Japan has an entirely different industrial relations structure. Workers in Japan work for six days a week, with two weeks holiday a year. There is an emphasis on technology. But the focus of Japanese trade unions is on the business and the success of that business. The chairman is more or less a father figure to the employees. In Japan they have a strike season that is set and lasts for three days. It is set down so that it will cause minimal disruption to businesses. Many people, in order not to disrupt business, do not actually go on strike. They just wear a black armband to indicate that they have a protest about one thing or another. Japan has one of the soundest, strongest currencies in the world. It is investing all round the world and paying for it at home, which is not helping other countries very much. But if we want to compete, we have to work harder and smarter. We cannot do that while the country is being held to ransom by a few rampant unions and a welfare system such as that which crippled Great Britain. We certainly cannot do that when these few militant unions are aided and abetted by the Government.

The book entitled Australia Reconstructed, which has been circulated over recent months, has received a lot of publicity extolling its virtues. Its context has been modelled on the Swedish and West German industrial relations systems and it is being used as a blueprint for future industrial relations in Australia. But it is just another socialist recipe for failure. Of course, those socialist paradises behind the iron and bamboo curtains also have trade unions. I have visited the Peoples Republic of China a couple of times, where trade unions exist to ensure that the production teams meet their production goals, which is a very different form of action for unions from that which pertains in Australia. Currently, there is enormous union unrest in Poland, but it is not over better terms and conditions for the unions; it is really a power struggle between the unions and the socialist Government, and all that the union wants is a bit of the socialist power from the Government. The people running that union problem are still socialists; they just think that the wrong people are running the Government.

I would like to comment briefly on the accord, which I see as a triumph of union muscle over common sense in Australia, and central wage fixation with the advent of high fixed minimum wages. I am sure that these are among the main causes of unemployment in Australia, and they are a direct result of union action and the action of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If we have high fixed minimum wages, we create a lot of people who would work for less and a lot of people who could afford to pay less. But those two can never meet because, under the law, workers have to be paid these high fixed minimum wages. But not only that; it puts those people out of competition with the unions, and I am sure that the big group of unemployed people in Australia could be vastly reduced it we did not have these high fixed minimum wages.

One of the faults is that unions assume that jobs are there, and that it is their right to do the jobs. They assume also that high wages are automatically there, and that jobs can be featherbedded in a lot of cases. But this is not the case. Jobs have to be created; they have to be changed; and they have to be exchanged. They are really a commodity just as money is a commodity. Money is the people's means of exchange, and that has also been hijacked by governments around the world. But in this legislation the Australian Labor Party has largely ignored the recommendations of the ILO and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is an obstruction to direct negotiations between employers and employees. We have to be more flexible in that area, not centralised and bureaucratised.

We cannot continue the absurd work practices that have bedevilled Australia over many years now, such as working to rules, slow-downs, demarcation disputes, go-slows, featherbedding, and the interminable industrial disputes to which we are subjected-and most of them for the most paltry of reasons. We have to be able to guarantee our prices and our delivery dates for overseas commodity sales. All the union actions that have been taken in the past have delayed our delivery dates, increased our costs and made us uncompetitive. This Industrial Relations Bill actually proposes the maintenance of heavily controlled, heavily centralised and heavy bureaucratic procedures and it will continue to cripple our chances to compete on the international stage. I welcome the chance to debate the Bill in the committee stage that is coming up and I support the 50 amendments that are proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of my colleagues have addressed in considerable detail many of the policies that are enunciated in the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 and the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988 which are currently before us. They have outlined a number of reservations and a number of qualifications in many areas. As Senator Sheil has just pointed out, a range of amendments will be proposed by Senator Chaney in the consideration of the detail of the Industrial Relations Bill. I would like to comment particularly with regard to the application of this legislation in the Northern Territory and how it will relate to the need to protect Northern Territory tribunals. Senator Chaney has distributed a proposed amendment to the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill and that will come before us later in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the Government's legislation would be to remove any statutory protection for the police and prisons arbitral tribunals which are constituted under Northern Territory legislation. Such a move would be totally inappropriate at a time when the Northern Territory is moving towards Statehood. If these two local tribunals were to cease to exist and have their functions taken over by the new Industrial Relations Commission, the only control that the Territory has over industrial relations would be lost. I appreciate that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, has claimed that he does not intend to eliminate the tribunals but he proposes to structure them by way of regulation. I do not believe that that is good enough. The effect of removing the statutory protection that is provided under the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act for these tribunals was established prior to self-government on 1 July 1978.

The police and prison arbitral tribunals have a particular and special functional role in the Northern Territory. I wish to highlight the work that goes on in the police forces and the prison service of the Northern Territory. The men and women who work in these areas of the Public Service in the Northern Territory have a very demanding, functional job to do. The role of a police officer or a prison worker is certainly compounded by the peculiar problems that exist in the Northern Territory. They do a fine job and are an integral part of the Northern Territory's unique Public Service.

The provisions as proposed by the Federal Government in the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill, if passed, would remove that statutory protection and, therefore, subject employment in the police and prison service in the Northern Territory to the provision of the Federal industrial relations legislation. The problem is that the Northern Territory would then have to rely totally on the Minister's undertakings with regard to regulations.

There are some very good and cogent reasons for maintaining the status quo. The constitutional history and development of the Northern Territory, moving from a governed Territory to a self-governing Territory in 1978 and now the progression towards full Statehood status within Australia, is most important to the Northern Territory. As has been stated on previous occasions, the Federal coalition parties support the move of the Northern Territory towards full State status. We believe, therefore, that it should be entitled to all the rights, benefits and responsibilities that apply to a State of Australia, including industrial relations. Indeed, in the explanatory memorandum attached to the Budget legislation which recently came before the Parliament the Northern Territory, for the first time, is described by the Labor Government as being funded on a seventh State basis. That is the actual phrase that has been introduced into the financial arrangements and, therefore, it should be extended to these other very important industrial relations areas.

For the Federal Labour Government now to move at this time of constitutional development of the Northern Territory to further restrict the industrial relations responsibilities of the Territory is short-sighted. A substantial number of employees in the Northern Territory are already covered by awards of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly cannot at present legislate on industrial relations matters. This amendment to the self-government Act by the Bill before us would further limit the powers of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in this regard. This is a retrograde step while the Territory is moving towards obtaining the status of a State.

The Northern Territory Government itself has not been silent on this matter and over the past few years has made approaches to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and his Department raising their concern about these changes. At best the response has been that there is no intention to remove the protection for the two Northern Territory tribunals and that in future the protection will be given by way of regulations under the new industrial relations legislation. If there is no intention to remove the protection for the two Northern Territory tribunals why then is it necessary to amend the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act at all? There is an inherent flaw in proceeding in the manner proposed by the Minister for Industrial Relations.

While the protection continues to be embodied in the legislation, any requirement to alter the provision will require an amendment to the legislation to be brought to this Parliament-it can then be subject to the full parliamentary process and be fully debated before being passed into law. However, if the protection is provided only by regulation any change to those regulations is not automatically subject to the full parliamentary process and virtually by the stroke of a pen the Minister could alter the arrangements to the detriment of the Northern Territory's responsibilities for these two important tribunals. As we all know, it is far easier to alter regulations than it is to alter legislation, even if that be the whim of the Minister. Whilst my colleague Senator Collins may well be Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, and I would hope that he would be vigilant if ever a matter such as this came before him, one cannot be assured that Senator Collins will always be Chairman of this Committee and that the new Chairman would share my concerns for the Territory on this matter.

The amendment to the Bill, as proposed by Senator Chaney, will preclude such actions and overcome the difficulties by maintaining the status quo in the new legislation. I see it as imperative that the Northern Territory retain the legislative protection currently afforded by the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act enabling the two tribunals to be established under Northern Territory legislation. This Parliament should not at this time take away any industrial relations responsibilities at a time when the Northern Territory is looking towards statehood and assuming all the rights, privileges and responsibilities of a State, particularly with regard to its own Public Service employees. This Parliament should not be removing such responsibilities at a time when the Northern Territory is showing a willingness and is making positive moves towards statehood.

These moves have been widely accepted throughout the Northern Territory community. The Northern Territory Government, in the past few months, has conducted a very open public awareness campaign throughout the Territory. It has invited debate and criticism of the areas that need to be developed particularly as the Territory moves towards statehood and the development of its own constitution. Senator Chaney's proposed amendments to the Bill maintain the status quo and I commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not doubt for a minute that the latter group exists. I respond by saying that this extraordinary view of industrial relations put by Senator Sheil-in other words, that the market would control these matters and the employers and employees could work it out between themselves-presumably would lead to some sort of social paradise where there would be no exploitation. There is a general view in the community that all the dreadful things that happened half a century ago could not be repeated today.

I will briefly recount a story about the Berimmah Baked Bricks company in Darwin, and I am sure that Senator Tambling is aware of this story. I hasten to say that the management of this factory in Darwin has now changed. This incident occurred only four or five years ago. An illegal immigrant from Indonesia entered Darwin and hid out in the bush behind the brick factory. Somehow or other the management of the factory discovered that this man was an illegal immigrant who feared that he would be found out and returned to Indonesia. As a result, the management employed him to work in the brick factory. Of course, the other employees noticed this gentleman turning up every day, working the full eight hours and then disappearing at the end of the day and, as far as they were concerned, going home. TALK.START.PARA: —The wetback syndrome.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their fulsome contributions to this debate. I have not been able to hear them all but, of course, as long as I have been in the Senate a debate on industrial relations has brought out the demonology in Australian society and politics. I heard Senator Reid talking at great length about a garbage dispute in Canberra and also heard Senator Alston retailing his experiences as a student-many decades ago, I assume-when trying to work on a building site. All these things simply display a common recognition of the fact that there are problems in the industrial relations arena and the issues we have to debate really go to the best way to solve those problems. That is a legitimate topic for debate. I do not want to dwell on particular graphic issues of industrial disputation and disagreements between parties leading to detriment to the Australian community; rather, I want to concentrate on what the Government thinks is the best way of trying to resolve these issues, not only in the short term but also for the long haul. Much of that is based on bringing about attitudinal changes of one kind or another in both management and the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement I have just made is trite in the sense that if one follows industrial relations debates in the Senate for as long as I have been here, one finds that they were characterised throughout the 1970s, for example, by a paper given by Malcolm Fraser, the former Prime Minister, in which he always talked about the importance of employers and employees reaching agreement and the consensual approach to industrial relations as the desired approach, but he then went on to cover his flank, as it were, by saying that there must be legislation which carries consequences if that level of agreement cannot be arrived at. That was the linchpin of the debate about industrial relations throughout the 1970s. All sorts of things have been tried by parliaments in terms of legislation and changes to it, but the basic issue is still one involving attitudinal change, which is fundamental.

These Bills now before the Senate-the Industrial Relations Bill and the associated Bill-are an important element in the Government's industrial relations reform agenda. They reflect the Government's approach to industrial relations. That approach is based on a philosophy of consultation and cooperation rather than confrontation. We would say that it is in contrast to the Opposition's policy, which we believe encourages conflict. The Government's industrial relations approach embodies a number of things: for example, a more effective system of industrial regulation; a fair and equitable wages system; the extension, importantly, of opportunities for training and skills enhancement; the minimisation of industrial disputes through cooperation; increased involvement by employees in work place decision-making that affects their working lives; safer and better working environments; the elimination of discrimination in the work place; and the creation of greater job security. Many of these objectives are, in a sense, common ground. The real question is how best to achieve them in the Australian context.

All sorts of analogies and comparisons are drawn with countries such as Japan and the United States. In fact, the Japanese and United States models of industrial relations are the ones most used by Opposition senators by way of supportive comparison for what they have to say. Extraordinarily, the German model, which is perhaps the most successful in the world--

TALK.START.PARA: —We will never get down to 16 unions.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the extraordinary things about the references to the Japanese model is that the Liberal Party says that it is on about labour market deregulation-a free and open labour market. TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I make about the table is that Senator Chaney's comparative figures are based on working days lost per 1,000 employed, whereas the figures I have tabled are working days lost per 1,000 employees. The figures used by Senator Chaney are unsuitable for comparison as they include employers, the self-employed, members of the defence forces, and others who are not under any circumstances normally engaged in industrial action of one kind or another. There are all sorts of definitional comparisons and so on which make cross-country differences unreliable. Some of the comparisons used by Senator Chaney tend to show Australia's record to be relatively worse than is the actual position. For example, Australian figures include all disputes involving the loss of more than 10 working days in aggregate, but the United States example chosen for comparison does not count disputes involving fewer than 1,000 workers. The table I have just had incorporated in Hansard shows that, notwithstanding definitional inconsistencies, Australia's record was above that of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average for the period 1976 to 1982, a period of Liberal government, but below the OECD average for the period 1983 to 1986, the period of the present Government. To put the Australian figures in context, the number of working days lost recorded in 1986 means that on average during the whole year each member of the work force stopped work for less than one quarter of one working day. An independent research by Messrs Beggs and Chapman of the Australian National University concluded that the Hawke Government consensus based incomes policies have been instrumental in reducing the level of industrial disputation in Australia. That research found that the levels of disputes were 82 per cent below those in the period 1964 to 1982. They go on to say that this lower level of disputation has been a matter arising from Government policies, and has not been simply a manifestation of international events and forces.

SPEECH.PARA: If the table that I have just referred to is studied by honourable senators, they will see that in the period 1983 to 1986 Australia had a much lower level of industrial disputation than did Canada, Denmark, Finland, Greece, Ireland, Italy, New Zealand, Spain, and the United Kingdom, for example.

Senator Chaney also made a considerable point about the fact that we claim-and I think this claim is supported by all the evidence-that a reduction in wage outcomes under the present Government's policies and attitudes, with the average annual level of increase in nominal earnings, is about half the level that prevailed during the Fraser years. I want to refer back to that point at a later stage in the debate.

The third thing which the approach of the present Government has brought to industrial relations is an extraordinary attitudinal change on the part of both employers and unions, as evidenced in the operation of the two-tier wage system. This system saw for the first time employers, employees and unions reaching agreements which embodied significant productivity improvements, major reforms in work place activities, and so on. I cited yesterday in Question Time, I think, an example of the efforts of parties in relation to the metal trades award in terms of the structural change and productivity increases which will flow from that.

Also under the present Government's policies there is a growing consensus amongst industrial parties represented at peak levels of organisations. I refer to joint publications of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) in relation to work practices, and the very important Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. publication, called Untying the Knot, about reducing inflexibility in the industrial system. It would be vulgar to dwell at great length on the documented achievements of this Government in the industrial relations system, including levels of disputation. Senator Chaney says, `It's still not good enough.' I agree with him; there is no dispute about that. However, the level of achievement has been enormous.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could narrow the areas of disputes.

—If Senator Chaney would lower the level of dispute to concede that we probably would be much further forward. All these things have been achieved at the same time as there has been growth in gross domestic product of 4.2 per cent in 1987 which compares favourably with that of other OECD countries, a reduction in the current account deficit, a reduction in the inflation rate, an increase in total employment of 3 per cent in 1987-88, and a reduction in the unemployment rate in 1987-88 by 0.5 per cent to 7.8 per cent. This Bill is introduced against a background of the most impressive industrial relations record of any Australian Government. This legislation is being developed to complement such achievements and to facilitate further reform.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of points have been raised in the debate. I turn to that debate as it has progressed so far. The amendments moved by Senator Chaney on behalf of the Opposition-both the Liberals and the Democrats have moved amendments-represent a vehicle for advancing a view about industrial relations. It is a view which is present in the debate internationally. They are not serious amendments. The amendments moved by Senator Chaney as a package advance a view which I would describe as a somewhat ideological view. That is not a bad thing; I am not condemning that. They leave the Government legislation substantially intact in so far as the existing structure of the system, the current industrial parties, and the current union structures are concerned. They leave intact, of course, what is almost impossible to overcome in a very quick way; the fact that we have a Federal system of government in Australia and this Federal legislation is, in a sense, complemented by or complementary to legislation which exists throughout the States.

If these changes were made in the way they are proposed-as I said, they represent a vehicle for advancing a particular view of industrial relations issues-we would have the most unholy shambles. We would have Federal legislation which still carried the mainstream structures and powers of the past with a number of changes grafted onto it and, at the same time, different systems would operate in the States. That would be highly detrimental to any system of industrial relations because there is a need-even if one were to believe in Senator Chaney's view, which I do not-for transition mechanisms.

The speeches made by other honourable senators have covered industrial relations generally. They have suggested what should be contained in the Federal industrial relations legislation. Inevitably they are properly concentrated on differences in approach between the Government and the Opposition. Of course there are some points on which we all agree. We are all approaching it from different directions and we all want a better industrial relations system. As I said at the beginning of my speech, the question is how to get there.

The Opposition criticises the Bill because it says that it will not achieve improvements in productivity and industrial efficiency. Senator Chaney claimed that the commissioners unnecessarily prevented employers and workers from reaching their own agreements about the performance of work and conditions of employment. He said that the current system hinders labour market flexibility. In some ways these assertions do not adequately reflect the existing situation or the improvements proposed under the Bill. The successes which this Government has had to date could not have been achieved without a relatively successful Federal conciliation and arbitration system, a tribunal which Senator Chaney castigates as being the instrument for a spectacularly successful wages policy. If it is not recognised here, it is recognised internationally as such.

Federally registered unions which the Opposition apparently regard as some sort of industrial dinosaurs, and which will still remain, even if Senator Chaney's amendments are carried, are contributing to the achievement of substantial productivity improvement through restructuring of awards-which they have been very good at initiating in some industries-progress towards multiskilling, the elimination of restrictive work practices, and the development of industrial democracy on the European model. Basic change has been quite rapid and the existing system has been able to deal with it. I think it is important to remember that industrial friction caused by change must be avoided in transitional mechanisms.

The industrial relations system to which I have referred it retained and improved under the provisions of this Bill. What I want to say next represents the kernel of the differences in approach between the Government and the Opposition, in the context of this Bill. The Bill adds provisions enabling the Commission to authorise the entering into of certified agreements providing for particular arrangements about the performance of work, employment conditions, rates of pay and so on, which are specific to the parties to the agreement. Under this Bill one can arrive at an agreement in an enterprise or workplace between the employer and the employees or their representatives, and one can have that agreement certified by the Commission. The Opposition says: `We believe that. We can do that, too. The way we would do it is to have such agreements entered into at the enterprise level by bargaining units'-I forget what the Opposition calls them; it is something like that-`without the provision for certification.' That is very important because there are two reasons for having that provision for certification, via the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, of agreements reached between the parties at an enterprise or other level.

The first reason is to avoid the sort of abuse where, in particular circumstances, conditions-wages, hours of work, and so on-can be lowered without reference to the capacity of the firm or industrial entity or whether it needs those changed conditions in order to manage the problem which it has in terms of wages and levels of conditions. There is a safeguard provided by the certification procedure of the Commission; that is, there is an outside party which can look at the question of whether that is a reasonable agreement.

The second reason why the certification procedure is necessary is exactly opposite. If unions or employees in an establishment reach agreement on very high levels of wages and shorter hours, there is still wisdom in having the agreement certified by the Commission to prevent movement of those conditions, wages and so on into other sectors of the economy. So there are two purposes for the certification procedure which are less flexible, perhaps, than the Opposition would suggest, but they are very important in terms of keeping a moderating influence in the industrial relations system in this country. Senator Hill dismissed this proposal as timid. It has been endorsed by the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures. It is a very important provision which I think is at the nub of what this debate is about.

The second area of difference relates to the role and powers of the proposed Industrial Relations Commission. There was much reference to the present Conciliation and Arbitration Commission obstructing employers and employees. Reference was made by Senator Chaney to some recent cases which I have neither the time nor the inclination to go into because some of them are still before the arbitration tribunals. He described the second tier system as a very bureaucratic and centralised way of impressing on enterprises the need for flexibility, and as a barrier to change. If he believes that, it amounts to a triumph of ideology over experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are plenty of people in enterprises who would say exactly the same thing.

—Yes, and plenty who would not. The Government's proposals for the new Commission have a number of characteristics which are essential for a successful system. Effective independent machinery is provided to resolve disputes. The interests of the parties and the wider public interest are safeguarded. I will say no more about those matters because we can talk about them during the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The third main area of debate relates to the compliance measures. I will not summarise the Opposition's position at this point, but we believe that it is a distorted view of the history of the legislation. The 1987 legislation contained a comprehensive package of compliance measures, but excluded common law injunctions and actions under State legislation. There was a great clamour from employers and the Opposition about the provisions. A publicity campaign was launched and the Government agreed to defer the legislation. We now have the legislation in its existing form. Again, it is a matter which we can pursue when we discuss the compliance provisions at the committee stage. Senator McLean, of course, recognised the good sense of the decision which was ultimately made. As for the 1988 Bill, it is not true to say that it is devoid of compliance measures. The Government is trying to secure voluntary compliance at every opportunity, because that is the best means of achieving industrial relations results.

The fourth area of debate relates to individual and collective rights and obligations. Let me make these points quickly: this legislation does not authorise closed shops; the Commission's powers will be confined to awarding preference; a responsible system of conscientious objection is maintained. It is quite wrong to claim that the Bill will place Australia in breach of international standards of freedom of association-as some honourable senators, including Senator Knowles, Senator Chaney and others, have said-because these international standards do not require legislative protection of the right not to join a union. Much has been said about individual freedoms and rights. I quote briefly from the report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation chaired by Senator Harradine, tabled in the Senate in 1982:

Some individuals are quick to recognise their perceived rights but are not also as quick to recognise their duty to associate with others for the common good. In addition there is a distinction between personal choice based on conscientious belief on the one hand and the dictates of self-centred individualism on the other.
Those are the immortal words of Senator Harradine, who must be regarded as something of an individual, if not self-centred.

The other main areas of debate, of course, relate to union structures. The Opposition criticises the Government for its changes in relation to the registration and amalgamation of unions. The Opposition, unlike Senator McLean, overlooks what is achievable in our system. Its views are totally contrary to those of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, the Myers report, the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry, and the Coombs Royal Commission, all of which recommended fewer unions and higher membership requirements.

I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. I seem to have run out of time. We will have the opportunity during the committee stage to deal with some of the other issues at length.
