The amendments put forward changes which will bring into this legislation some of the elements of the industrial relations policy which the Opposition announced in June of this year. The major thrust of the amendments is to reduce the centralised elements of the system by making it more flexible, including the operation of the centralised system itself, and indeed the first amendment goes to that question.

SPEECH.PARA: The second bank of amendments relates to the question of voluntary unionism and that has a certain piquancy today in the Senate, given that a couple of people just lost their jobs in this Parliament House because of their refusal to join or not to join trade unions as they please rather than being subject to the direction of a trade union or indeed an employer in that regard. There will be a bank of amendments which relate to the fact that at the moment, on the admission of the Government itself, there are no effective compliance provisions in the law in relation to voluntary compliance, which is the sort of compliance that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has just indicated he would prefer to see where voluntary compliance for one reason or another is simply not occurring. Nobody would quarrel with what Senator Button had to say a few minutes ago which was that the voluntary compliance would be preferred.

The reality is, and it is known to virtually every Australian, that at times people involved in the industrial relations system in Australia flout the right of other people and do not comply with their obligations under the system. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) advised the Parliament in May of last year that the present compliance provisions are effectively moribund. They are not working and this Bill does nothing to remedy that deficiency. We will be proposing amendments to change the provisions relating to trade union structure. We do that because this Bill is promoting a viewpoint which has been advanced by the ACTU that in matters relating to trade unions, big is beautiful. Apparently size is the criterion for excellence. That is a view which is certainly not shared by the Opposition and is not shared by participants in the industrial relations field, including many trade union participants.

The idea that it is only small unions which cause difficulties in the industrial relations system and the idea that creating larger unions through amalgamations which may have little or nothing to do with the logical industry structure will necessarily improve things, is not a viewpoint which is accepted by the Opposition or by many people who, on a day to day basis, are practically involved in this industrial relations system. The approach of the Opposition is one which aims to pay much greater regard to the principle of freedom of association. We believe that in Australia one should start with the proposition that individuals are free to join or not to join trade unions, or indeed to join or not to join employer associations, according to their perception of their own interest. It should not be a situation where they are bullied or intimidated or told that it will cost them their business or their employment if they do not go along with the directions of somebody that they must join an association, a trade union or otherwise, without regard to their personal preference.

The principle that we are advancing in our amendments is that the public interest lies in promoting direct employer-employee dealing at the enterprise level. In other words, if we want a more productive Australia-and we need a more productive Australia if living standards are to rise and we are to pay off our debts; indeed I understand that the objectives of the Government are to produce a more productive Australia-then we have to encourage greater direct dealing and cooperation between employers and employees in this country. It is a widely understood fact that in many circumstances existing trade union structures and not least those structures which are already large, often intervene in a quite destructive way in the direct and cooperative dealings between employers and employees.

Our amendments aim to facilitate the creation of single enterprise bargaining units. We are in no sense setting our face against trade unions; that is not a matter which is even in the back of our minds. It is certainly no part of our agenda. What we are saying is that we want units which are relevant to the economic challenges which face this country and to the economic task that individual enterprises have to perform.

The question of large or small, in our view, has been grossly overplayed in this particular debate. One can point to Germany and to the small number of large unions in that country as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce did in his response. One can equally point to Japan where there are a very large number of small unions. In each case one can say that there has been a success in achieving continuous economic growth and a high level of productivity as well as a high level of competitiveness. What we would say about both Japan and Germany is that the union structures that they have do not, as they do in Australia, interrupt or interfere with the workplace relationships within enterprises. That is the disability, and is the fault in the system that our amendments seek to eradicate. We do not do that by saying that one can put into the law some direction as to precisely what shape trade unions should adopt. We say that in the end that is a matter for employers and employees to work out as they pursue their respective interests in the knowledge that they have an overriding common interest in prosperity and in success. We believe that if the structures are freed up to permit people to pursue their interests in that way, they will move to a more logical trade union structure for this country than the presently proposed amalgamations are likely to produce.

I am sure that in the course of the committee debate we will look at some of the proposals for amalgamation which lie on the table at the moment. I do not think that the Minister at the table will be able to say that those amalgamations are in any sense likely to produce a situation where we have the ideal of single enterprise bargaining units which enable people to deal with each other without the complexity of demarcation disputes and so on. I suppose the simplest argument that is normally advanced with respect to the large union question is that it is likely to lead to a reduction in the number of demarcation disputes. I hope that the Minister might be able to produce some hard evidence that that is so. I do not think that he will. On what we have seen of the statistics it appears that he is more likely to have difficulties in the demarcation dispute area where we are dealing with large craft based unions than if we are dealing with small unions. Indeed the case has been put directly to the Opposition by a number of small unions that they are not the source of industrial problems, that it is much more likely to be the larger trade unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have small craft based unions you derogate from the possibility of multiskilling and a whole range of flexibility. That is the problem.

—That is fine to the extent that people can be encouraged to enter into the award restructuring which is currently under way and to the extent that they can be brought into more rational industry based or enterprise based structures. Those propositions will certainly have the support of the Opposition. What we say is that the mere pursuit of size will not of itself produce the outcome that the Minister apparently wants to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: In these general comments, I want to challenge the suggestion that what has been put forward by the Opposition are not serious amendments, that they are merely a vehicle for advancing a view. The fact of the matter is that if one looks at, for example, the enforcement provisions and the compliance provisions that the Opposition is proposing should be inserted into this Bill, one sees that they are very much along the lines of the compliance provisions which the Minister sought to put into the predecessor to this Bill just a little over 12 months ago.

I think it is quite absurd to suggest that the enactment of effective compliance provisions in the Federal legislation will in some way destroy the balance of this Bill or in any way cause an imbalance or a problem in terms of the varying State and Federal jurisdictions which will continue to apply to this country. I think that the general comments made by the Minister are simply not warranted on facts and again I invite him during the course of the debate to demonstrate, where particular amendments are being brought forward, in what way those amendments will interfere with, or conflict with, the operation of the federal system of industrial relations which will continue to apply in this country.

I also want to say that, whilst there may be a good deal of common ground between the Government and the Opposition with respect to the general objectives which are being pursued, a government will continue to get the support of the Opposition where it pursues policies which will add to the flexibility of the labour market in this country. I give an example of that in our support and encouragement of the approach to award restructuring which has been pioneered by the metal trades associations and the metal unions. We certainly think this is a substantial and positive move in the Australian labour market. Those areas of agreement should not mask the fact that what we are seeking to do is remove elements of the present system which prevent more of that successful move towards flexibility than can apply under the Government's proposals.

Senator Button referred to the Government's spectacularly successful wages policy. The truth of the matter is that productivity in this country remains stagnant and nominal wages, that is the amount of money wages that people receive in this country, will go up again this year at about twice the rate of many of our trading competitors. Our competitiveness will not decline, because our inflation rate is also running at or worse than twice the rate of many of our trading competitors. But it is simply not a satisfactory outcome for Australia to go on having money wage increases which are simply gobbled up by a high level of inflation which preserves our competitiveness merely by in the long term guaranteeing that we will have a less valuable currency, by inflating ourselves in that direction.

I agree with the Minister that friction has to be avoided in transitional mechanisms as the system pushes towards greater flexibility. Again I invite him during the discussion on specific amendments to tell the chamber where any proposal of the Opposition would give rise to additional friction-by which I guess he means industrial disputation or industrial difficulties within workplaces.

I make those general comments because the Opposition is seeking in the circulated amendments to move the system further down the path of greater flexibility because we believe that is vital to us. We think that our international debt and our stagnant living standards can be dealt with only if we achieve higher productivity. We go along with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and those other bodies which have reported on the Australian labour market and regard the need for greater flexibility as virtually self-evident. I commend clauses 1 and 2 of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The expression `industrial disputes' in the objectives of the Bill must be read in the light of the definition in the Bill. It requires a number of other things. If, by the Opposition's amendments, the legislation is changed to a system based on enterprise bargaining between employers and employees directly, that will remove the parties to industrial disputes as defined in this legislation-and as still will be defined in this legislation after the Opposition's amendments. If one looks at clause 3 and the Opposition amendments one sees the inconsistencies which are already arising.

I was trying to make a point about the conflict inherent in the transitional phase. There is a whole system of interrelated State and Federal industrial tribunals. TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably true that we could deal with the issues that have now been raised by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in dealing with the specific amendments that are to be moved to clause 3. In other words, this Bill covers only one element of the industrial relations system in this country, that is, the element which is under the Commonwealth conciliation and arbitration power and which is dealt with by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We have, contemporaneously with that, a series of State commissions and there is a degree of interaction between those two systems.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite apart from that, there are a very substantial number of employer-employee relationships in this country which are of a contractual or informal nature and a very substantial number, particularly in the small business sector of the Australian business community, where these formal State and Commonwealth systems have very little impact. The Commonwealth system, not of necessity but in fact, can impact upon those other arrangements. I suspect that during the committee stage we will be debating, for example, the efforts which have been made by the trade union movement to interfere with the early attempts in Queensland to deal with employee-employer relationships by means of voluntary employment agreements. It is vitally important that this Act-we know it will become an Act-does not contain provisions which can be used to override other elements of the industrial relations system within Australia which are moving down the very track that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has sought to promote. There has been no more assiduous Minister in the Government in promoting the whole idea that Australians have to develop a new workplace culture. As I understand it, Senator Button has been urging the Australian people that they have to become much more concerned about quality and productivity. He is seeking major changes in the way we think and behave in our workplaces. The Budget Papers talk about the mullock heaps of restrictive practices in this country.

The Opposition amendments are aiming to ensure that the positive movements in industrial relations in this country are preserved and, where possible, accelerated. I simply make the point to the Minister that he was quite wrong when he suggested that in these amendments we are trying to move completely down the path of our own policy. We have not put forward amendments for the very broad framework that we envisage which would enable employers and employees generally to regulate the whole of their workplace arrangements by agreement. We have not put forward that sort of fundamental second stream approach in this set of amendments.

Our general approach is that, for that approach to succeed, it is very important that the overall industrial relations framework be in an appropriate condition so that employers and employees are dealing with each other on a basis of reasonable equality, and there is not an imbalance of power in the relationship. Given the Government's resistance to sensible compliance provisions-the sorts of provisions that it sought to put in the Act in only May of last year-and given the Government's resistance to the principle of voluntary unionism, we do not think it is appropriate at this stage to be putting forward those detailed amendments which, by inference at least, Senator Button was suggesting are part of the package of amendments we are putting up now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a series of amendments to clause 3. Firstly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, paragraph 3 (a), lines 10 and 11, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
`(a) to promote industrial harmony and co-operation between employers and employees;'.
Mr Chairman, the existing object which I seek to delete reads:
3. The objects of this Act are:
(a) to promote industrial harmony and co-operation among the parties involved in industrial relations in Australia;

We are seeking quite specifically to remove the reference to `parties involved in industrial relations in Australia' and to use the expression `employers and employees'. We are moving that amendment because we think it is a simple matter of fact that if Australia is to have a more productive economy then it is central that we get better workplace relationships. In particular, there should be the closest possible cooperation between employers and employees and, as far as possible, direct dealing between employers and employees.

Over the two-year period when I was spokesman for the Opposition on matters relating to industry, technology and commerce, shadowing Senator Button, I spent a great deal of time talking to people who were in the business of trying to improve their productivity. I visited many enterprises in Australia. Subsequently I spent some time visiting enterprises in the United States. The pattern was exactly the same in every case, namely, that if a firm was successful in increasing its productivity, that was a function of a good, positive and direct working relationship between employers and employees. It seemed to me to be a common factor. In those circumstances anything which gets in the way of, or which is a barrier to, that sort of direct dealing, is clearly a significant negative, not only for the employers and the employees concerned-although it is important to them because the capacity both to maintain employment and to make higher profits, and hence to pay higher wages, depends on their success in working together-but also for the national interest. Our overall level of debt and lack of productivity rises are matters of concern to every Australian and adversely affect every Australian.

I have made the point in a number of debates in this chamber that elements of the current system which would not be changed by this legislation can get in the way of what we are seeking to promote. An example from the Minister's own State of Victoria which I cited was the failure of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union successfully to undertake second tier negotiations in the meat industry. A number of employees and employers saw that their common interests would be served by their getting together and working out how to improve productivity and pay higher wages.

I gave the quite specific example of a company known as Castle Bacon Pty Ltd, with a work force of over 500 employees, which, on the basis of direct discussion with its employees, obtained agreement to a series of productivity improvements and, in turn, gave its agreement to a 4 per cent wage increase. The employees concerned elected six representatives to put their case to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. They went before the Commission and applied to have the agreement given effect to under the restructuring and efficiency principles of the last national wage case. That was successfully opposed by the union.

The tragedy is that the Commission, in acceding to the union request, not only brought the union in as a party, but also did not countenance a series of productivity improvements. It put in a series of relatively minor gains, which the employer thought were worth maybe 1.9 per cent, rather than 4 per cent. The sad thing for Australia as well as for the people involved is that a chance to make a productivity gain was cast aside. That resulted from the system having as its concern the parties to our industrial relations system, namely, employer organisations and trade unions, and employers and trade unions, and not the people who are really involved-the employers and employees.

I gave another example of meatworks in Queensland in very similar circumstances. The Deputy President of the Arbitration Commission, Mr Riordan, a Labor ex-member of this Parliament, said that all discussions between `the parties'-his expression-should involve the union, employer organisation and employer. His direction was:

Employer-initiated conferences at an enterprise level occurring without the presence of the union should cease because such conferences will not assist this Commission in its important task of preventing and resolving disputes.

The Opposition is in no way seeking to keep a trade union out of an issue where there is a disagreement between employers and employees and the employees wish to be represented by a trade union. There is no suggestion that the trade unionists should have their freedom restricted in any way. Indeed, our later amendments will give employees greater freedom than the Government proposes to say who should represent their interests. Our policy is that, even where it is a matter of direct dealing outside the system, employees are entitled to nominate a union as their agent if they wish. There is no attempt to exclude the trade unions if that is what the employees want. But in the cases I have cited the trade union has been standing between the employees and a wage rise, and between the employers and productive changes. It is that which we think is an absurdity. It flies in the face of the logic of every general industry proposition that is put forward by this Government.

This amendment, therefore, seeks to say to the Commission which will henceforth be established under this Act that the object is to promote industrial harmony and cooperation among employers and employees, not some entity known as parties to industrial relations, but among the employers and employees who have to make things work in this country. I commend that principle and I invite the Minister to tell us why that is a difficulty for the Government and why it cannot be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be opposing this initial series of amendments. I would like to take the opportunity to touch on our general rationale. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the amendment moved by Senator Chaney to clause 3 and the further amendments Senator Chaney will be moving to this clause. Those amendments all go to the heart of our current industrial relations problems.

As I said, it is essential that we get to a situation where there is a much more direct relationship between employers and employees, where the responsibility for good industrial relations is referred to the workplace in which those industrial relations take place and industrial relations decisions are not taken at a level isolated from the workplace.

Unless the Opposition's amendments are accepted, this legislation will entrench the current longstanding practice of industrial relations in this country which has led to much industrial disputation because it does not relate to what is happening on the ground in the workplace. The reason for that is that this legislation is very much based on the recommendations of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. The Government acknowledged that earlier in the second reading debate. It must be remembered that the Hancock Committee membership was dominated by the cosy industrial relations club. It reflected the membership of industry peak councils, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and tribunals, which have all become a common interest group concentrating on short term compromise solutions rather than tackling basic problems and longer term issues with regard to industrial relations.

I believe that this legislation also owes something to the propositions put forward in that infamous document Australia Reconstructed, which sought to emphasise the corporate state and to institute bigger unions as part of the unions' push for the further entrenchment of their privileged position. Again, that is highlighted in this legislation, particularly when we consider the provisions with regard to the amalgamation of unions and the requirement that, within three years, all unions must have a membership of at least 3,000.

So we must move towards a more market-oriented system of industrial relations and wage determination. We must seek to overcome the advocacy nature of our present industrial relations structure, which heightens the atmosphere of conflict rather than promoting an atmosphere of cooperation between employers and employees. All it will do is guarantee a protraction of the dispute and, at the end of the day, when there is a finding, in no way will that be enforced to the point of ensuring that employees and employers comply.

SPEECH.PARA: We talk in that clause about the virtue of facilitating the consolidation of a single enterprise bargaining unit. That, in my view, is certain to promote industrial harmony and cooperation between employers and employees. For my part, I do not make judgments as to what is a suitable size for a union-whether it is 3,000, 1,000, 500 or 100. I do not think that that ought to be the criterion for good industrial relations or for good unions.
Progress reported.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Foreign Minister designate and Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the alleged comments by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in which the maturity of our closest neighbour, Papua New Guinea, was questioned; the 150 million people of Indonesia were described as `erratic and hostile'; our largest trading partner, Japan, was termed as hypocritical; and the then Foreign Minister of Malaysia was described as oafish. Does the Minister agree with these views of his former colleague and how does he reconcile them with the Government's alleged attempts at improving relations with the countries of South East Asia? Given the wide publicity that these views have now received and the significant position that Mr Hayden will shortly occupy in this country, what does the Government propose to do to minimise the damage done to our relations with our nearest neighbours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government strongly regrets and condemns any leak of sensitive information at any time. The reports in this morning's press are therefore a matter of serious concern to the Government. If the documents of the kind described are indeed in the possession of Mr Toohey, obviously they were obtained illegally. The facts do need to be fully investigated before anyone, including Senator Chaney, jumps to any conclusions about anything. This morning the Government moved promptly to initiate an investigation, to be conducted by the Australian Federal Police. Until we have the results of that investigation it is not appropriate to comment-and clearly we cannot-on the circumstances which may have produced the reports in question. Obviously we are fully conscious of the need to explore all the proper steps that might be taken to protect Australia's interests from the damage that could be done as a result of the publication of confidential material relating to foreign affairs and national security.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the substance of the documents which Mr Toohey claims to have obtained and to which Senator Chaney referred in his question, there is only one general comment that I think can be appropriately made at this stage: other countries can be completely assured that Australia's foreign policy is as has been articulated in definitive statements by the Government, including our complete commitment to the development of friendly and productive relations with all countries in our region and our commitment to an independent foreign policy based on Australia's national interests. None of this is qualified in any way by the publication of alleged private comments by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response and note his reliance on the policy as articulated, but I draw his attention to the difficulty in pursuing that policy and convincing our neighbours that that is our policy when reports of this nature are available. Will the Minister keep the Senate fully informed on the inquiries that he says are being made? This is no longer a matter of private government administration; it is now a matter of public interest going to the maladministration of foreign affairs by this Government. Will the Minister give a clear undertaking that this Senate will be kept fully advised on the inquiries the Government is undertaking and of the outcome and the action which the Government proposes to take?

—I do not concede for a moment that any question of maladministration is involved here. Without conceding the accuracy of any of the allegedly leaked documents, it is of course quite proper for opinions to be expressed privately by Ministers to officials in the course of their duties. What is outrageous is that comments and material of that obvious sensitivity, and which are part and parcel of the administration of any department and any government, can be leaked, if indeed that has been the case in this instance. Yes, I will keep the Senate informed as to the progress of the investigation, because obviously an issue of significant public importance and interest is involved.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of an article appearing in the Australian of 30 August which claims that the Government does not have adequate monitoring powers in place to check the progress of the partnership for development agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That article was drawn to my attention and I understand from what might be called the grapevine that it had not been completed at the time it went to print, which might explain some of the things in it that I found difficult to understand. First, for example, it referred to the partnership for development agreements as a trend to industry protection at the same time that tariffs were being lowered in other areas. No one is being asked to engage in any uncompetitive activity internationally as a result of the partnership for development agreements. So I find that unusual. The article also said that there is difficulty in monitoring offset requirements. It is not that there is difficulty in monitoring offset requirements under the offsets scheme, but difficulty for international corporations to find appropriate offset partners. It is very difficult for them to do that and that is a problem, as is monitoring.

ANSWER.PARA: The article says that there are not adequate monitoring powers in place to check the progress of partnership for development agreements. The terms of the partnership for development agreements have been clearly stated on a number of occasions with respect to performance, research, development and exports. The agreements are audited annually in terms of progress under the commitments made by the partner. In each of the partnerships annual targets are established, and they are audited. The review process also focuses on future activities by the partners and, of course, there is also a provision for the termination of partnership agreements by the Commonwealth which could be utilised where serious under-performance by a partner is established in the audit process.

What is the sanction with respect to Commonwealth termination? The sanction with respect to Commonwealth termination is simply that by entering into a partnership agreement the Commonwealth acknowledges that an international corporation has established activities in this country in the field of research and development, manufacturing perhaps, and software development in terms of the provision of computer industry related services which are of such order that the partner can be absolved from its obligations under the offsets program. If the Commonwealth in the course of terminating an agreement says, `This company is no longer of this character', I would have thought that that would be something of a sanction. As I said to Senator Lewis the other day while answering a question, these agreements do not represent contractual relationships between the Commonwealth and the corporate partners. There are no binding commercial contracts; it is not intended to be that way. It is an arrangement between the Commonwealth and international information industry companies as to how they do business in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you leave a partnership if it is not a binding commercial agreement?
—Very simply.
—If you have an arrangement, you can call it what you like.
—If we do not want to call it a partnership, we call it something else.
—Nonsense! You are a lawyer. Didn't you learn anything?

—I am a lawyer but not a pedant, and there is an important distinction between the two. Senator Lewis understands what I am saying. I am sure that if he has anything to contribute to this matter he will do it by way of debate and not by interjection.

—I refer the Minister for Home Affairs to the failure so far by the House of Representatives to pass the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill to make informal all ticks and crosses votes during Saturday's referendum. Is it a fact that this failure, despite the agreed objectives of all parties in this Parliament, is because the Government has advice from the Attorney-General's Department that the Bill may cast some doubt on the constitutional validity of the referendum? Does the Minister recall my providing him earlier this week with an independent legal opinion by an eminent Queen's Counsel, Mr Alan Goldberg, strongly disputing the advice of the Attorney-General's Department? What is the Attorney-General's response to this opinion, and why is the Government still stalling on this issue? Given that Australians are going to vote on the referendum questions in three days' time, will the Minister now give the Senate an assurance that the Government will pass my Bill through the House of Representatives so that it will be absolutely beyond doubt that the only valid votes on Saturday will be those where people write `yes', or preferably `no', in the spaces provided on the ballot paper?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of Senator Short's question is yes; the answer to the second part is yes, by other reasons. Most people, if they just listen to Senator Short, would not understand the background. The allegation made by press release is that somehow this Government has been trying to have ticks and crosses by deliberate policy counted in this referendum. That accusation made by the Opposition is absolutely baseless.

ANSWER.PARA: The proof is that we introduced legislation into the House of Representatives in March which was passed, despite three attempted Liberal amendments, and which was put to this chamber on 3 June. The vital amendment that would have outlawed ticks and crosses was defeated by all those sitting opposite in alliance with the Democrats. So when one looks at the Government's bona fides on this matter, it is no use Opposition senators saying that the Government is stalling or trying to permit ticks and crosses. Our record is there. Last June we attempted to cover this point.

When the issue was again raised some weeks ago, I issued instructions for legislation to be prepared that would again make the situation quite clear-that is, that a distinct yes or a distinct no would be a valid vote, and that ticks and crosses would not be allowed. Acting on that, I put the processes in train. We then received advice from the Attorney-General's Department that it would be illegal to change the rules part way through the ballot. I provided that legal opinion from Mr Pat Brazil to Senator Short some days ago when it was in proper form.

Prior to that the Liberal Party of Australia sought informal advice and then received formal advice from Mr Allan Goldberg, a person whose knowledge in these areas I acknowledge here today. He is a lawyer who often takes cases for the Liberal Party and who often approaches these matters with an incisive mind-not an infallible mind.

Subsequent to receiving that advice I gave it to the Attorney-General's Department for an assessment. It has provided me-I must say that it came at only five minutes to two-with a written response which I shall table. The two key points in it that one must remember is that already many tens of thousands of people have voted by post and pre-poll voting. It is the view of the Attorney-General's Department that one cannot change the formality of their votes now. They have already cast their votes under existing law, and would endanger the legality of constitutional change to change the rules part way through.

I refer Senator Short to section 128 of the Constitution, which I am sure he has already looked at. Not only does the Opposition legislation propose to outlaw ticks and crosses, but anyone who makes a mistake in one of the squares and puts `No' or `Yes' and then crosses it out and puts `No' or `Yes' adjacent to the square, which has always been acceptable in House of Representatives elections, would also find their votes misdirected.

If the Opposition believes that the original advice from the Attorney-General's Department to the Electoral Commission-there is no government role in this per se-is wrong and that its interpretation of ticks and crosses is wrong, that will have to be taken up after the referendum. Anyone in this chamber with any realism would know that that will become a factor only if the vote is somewhere between 52 and 48 per cent. Anything over and above that, both sides will drop off and say that it is irrelevant.

The one lesson to be learned out of this relates to the Opposition's mentality of just opposing. I do not blame the shadow Minister in this place, but I blame Mr Reith and Mr Sharp in the House of Representatives who initiated this and who badly briefed Senator Short. They did not understand the proposal when it came up last March and June. It is quite clear from the debate in the House of Representatives that they did not understand it. If ticks and crosses are allowed in this election, it lies on the Opposition's heads. We cannot change the rules halfway through, nor will we. I table the advice for information of honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, without debating the earlier history as this is not the appropriate time. I disagree absolutely and very strongly with Senator Ray's interpretation of the earlier history. Does the Minister not agree that the Bill goes to the method of counting the vote, not the method of casting the vote, and that not one vote has yet been counted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of votes have already been cast under existing rules. It would not be right if we went into a House of Representatives election and announced three days before that there would be a proportional representation system. That is an absolutely ridiculous point.
—The instructions on the ballot paper are to vote yes or no.

—Of course, the instructions are to vote yes or no. Nothing that this Government has done has encouraged anyone to put a tick or a cross. Not only do the instructions say to vote yes or no, but anyone who advocates a tick or cross is subject to a $1,000 fine. Opposition members know that because we put it in the Act in 1983-84 to prevent people misleading the electorate. But one cannot change the rules halfway through if it imperils the legality of the Constitution.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short says that history has nothing to do with it, but when he attacks the Government's bona fides I believe that it is essential to look at history to see whether we have been malevolent on this issue or not. Our score is on the board. We tried to change the position last session, but the Opposition and the Democrats thought otherwise. They bear the responsibility, not the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Home Affairs aware that Perth residents are receiving in their letterboxes copies of a news sheet entitled `Wake up Australia', which contains arguments in favour of the No case for the Saturday referendums? Does the Minister realise that these news sheets have been carrying as inserts copies of the Liberal Party pamphlet advocating a No vote in the referendums? Could the Minister advise whether the distribution of the above information is in accordance with the laws governing referendums?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was drawn to my attention, I checked the Electoral Act. From my reading of it and that of a couple of others, there would be nothing illegal in the inserting of the Liberal Party No case in the League of Rights publication `Wake up Australia'. My source for this information checked with the publisher how it came upon these Liberal Party leaflets and was told that the Liberal Party had given them for distribution. Whether to distribute separately or in the magazine referred to remains unclear.

ANSWER.PARA: It is fairly disappointing but is typical of the referendum case of smear and fear run by the No case that they should go to the extremes they have gone to. They have gone to a whole range of extremes of distortion, especially in regard to questions 1 and 4-never confronting the central issue, but drifting off into the dark side of politics, as they do on a lot of other issues. There could be no bigger drift than to use the League of Rights in this campaign, as the Liberal Party in Western Australia appears to have done. But it was not long ago in the other chamber that Senator Boswell had to show courage to repudiate the League of Rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this chamber.

—When I say `in the other chamber', I am referring to the old Parliament House. This must be a unique occasion. The National Party is more or less in the vanguard of the decent thing. The National Party has repudiated the League of Rights and we have the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party going hand in hand with the League. I call on Western Australian Liberal senators to repudiate the League of Rights and the fact that they are using it for the No case in this referendum.

—On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister is debating the question. The question was whether it was legal or not, and he has already answered that. I submit that you should ask him to complete his answer.
—Order! A Minister can answer a question in the way in which he sees fit.
—I am pointing out that it is a legal act to include the Liberal Party No case by request in the League of Rights material. Whilst it may be a legal right I point out the inconsistency--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is now clearly misleading the Senate. He has told us that he has no knowledge of how this came about. He has no knowledge whether this occurred at anybody's request. The fact is that there is a great deal of publicly available information on the referendums, including the Liberal Party's publications. The Minister is not only debating the questions but also he is misleading the Senate within the terms of his own answer and he should be called to order.
—Order! I think the Minister has been in order. However, I point out that his answer is becoming very long.

—It has been interrupted a fair bit, Mr President. I conclude on this point: we have another sitting day tomorrow and I invite Senator Chaney and the rest of the Liberals from Western Australia to investigate the matter. If they come into this chamber and repudiate the League of Rights and say they are not involved with it in the campaign, so be it. It will be on the public record. But we know that there is very little on the other side-they rarely repudiate their own. I am just waiting for the National Party of Queensland to come in here and ask some of the Liberals questions on this matter. Quite clearly they have attempted to repudiate the League of Rights. It is another example of the Opposition--
—What did Peter Baume say in that debate you are talking about?
—I am asked what Senator Peter Baume said. I go by what people do, not by what they say.

—I again raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is again debating the question. He is ignoring the fact that Senator Austin Lewis spoke on behalf of the Opposition in the same debate as Senator Boswell. Again, I ask you, Mr President, to call the Minister to order.

—On the point of order: for someone to interject, to get a response to the interjection and then to complain that the response is out of order is chutzpah of the highest order I have ever seen in the history of the Australian Parliament.
—Order! There is no point of order. I ask Opposition senators to cease interjecting and I ask Senator Ray to answer through the Chair.

—I conclude on this note: I was asked a supplementary question, if we can call it that, by those opposite, `What about Senator Peter Baume's speech?' It was a marvellous speech, but in the end-the same applies in the immigration debate-it is what one does that counts; it is not the honey coloured words one puts on it. If Opposition senators wish to ally themselves with the League of Rights for letterboxing purposes, they should not come in with high principled, waffly speeches in this place.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of the seminar conducted by Dr Ted Steele of the Department of Biology at Wollongong University on Tuesday, 30 August, at the Australian National University on the subject of the findings of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam? Is the Minister also aware that the conclusions of that seminar were that the current weight of evidence, including that which has emerged since the Evatt Royal Commission, leads inevitably to the conclusion that it has become more and more obvious that chronic pesticide exposure can lead to cancer as well as having other adverse effects? In view of this, in view of the very substantial scientific evidence which has emerged since the Evatt Royal Commission, and in view of the mishandling of information by the Commission, will the Government reconsider its attitude to the findings of the Commission and give veterans and their families the benefit of the doubt if they have ill health profiles consistent with the documented effects of exposure to agent orange?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that Dr Steele's views were based on various papers all but two of which were known and examined during the Evatt Royal Commission or as part of the Government's consideration of the agent orange issue.
—Just table the answer.

—Some honourable senators will be interested in the response. Obviously Senator Stone is not interested in veterans, but that does not surprise me. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs is obtaining a copy of the two remaining papers for examination. If Dr Steele wishes to submit new material to the Minister it will be examined. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs on 19 May 1988, when making public the Government's response to Mr Justice Evatt's report and Mr Hogg's assessment of it, indicated that the repatriation system would continue to provide for each veteran's case to be considered on its merits taking into account known medical and other evidence. I remind the Senate that under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, and as the Minister said in his May statement:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Repatriation Commission is required to determine that an incapacity or death (claimed as related to the veteran's operational service) is war-caused unless the Commission is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that there is no sufficient ground for making that determination.
Finally, the Government, through the Department of Veterans' Affairs, is continuing to monitor health trends within the Vietnam veteran community and relevant research both in Australia and overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Senator Reynolds in answering the question referred to the fact that some of the known references were cited by the Evatt Royal Commission. Is the Minister able to acknowledge that one such reference became the subject of a discussion after the Evatt Royal Commission in that the two authors appealed and objected to the Governor-General and the Prime Minister, saying in fact that the contents of their paper had been misrepresented and distorted; that they claimed compensation of $30,000; and that the Minister promised to offer some explanation of the Cabinet's position in relation to that claim?
—No, I am not prepared to acknowledge that. I will take that part of the question on notice and get an answer for the honourable senator by tomorrow.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. The Minister is actively negotiating the development of a forest accord to ensure that issues relating to forests will find common ground and that forest policies are based on commonsense. One of the aspects of the forest accord is the establishment of new tree plantations to improve productivity and to reduce the demands on native forest resources. Given the time implications of setting up plantations, can the Minister outline the initiatives he has set in place to ensure that sufficient incentive is there to enable the development of these plantations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Devlin for the question.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an important question about the future of a major industry in Australia, and I would have thought that Opposition senators would have appreciated the interest that Senator Devlin as a Tasmanian has shown in this matter. The realisation of a forest accord is something, I think, that is supported by all the parties that seek to influence forest policy in Australia. That is from the point of view of the unions concerned, from the point of view of the industry, from the point of view of those who work in the forests and from the point of view of conservationists who seek to preserve or protect part of Australia's native forests. All organisations have affirmed that they want to see an accord reached. Shortly the Government will commence the procedures to do so. All of the State governments and the Northern Territory Government, at the national forest Ministers meeting in Fremantle last month, supported the Commonwealth Government's proposition that a forest accord be undertaken.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the essential features of an accord would be to expand the resource base so that we do not continue to have arguments over whether a stretch of native forest should be conserved or whether it should be logged. The prime objective in expanding the resource base is to encourage investment in plantations by private industry and to sponsor that investment so that, for pulp and paper manufacture for woodchips, hopefully later for saw logs, one can obtain the needs of a major industry in Australia from plantation work rather than rely on native forests.

Senator Devlin asked me what we are doing about it. I point out that the national afforestation program is the provision within my portfolio under which we are proceeding to stimulate plantation investment. The program was established by the Government in 1987. It provides $15m over three years to stimulate a sustained increase in the level of investment by the States and private industry in hardwood plantations and in the rehabilitation of degraded land caused through afforestation. To date, projects have been approved which will double the rate of hardwood plantations established in Australia prior to the national afforestation program (NAP), creating over 10,000 hectares of plantations. Funding will also be allocated for research and to forest 7,000 hectares of land rehabilitation for land degradation control purposes.

The Treasurer, in his Budget statement, announced an allocation of $5.95m for this financial year to fund new and ongoing projects under the NAP scheme. This represents an increase of more than 200 per cent on the 1987-88 funding. That is a positive initiative by the Commonwealth Government which I believe will be a centrepiece of the accord when it is concluded. We have traditionally had a big forest products industry in Australia. We can tear a leaf out of the book of some other countries, which have taken Australian hardwood-eucalyptus globulus is the best example; Tasmanian blue gum-and put it in to plantations. Brazil is one country which has done that and which now stands to achieve a lead over Australia in hardwood production. The way forward for this industry in Australia is to move into plantations and do the same. Those companies that rely on forests should show initiative and develop those plantations, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories had any discussions with the Prime Minister about the contents of an alleged car telephone conversation between the Minister and the Treasurer?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. If the subject matter of the question is, as it appears to be, about the content of car phone conversations relating to the relationship between the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, it is manifestly quite out of the ambit of the Minister's area of ministerial responsibility and, as such, it is quite beyond his competence to answer, for the reasons that you articulated yesterday, Mr President, in ruling on the same point of order.
—Order! I will listen to Senator Puplick's question.

—Thank you, Mr President; I appreciate your courtesy. If so, I ask whether the Prime Minister sought any assurance from the Minister that the Treasurer did not use insulting and derogatory terms about the Prime Minister-for instance, inquiring whether the Treasurer described him as `envious'; I omit the other qualifying adjective and scatological noun. Was the Minister able to give the Prime Minister the assurances that he sought?

—Order! I have listened carefully to the question. Yesterday I pointed out that my predecessors have consistently ruled that the question must relate to matters within a Minister's area of responsibility. I asked Senator Richardson whether there were any areas within his responsibility in the question, and he gave an answer. I would think that this question today is therefore out of order.

—Mr President, before you rule on that matter-and I note that you say you `think' it is out of order, not that it is out of order-can I simply address the point of order which you seem to be raising from the chair in response to the point of order which was raised earlier by Senator Evans. Quite clearly, this potentially goes to the question of a Minister's place in the Cabinet.
—Ha!

—It is all very well for Senator Evans to say, `Ha!'. The situation is that some of the rather extreme statements of his predecessor are on the public record. I have little doubt that Senator Evans will be telling us in time that that is a matter of considerable importance to his portfolio responsibilities. This goes to the wider question of the whole operation of government and relationships between Ministers. It could be the grounds for the dismissal of a Minister. To suggest that this is not a matter of public interest, that this is not a matter relating to public affairs, is in my view to take an absurd and narrow view of what are public affairs. I ask you, Mr President, therefore, not to rule this question out of order. It seems to me to be quite clearly a matter of public significance which goes to the operation of ministerial government in this country.

—On the point of order, Mr President: in the time that Senator Chaney has been Leader of the Opposition he has probably taken upwards of a thousand points of order. At least a hundred have been in relation to whether something is in a Minister's portfolio. When Government senators ask questions about Mr John Elliott or the Liberal Party health policy, which one may describe as public affairs, Senator Chaney is the first one to jump to his feet and have them ruled out of order. By tomorrow I will have the text of all of those points of order so that I can quote them to Senator Chaney. I can recall several times when he tried to limit the debate by saying that the Minister could only answer something for which he was responsible. He quite often raises as a point of order the fact that we are not responsible-thank goodness!-for Liberal Party policy or John Elliott. It is along those lines, Mr President, that I concur with your ruling and believe that you should persist with it.

—On the point of order, Mr President: as to the matter that Senator Ray has just raised, it has nothing to do with the ministerial responsibilities of the Prime Minister and members of his Cabinet. He is talking about Liberal Party policy matters, and the Federal President of the Liberal Party is not relevant to these matters. I take you back, Mr President, to what you said a few moments ago. Yesterday you put to Senator Richardson the same sort of ruling as that which you were about to make today; I hope that you have not yet quite made it. You then invited Senator Richardson to answer the question if he wished. The truth is that Senator Richardson answered the question. He may not have answered it fully, but he certainly partially answered it. I put it to you that by making a partial answer, Senator Richardson acknowledged that it was within his portfolio and that you should again put to him today that if he wishes to answer, it is his right to so answer.

—Order! It will not come as any surprise to honourable senators to know that this morning I re-read the question and the answer that Senator Richardson gave yesterday. I am now of the opinion that this question is exactly the same sort of question that was asked yesterday. I do not believe that it is in his area of responsibility, and I am ruling it out of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the Minister provide the Senate with any information on the extent to which the capital gains tax has improved the progressivity of the Australian tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the information for the 1986-87 income year-that is, the first year for which capital gains tax was applicable. It shows that $43m, in round figures, was collected from individuals. Capital gains tax was paid by only 23,000 individuals out of a total of 7.2 million taxpayers, so about 0.3 per cent of taxpayers were subject to capital gains tax. It also shows that the great bulk of capital gains tax is paid by persons with high incomes. That is demonstrated by the fact that of the $43m collected, 65 1/2 per cent was collected from persons with taxable incomes in excess of $50,000. In addition, $46m in capital gains tax was collected from the corporate sector. That demonstrates very clearly that the incidence of capital gains tax is very heavily concentrated at the top end of the income scale. From memory, 65 per cent of capital gains tax was paid by people with incomes above $50,000. If I remember correctly, income tax paid by people with incomes above that figure represented only about 10 per cent of the total amount collected. So the tax is obviously much more heavily concentrated-as anybody who knows anything about it would expect-on high income earners.

ANSWER.PARA: The only other point I make is that the actual tax collected from the capital gains tax is no more than the tip of the iceberg. The more important role of the capital gains tax, which probably can never be quantified with any precision, is that it puts a net under the income tax system. For years, when John Howard was presiding over the disintegration and decay of the Australian taxation system, there was a succession of tax avoidance and evasion schemes. At the bottom of most of those tax avoidance and evasion schemes was the conversion-in some cases fraudulent conversion; and they are being caught up with now-of the amounts that ought to have been taxed as income into a capital gain which was at that stage not taxable. That, of course, is no longer the case. I trust that some time after the Liberal Party has dumped its present leader, and before the next election, it will come to see the error of its ways and drop that silly undertaking it gave at the last election to invite the rorting and decay of the Australian taxation system by abolishing the capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications and follows that which was asked by Senator Puplick and ruled out of order. Has the Minister been asked to inquire or has he initiated inquiries on his own initiative into the reports of the taping of an alleged telephone call between the Treasurer and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories? If so have these investigations confirmed the existence of such a tape recording? Has the Minister or any other Minister been acquainted with the details of the alleged conversation? Is any further action being taken or is any further action planned with respect to this matter?
—I have not been asked to initiate an inquiry nor have I done so. I have no knowledge of the alleged content of any such conversation. What was the last question?
—Have these investigations confirmed the existence of such a tape recording? Does the Minister have any details and is there any action planned?
—Not applicable and no.
—Mr President I ask the Minister a supplementary question. In that case is he aware of any action being taken by Telecom Australia or by any other authority with respect to these allegations?

—I am sure that if one of the parties to an alleged conversation took the view that his privacy had been invaded he would take the appropriate steps and seek an investigation from Telecom Australia. If that has not happened there is no doubt that it is because nobody feels that there is any substance to the allegations that have been made.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY SUPERANNUATION SCHEME: MR ROBERT WOOD

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister received legal advice in relation to Mr Robert Wood's request for payment under the parliamentary superannuation scheme? If so, what was that advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said three days ago or it may have been last week-I do not remember for certain-that I had asked my Department to check out the legal position regarding never-was-Senator Wood's application to have refunded to him the contributions to the parliamentary superannuation retirement scheme that he alleged he had made. It is rather lengthy and I will not quote the whole lot. I will quote what I believe are the most relevant sections. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: You ask-
`you' being the Finance officer who initiated the inquiry from Attorney-General's-
whether the superannuation contributions credited to Mr Wood are legally refundable to him or whether the moneys, at law, are considered to be available to the Commonwealth.
The short answer is that the moneys are not refundable to Mr Wood.

The amounts paid to Mr Wood by way of parliamentary and electoral allowance were not, in the light of the High Court's decision, properly payable to him. That is, because Mr Wood was never a properly elected Senator, the appropriation in s. 7 (13) of the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973 that applies, among other things, to parliamentary allowances, never authorised the payments made to Mr Wood. Those amounts would be recoverable pursuant to the principle stated in Auckland Harbour Board v. The King (1924) AC--
What does the acronym AC mean? Anyway it continues:
I am not sure what that means actually. The letter goes on:

I understand however that the moneys deducted as contributions under the Superannuation Act from the moneys paid to Mr Wood as parliamentary allowances in fact have always remained in Consolidated Revenue. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President I ask a supplementary question. Can I understand from that answer that Mr Wood would receive none of his own contributions that he had paid into the fund itself? If that is a fact what is the position in regard to Mr Wood when he was serving in this Parliament and voting in the Parliament? Would not the Minister feel that it would be unfair for Mr Wood not to receive back the contributions that he had paid in?

—The thrust of this advice is that in fact no contributions were paid into any fund. The notional contribution, if you like, remained in Consolidated Revenue. The question, which goes beyond my area of responsibility but is implicit in the supplementary question asked, is whether any votes of the Senate taken during that period between September and May, I think it was, in which never-was-Senator Wood may have been recorded as voting, were affected in the legal sense. I do not know but so far as I am aware there was no vote of the Senate at that time, in which never-was-Senator Wood had his name recorded, which was so close that the subtraction of one vote from one side would have made any difference.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation at the South Australian Institute of Technology is not in that category. Indeed, SAIT has another campus which is many kilometres away. I must say that I find Senator Teague's apparent moral outrage arising from his misinterpretation of Government policy rather curious to say the least in view of the fact that it was the Fraser Government, of which he was a back bench supporter, which in 1981 issued a hit list of forced amalgamations. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I tell the Minister that I do not project moral outrage but policy opposition. For the information of the Minister, I quote from the statement-though not from the area concerning general mergers. On page 29 the White Paper states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the government remains committed to the view that institutions sharing common or adjacent sites should be combined under a single management structure and have a single educational profile. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That is a statement. There is no supplementary question.
—The question, Mr President, is this: Does the backing off that the Minister has indicated in his answer hold in the light of the explicit words that are in the policy?
—I am pleased if Senator Teague is not trying to be sanctimonious. It will be a pleasant change.

The Registrar of Plant Variety Rights has invited comment on possible options for amendments in the Plant Varieties Journal published, I think, in June of this year, volume 1, No. 2.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of what Professor Lazenby has said. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. Has the Minister seen the article in today's Age by Xavier Connor, QC, on the proposed extension of section 116 of the Constitution in next Saturday's referendum? Mr Connor says about the proposed change:

QUESTION.PARA: On the one hand, it prevents state promotion of any religion. On the other hand, it prevents any interference with the free exercise of religion.
Does the Minister share Mr Connor's disappointment with the adoption by the Australian Bishops Conference of the legal opinion prepared by Mr David Bennett, QC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article by Xavier Connor in today's Age headed `Bishops' doubts are groundless'. Xavier Connor, as members of the Senate will know, is a former Federal Court judge and a former President of the Australian Law Reform Commission and I think is very highly regarded on both sides of politics. He said in the article:

ANSWER.PARA: The view of the bishops is not based on Catholic theology or doctrine but on a seriously flawed view of Australian constitutional law. The vice of the bishops' presentation is that it completely and unfairly ignores a strong case for voting Yes which is entirely consistent with the teaching of the Catholic Church.

I find myself in total agreement with the comments of Xavier Connor. The Catholic bishops, unfortunately in my view, have made their statement based on a very bad reading of the law. It is also very defective from a philosophical point of view. The bishops seem to have been advised that the proposal to be put to the people on 3 September by way of an extension of a very important freedom which the framers of our Constitution in the late nineteenth century thought was so important that it ought to be embodied and entrenched in the Constitution rather--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Should the Minister be canvassing this issue when in debate in this place he said he was unable to give a categorical assurance on this issue? This is an absurd thing. The Minister is now asserting a position which is quite contrary to the view he asserted in earlier debate and he should be told to desist from that.
—There is no point of order. I have no power as to how a Minister shall answer a question.
—Whether honestly or not.
—I ask the honourable senator to withdraw that.
—I said `honestly or not'.
—Order! I call Senator Tate.

—I will ignore that snide comment. Nothing that I have said so far is contrary to anything I have said previously. What I was in the middle of saying was that the bishops' opinion seems to be based on the legal advice that the proposal to be put to the people on 3 September is identical to what is contained in the United States Constitution, and that is not the case.
—It is not the contention.

—I agree it is not the case; it is not identical. Indeed, the bishops speak of experience in the United States of America, where there is a constitutionally enshrined prohibition against the establishment of any religion. Those words do not appear in the United States Constitution. Therefore, as I say, it is quite clear that the bishops have received very bad advice in that regard. I believe that colours and taints the rest of their opinion.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also important to point out that the Labor Party has been a tremendous supporter of the non-government school system since the time of Mr Whitlam as Prime Minister and Mr Kim Beazley Sr as Minister for Education. The very divisive debate on state aid to schools and the sectarian bitterness were put to an end by the action of that Government. That has been reinforced by the history of the last five years. The Hawke Government has created a situation whereby-I see this as I go around Australia, and certainly Tasmania, opening extensions to non-government schools-the practical choice available to parents has been increased immeasurably. It is implausible to think that there is some sort of hidden agenda whereby the introduction of this constitutional proposal is designed to do away with the funding of non-government schools by governments.

Indeed, any fair reading of the DOGS case reveals that that case turned on the point that the provision of moneys for non-government schools in no way establishes any religion as a state church with all the titles and privileges that attach to that status. The fact is that the provision of such moneys can never establish any religion under our Constitution and therefore such funding would not be prohibited by the Constitution.

I want to deal with the final point that Xavier Connor made; that is, that our proposal is entirely consistent with the teaching of the Catholic Church. It is important to point out that the Catholic Church in its own fundamental documents or constitution-the documents of Vatican II-makes it very clear that this question of religious freedom and liberty is so important that it ought to be entrenched in constitutions and not left to the normal political processes where only the political muscle of majorities is relied upon. That is not a sufficient safeguard; the framers never thought it was a sufficient safeguard. The extension of the freedoms and rights that they entrenched in our Constitution so as to bind the States and Territories is, I think, a very important one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Whilst the broadcasting system in the chamber has improved considerably in recent days, I am aware that there is now some difficulty with the clocks. However, the clock that timed Question Time is correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During Question Time today Senator Ray replied to a question from me on whether the Government will take action on my private members's Bill, on behalf of the Opposition, to make informal all ticks and crosses votes at next Saturday's referendum. In his reply Senator Ray said that had the Opposition not rejected Government proposals earlier this year then the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act would have been amended to prohibit ticks and crosses as formal votes. There were other problems and that is why I advised the Opposition to reject the relevant Government amendments. The Australian Democrats took the same view as we did.

SPEECH.PARA: That amendment earlier this year was technically flawed. Whilst it may have dealt with the ticks and crosses issue, it would not have dealt with the other concerns relating to whether particular methods of casting votes were formal or informal. It was those other concerns which were uppermost in the minds of all parties. It was for these reasons that the Opposition rejected the Government's earlier proposals; the concerns were not adequately dealt with. Senator Ray knows that full well. In other words, Senator Ray has completely misrepresented me on this matter. May I also say that in his response he misrepresented my colleagues in the other place, Mr Reith and Mr Sharp. The Government quite obviously is not prepared to take the necessary action that lies within its right to remove what otherwise will be a major bias in favour of the yes vote at the referendum on Saturday.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will be very brief, Mr President I invite honourable senators opposite and honourable senators on this side to read the House of Representatives Hansard of 17 March and 3 June. I invite them to find there a proper explanation as to what the technical difficulties were that caused the Opposition to reject that clause of the Bill on 3 June. In private conversations with Senator Short, in the public record, and everywhere else, we have never had a satisfactory explanation. The only thing the Opposition fails to understand is the use of word `qualification'. The Opposition misinterpreted that and then went off on a wild goose chase that led it to reject that clause at the time.

—by leave-I thank Senator Ray for those remarks, but if he reads the Hansard of 3 June he will find an explanation as to why certainly the Opposition, and I think the Democrats, although I cannot speak for them, rejected this amendment and the reasons for it. I also refer Senator Ray to private conversations we had before this Bill was debated in the Senate. I said to Senator Ray that our concern was with the words `or without words of qualification' in the amendment. Senator Ray did offer to seek a view on that and that was the last I heard of it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Bishop proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The serious threat to rights and liberties posed by the Hawke government's fourth referendum proposal, including the traditional notion of freedom of religion in Australia and in particular the widely supported principle of state aid to independent schools.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that this matter of public importance follows the last question asked in Question Time when Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice, attempted to give the Catholic bishops both a theology lesson and legal instruction, which perhaps I will deal with a little later in this address. Several things need to be drawn to the attention of the electorate as a whole, despite the very best attempts of the Government to stop debate on this question being raised. The first point I raise is: why on earth do we have the questions of trial by jury, freedom of religion, and fair and just terms for property rights bound up in the one question?

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of my traversing Australia to try to bring to the attention of people the seriousness of this question, the Australian Labor Party, unable to find a parliamentary member of its team to debate the question in Armidale, sent a legal consultant to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to debate it in his place. When I asked him that question, he replied, `Oh well, otherwise there would have been six questions on the ballot paper and the Australian people could not cope with that'. That degree of cynicism being displayed in this whole debate is at the essence of why we have three important issues rolled up in one. I suggest that the real answer is that the Government hoped that the question of freedom of religion would slip through without it being properly addressed and debated.

Immediately one thinks of the attitude of trying to slip through a very subtle and cynical amendment to the Constitution one asks oneself a few questions. Why? What is the hurry? What is the rush? Where is the cry from the electorate, from the people? This is a Government driven referendum. There has been no cry from the people for any changes to be made to our Constitution. So the question we are really debating is whether we find the Government driven referendums in the national interest-not in the Government's interest, not in the Opposition's interest but in the national interest.

When I looked at the question of the so-called extension of the freedom of religion I remembered well the Council for the Defence of Government Schools (DOGS) case, the bitterness and the divisive debate that raged for over a decade while that case was drawn out, from 1973 with, finally, a judgment being given in 1981. I remembered the debate. I remembered that Lionel Murphy accepted the plaintiff's case.

Let us recant the plaintiff's case. Firstly, the plaintiff said that the decision of the Federal Government to grant state aid to independent, church based schools was an infringement of the existing section 116 of the Constitution. The argument went this way: if one gives a grant of money to a school to build an assembly hall, it is quite likely that the school will have a religious service inside that hall and that, the plaintiff said, amounted to the establishment of religion.
