Secondly, it was said that if one gives recurrent funding, annual budget funding, to pay teachers and to keep the school running it is quite likely that in the course of that year there will be religious instruction, and that, the plaintiff said, amounted to the establishment of religion.

That argument had been run quite successfully in the United States, where the wording of the First Amendment is different from our section 116. Mr Justice Lionel Murphy-consistent, at least, because he had opposed it when he was Attorney-General in the Whitlam Government-accepted fully the arguments as proffered by the plaintiffs. It is well to remember that of the 19 plaintiffs-finally the matter was brought by the Attorney-General of Victoria-who wished their names to be recorded, two were Bill Hartley and John Halfpenny. It is important to remember that when one asks oneself the question: if one really wanted to get rid of state aid, how would one go about it? One certainly would not expect any government to have the political will to abolish state aid because, by 1990, 30 per cent of all school children will be in the independent system. So any government that tried that little caper would be out on its pink ear.

If one were dedicated to getting rid of state aid to independent schools, as is Mr Nilsen of the Defence of Government Schools organisation-he is loudly proclaiming it from the rooftops-one would go another way. One would look at the arguments in the DOGS case and draft an amendment to the Constitution which answered all those criticisms in the DOGS case. One would get the Constitution amended, run a new challenge to the new section 116 and get the High Court to declare that governments may not give aid. Governments are then off the hook.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only if you are fair dinkum.

—That interjection is fair. One would bring that point out and debate it fairly. But that is not the way the Government has chosen to run these referendums. We have had matters of public importance in this place pointing out the deception, the duplicity and the dirty tricks department, of which the ticks and crosses, with ticks being okay and crosses being informal, is just one example. The importance of these debates is to bring the issues to the attention of the Australian people, who are usually sensible and usually understand what is meant once the debate starts to be put fully before them. They reject the grab of the Government to do something which they do not wish.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what the judges said in answer to the plaintiffs' case about why the granting of state aid was held not to be the establishment of religion. Mr Justice Sir Garfield Barwick, the then Chief Justice, Justice Gibbs, a subsequent Chief Justice, and Mr Justice Sir Anthony Mason, the current Chief Justice, were all majority judges in that decision. Each one of them stressed the importance of the words `make any law for'. Our Constitution currently reads that the Commonwealth shall not make any law for the establishing of any religion. Mr Justice Sir Anthony Mason said, in his judgment, at page 116, that the main impediment to the success of the plaintiffs' case were the words `make any law for' establishing any religion. Those are the very words that the proposed amendment will take out of the Constitution. That is why the Catholic bishops have come out in their statement and said:

On the issue of freedom of religion the bishops have obtained specialist advice from a variety of experts. In the light of that advice the Bishops place on record their concern that a (yes) vote on this question could in fact end up seriously restricting freedom of religion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what Senator Tate said.
—Indeed. It is not what Senator Tate said. They further said:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal is vague, its meaning uncertain and its outcome unpredictable. There is no widespread discontent among ordinary Australians with the present religious freedoms that exist. This proposal however raises serious concerns for the future and deserves to be treated warily.
The Dean of the Archdiocese of Sydney said:

Any change to the Constitution on the question of freedom of religion may lead to new controversial litigation on the future of previously determined questions such as State aid to independent schools, religious instruction in State schools, prayer at public occasions and a religious department in the ABC.
Rabbi Apple, of the Great Synagogue, has said:

There has not been any public pressure for a change to the existing law, nor does religious freedom appear to be under threat in Australia. But even if the purpose of the proposed amendment is simply to tidy up the present law, so many new loopholes may have been created by the proposed new wording that we might end up with religious freedom curtailed, not extended.

Are they all wrong-the Catholic bishops, the Anglican Church and the Jewish Synagogue-because they disagree with the Government's proposal? When we had a guillotined debate in this place, during which we could not fully explore the ramifications of the legislation, at a quarter to three in the morning I asked the Minister, Senator Tate: `Why is it that in this our bicentennial year you would want to reopen this highly contentious and divisive issue and bring upon the Australian people the curse of divisiveness?' The Minister had no answer-and it was not simply because it was 2.45 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. Of course I answered. I answered for hour after hour.
—There were no more hours left; we finished at 3.40 a.m.

SPEECH.PARA: We then come to the question of people trying simply to extend this to the States. At present, should the High Court decide to overrule itself in the DOGS case-which it may do now and has shown its willingness to do recently with Cole and Whitfield and its decision on section 92, where it totally overturned its meaning of the words `absolutely free' and has construed the word `absolutely' to mean perhaps `relatively'-should it choose to overturn its own decision, it would be important to note that it could not affect state aid as made by State governments, because at present the prohibition does not affect States and Territories. So at the very least, by inserting the words `States and Territories' the Government is putting at risk, from a future High Court that may determine that it wishes to override itself, the question of state aid, which could not be done in the present way.

That brings me to the `opinion' given by Sir Maurice Byers in the form of a letter to the Attorney-General in the last days. In that letter, addressed to `My Dear Attorney-General' and signed `Yours sincerely, M. Byers', Sir Maurice Byers has made certain statements of certainty as to what the High Court may or may not do in the future. It is very dangerous for a barrister, eminent QC or otherwise, to make statements declaring that his or her opinion is absolutely correct and then to predict with the same degree of certainty what the High Court will or will not do. In that letter, which was released by the Attorney-General as an opinion, Sir Maurice said:

It is absurd to imagine that the (High) Court would leave the certainties of its interpretation of section 116 for the chaos the United States Courts have brought to the different language and specific social history of the First Amendment.

It is important to realise that the distinction between the meaning of the words `establishment' or `establishing any religion' in Australia and in the United States. The High Court has used the words `make any law for' to bring about a narrow interpretation of the meaning of the word `establish'. The United States Supreme Court, on the other hand, has chosen to give a very broad interpretation of the meaning of the word `establishment', so that it is now against the law, as defined by the Supreme Court as distinct from the legislators, for a volunteer fire brigade to erect a cross in a public place at Easter. On the other hand, when a public body wanted to erect a nativity scene in a public place at Christmas, and the matter ended up in the courts for five years, a split decision finally established that it could have a nativity scene in a public place at Christmas because it was traditional rather than religious. Do we want that sort of insane litigation before our courts? I certainly would think not. The danger in opening up this question is that we will suffer here the broadly based and broad definition of the word `establishment'.

Of course, the other thing that is most interesting in looking at Sir Maurice's statement that he and his opinion are absolutely correct and that the High Court would never change its mind, is that lawyers are not always correct. Indeed, two cases which came before Sir Maurice Byers as Solicitor-General come readily to mind, in which the courts found him not to be correct. Those cases are the Collector of Customs v. Brian Lawlor Automotives Pty Ltd, reported in the 1979 Federal Law Reports, and Clunies-Ross v. The Commonwealth, reported at page 193 of Commonwealth Law Reports, No. 155. In both cases Sir Maurice Byers put forward a good and reasoned argument. He lost. His arguments were found to be wrong. Lawyers can only deal in probabilities, not in absolutes. So in choosing to say that his opinion is absolutely correct Sir Maurice has passed from the legal arena to the political arena. Perhaps in so doing he ought to take one or two lessons from the Minister and from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). His problem in that missive to the Attorney-General is that he seems confused as to whether he is speaking as Chairman of the Constitutional Commission, counsel in the original DOGS case, a so-called independent counsel or, indeed, a clairvoyant predicting just what future high courts may or may not say.

Sir Maurice has built his reputation on sound ability. It is a pity to see this distinguished lawyer, who would normally cringe at the uncritical political hype of being described as Australia's leading constitutional lawyer, become Sir Maurice Biased and compromised.

In that opinion Sir Maurice chose to criticise an opinion by Mr David Bennett, QC. Mr David Bennett has had the opportunity of seeing Sir Maurice Byers's opinion and he has written a supplementary opinion, which I seek leave to table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In this supplementary opinion Mr Bennett answers, paragraph by paragraph, each so-called disagreement that Sir Maurice Byers has with his own opinion, which was originally given some weeks ago. As I said, Sir Maurice has now entered the political arena. He has said that his view that the High Court would never change its mind is absolutely right. The Minister has said that he cannot give an untempered and absolute guarantee that the case will not be upset. Yesterday the Prime Minister said that he could not give a cast iron guarantee that a Yes vote in next Saturday's referendum would not reopen the divisive question of state aid to non-government schools, and that the division of government between Parliament and Executive and judiciary meant that it was impossible for any figure outside the High Court to say what the High Court would do.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that Sir Maurice is not yet familiar with his new role of political advocate. Perhaps he would do well to read what Mr Ray Nilsen has had to say. He is the man who initiated the original DOGS proceedings and is now saying that he will bring another action and support the Yes case.

I put it to the Minister and to the Australian people that the test is whether it is beyond a reasonable doubt that these referendums are in the national interest-not the Government's interest; not the Opposition's interest; but in the national interest. Once the propositions are passed, it passes from the arena of the Parliament and parliamentarians and it moves to the High Court. I have spoken to many people who have said, `That fellow Lionel Bowen really is a nice chap and he and that nice Michael Tate would not do a thing like that to us. They have said they would not'. The answer to that is that it does not matter what the Government says. Once these propositions go through it is too late. It is like hanging; there is no second choice.

So I ask the Government and the Australian people to use the criminal standard-that is, whether it is beyond a reasonable doubt that these referendums are in the national good. We should not use the balance of probabilities and say, `On the balance of probabilities it might be okay because if we do not like it we can lobby our politicians, be rude to them, petition them, chuck them out, and we can change it'. But the only way we can change an amendment to the Constitution is to have another amendment, and that can only come from executive government with the support of the Parliament. We cannot go lobbying a High Court judge and we certainly cannot sack him or her.

I make one final plea to the Australian people. The Constitution is the most precious thing we have. It is something which needs good and strong debate-not guillotined-and we need to know beyond a reasonable doubt that it is in the national good; because a government can always ask again, but we cannot change it. When in doubt, vote No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop has brought into the chamber a matter of public importance which alleges that there is a serious threat to the rights and liberties of the nation in the proposal to be put next Saturday, 3 September, that the Australian people give their assent to securing three very important rights and liberties which those who framed our Constitution thought were very important back in the late nineteenth century. We are asking that those rights and liberties be extended beyond their effective application against the Commonwealth so as to bind the States and Territories. Those three very important rights are the right to trial by jury, the right to have fair compensation for property when it is acquired by the Government and, finally, the right embodied in the proposal that State and Territory parliaments and governments be bound, as is the Commonwealth Parliament at the moment, not to establish any religion, not to prevent the free exercise of religion, not to impose any religious observance and not to require those accepting public office to take any religious test.

SPEECH.PARA: These are all crucial parts of the good working democracy that we have in Australia, but they need to be secured, as I say, against the action of State and Territory governments in the future. It is quite right that at the moment we live in a reasonably calm and reasonably tolerant era in Australia's history, although that has not always been so. When one has the opportunity and the obligations, as we do as citizens, to engage in modifying our Constitution, we must keep in mind that we are talking about the fundamental document which creates the framework within which we will be governed and by which we govern ourselves as a free people not only for the next few decades but well into the next century. It is in that context that it is an act of great responsibility for us to ensure that future generations of Australians enjoy as a constitutionally guaranteed right those sorts of freedoms and rights and liberties which we presently generally enjoy through the political process. That is really what constitutional entrenchment of rights and liberties is all about.

Far from it being the case that this proposal poses a serious threat to rights and liberties, in fact, as I say, it secures rights and liberties for the Australian people into the future against actions-unpredictable and unpredicted at the moment-which could be undertaken by any government. In fact, we should recall the words of Sir Anthony Mason at a recent conference when he said that the common law is not the invincible safeguard of our rights that it was once thought to be. In fact it is a very weak reed indeed when it is up against the actions of a State parliament, for example, which of course with the majority support of those in its chambers-or in its single chamber, as it is in Queensland-can undertake action and impose matters on the people quite without any regard whatsoever to the so-called common law rights which the people may think they are entitled to.

It is with that background that we have brought forward this proposal. I will come to the religious liberty question more particularly in that regard in a moment. We know that the Opposition has been going around the country during the winter recess deliberately stirring up fears and misgivings and involving itself in scaremongering of the highest degree in relation to these matters. We know that when Mr Reith was in South Australia at a town hall meeting only a week or so ago he said, when asked by an innocent member of the audience whether the passage of this proposal would involve the elimination of Christmas and Easter, `I do not know and I do not care to find out'. Mr Reith was quite prepared to leave the people there in a state of ignorance because that is the state that best serves the Opposition's ends-to create fear, misgivings and uncertainly in the electorate so that with doubts aroused they may vote no. I do not believe that the Australian people will be taken in by the scaremongering campaign which has gone to such absurd lengths as to claim, for example, that prayers before Parliament starts might be in jeopardy as a result of this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —In America that is an administrative function.

—Senator Bishop does not even know United States law on that, so I do not think that I need to pay much attention to her thoughts. The framers of the Constitution in the late nineteenth century thought that the right to trial by jury, the right to have fair and just compensation if one's property is acquired, and the right to religious freedom were so important that they should be put beyond the reach of any particular parliament or government, but they did so only with respect to the Commonwealth. What these three proposals have in common-and a common thread has been sought by Senator Bishop-is that one is simply taking these three proposals and extending their application so that the State and Territory parliaments and governments are also bound to observe these very important freedoms.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer briefly to trial by jury. What difference does it make to a person facing the peril and jeopardy of more than two years' imprisonment that the alleged offence is a Federal, State or Territory offence? It makes no difference whatsoever to the fact that that person will be in severe jeopardy if he is found guilty, a conviction is secured and a sentence of more than two years' imprisonment is imposed. Therefore, we say in that situation, where such a peril is in prospect, an Australian should be able to assert as a right that trial by jury should be provided in the great tradition that has come down to us through the English legal tradition from Norman times. I believe that there is no real argument about that.

As to the acquisition of property, what difference does it make to an Australian whether the Government acquiring his or her property is the Commonwealth Government, a State government or a Territory government? It makes no difference whatsoever. In all those instances it is right and proper that fair compensation be constitutionally guaranteed. It should not be left to the mere whim of political chance as to whether one receives fair compensation. Indeed, I would have thought that Senator Bishop, with the New South Wales Coal Acquisition Act experience in mind, would not want to leave the fair compensation of the owners of those coal rights to the vagaries of political fortune but would have liked to see persons faced with the acquisition of their property by a government of whatever sphere-Federal or State-in a position where they could obtain compensation. In the same way, what difference does it make which Parliament or government attempts to establish any religion, to interfere with the free exercise of religion, to impose any religious observance or to require some religious test before the taking of public office? Whether it is a State, Territory or Commonwealth parliament or government, none should be involved in an activity which impinges on what is really a central part of a human being's integrity and personality, that is, the freedom to choose without external governmental pressures to adhere to a particular religion or, of course, to none. That is a very central part of human integrity and dignity. Our Constitution ought to provide for that particular right to be asserted against all governments.

The matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Bishop refers to our `traditional notion of freedom of religion'. Of course we have a traditional notion but we must realise in Australia that we are going through a fairly calm and reasonably tolerant period. However, I might modify that in a moment in relation to racial minorities. You would appreciate that point more than most on your side of politics, Mr Acting Deputy President. We live in a relatively tolerant era in Australia's history at the moment as far as minorities are concerned. However, I believe that we need to emphasise that our legal system, and in particular our common law tradition which we inherited from the United Kingdom, is quite unable to protect minorities against the majorities which can force their will to be embodied in law through the action of a parliament which they dominate. In fact, we know from the history of the dissenters and the Catholics in England that it is the case that the common law was unable to protect them. It was only very gradual political action which secured some rights and a sphere of freedom for them.

We are involved in the construction of a constitution which is to serve future generations, so we should listen to the warning bells which have been sounded in relation to this matter by the Supreme Court of South Australia, which only a few years ago made it very clear in the Grace Bible case that the common law is unable to withstand the action of a State parliament determined to infringe freedom of religion. Sir Anthony Mason, the present Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, has also said that the common law is not the invincible safeguard of our rights that it was once thought to be. I refer to the beating of the drums of racial intolerance which have been heard around this country over the past month, exacerbated by certain statements by certain members of the Opposition-though you, yourself, very honourably, are not to be included in that category, Mr Acting Deputy President. Anyone who understands how the embers of racism have been stirred, and can be stirred even further, in a way that puts minorities in real jeopardy and in real peril as we construct our society over the next several years and decades into the next century and into the next millennium will know that the sort of easy complacent assurance that was a feature of Australia until very recently, even until a month ago, that minorities would get a fair go in this country is now not so easily assured.

The fact is that minorities can be very quickly singled out by the great mass of the people coalescing into a majority and they can be put in real peril and jeopardy. I am suggesting that in relation to religious minorities that is not such an unreal prospect as we move into the next century. Where, as has been an unfortunate characteristic of the debates over the winter recess emanating from the Opposition benches in part, one has a combination of rousing of fears about a minority-a minority in a racial, ethnic and religious sense-one has a very explosive situation, which I believe can lead to the destruction of the sort of tolerant society which is too easily relied on in the Opposition's approach to this question.

I refer in particular to the way in which adherents to the Muslim faith have been singled out in many instances in the course of this debate. Senator Bishop-I am sorry that she has now left the chamber-has mercilessly singled out some examples in her traipsing around the Australian nation to put her point of view. I respect her in putting that point of view, but there are two examples on which she has constantly harped. One is female circumcision, which is not a question of Muslim belief or a tenet of that religion but is practised by some person with certain cultural or tribal origins who happen to be Muslims. But by no means do all Muslims practise female circumcision, and certainly not the major kind-I bow to you as a physician, Mr Acting Deputy President-which amounts to mutilation such as would offend against the ordinary laws, if one could ever prove it.

Senator Bishop also spoke of a case that was before the magistrates courts in Melbourne, where a person had bound his wife to a bed for three days, assaulted her and sexually abused her and apparently claimed in the magistrates court that this was all permitted by the Koran because he was merely disciplining his wife as permitted by that sacred book. That of course was rejected by the magistrate, and would be rejected by the High Court on any reading of section 116 as proposed and as is at present there. By their decisions in the Jehovah's Witnesses case and the Scientology case, the judges made it clear that the ordinary criminal laws which are important for the cohesion of society are not displaced by claims that one is putting into practice some religious imperative. Seizing on those examples and using them endlessly around the country is part of a very dangerous process whereby minorities in our society cannot feel as assured as they may have been even a matter of months ago that they will always enjoy the space, to use an Americanism that has crept into our language, allowed to them by the majority of their fellow citizens.

Regretfully, I believe that that complacency underlies much of what the Catholic bishops say. I shall not repeat endlessly the fact that the defence of government schools case turned on the point that, in order for the passage of money from a government to a religious body to offend against the Constitution, it is required that that funding create a situation where it can be said that that religious sect, church or denomination has been established-established in the sense of having all sorts of rights and privileges accrued to it with which we are familiar in relation to the Church of England in England. That situation is not brought about by the funding of non-government schools, church-based hospitals or other community organisations. For that reason that funding is not imperilled because it can never amount to an establishing of any religion. I do not want to go over all that again because it has been done to death.

I say in passing that it is important to do away with the conspiracy theory that somehow governments, obviously not wanting to undermine the funding of non-government schools, have been beguiled, misled or somehow seduced by Mr Halfpenny and Mr Hartley into putting this forward as a proposal to achieve by way of subterfuge what no government would contemplate doing openly in the political arena. That is absolutely ludicrous.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are still members of the Labor Party.

—Hartley is not a member of the Labor Party. He was expelled from the Labor Party a couple of conferences ago. That shows how much Opposition senators know. But that is not my point. The point is that this proposal was not conceived or drafted by Halfpenny and Hartley. It was drafted by the Constitutional Commission chaired by Sir Maurice Byers, who has been most unfairly spoken of as Sir Maurice Biased by Senator Bishop in the course of debate. Sir Maurice was counsel for the Commonwealth in the DOGS case and argued successfully for the funding of non-government schools by the Commonwealth. On the Commission he was assisted by two learned professors of law, Zines and Campbell, and by Gough Whitlam and Sir Rupert Hamer. It is quite implausible to put together a conspiracy theory which allows all those five people to be drawn into a scheme to insert into the Constitution the undermining of government funding of non-government schools or hospitals. It is absolutely ludicrous.

SPEECH.PARA: My great sadness in relation to the Catholic bishops' document is not so much at their getting the law wrong, which seems to be based on bad advice in that we are talking about provisions in the United States Constitution, but the fact that their document reads:
The long tradition of freedom of religion which our country has enjoyed is best protected through the democratic process in the Federal Parliament and each State and Territory Legislature.

The bishops do not really believe that; otherwise they would be asking for the repeal of section 116. They know that it is important to have a constitutional guarantee at the Federal level. They ought to be prepared to accept it at the State and Territory level, and not rely merely on the political muscle of the majority. They seem to have forgotten their history out of the ghettos and their minority position. They seem to be indifferent to the other adherents to minority religious groups who are at present in our country and who will be in the sort of jeopardy of which I spoke earlier.

It is not good enough to rely on the simple democratic process in talking about the guarantee of fundamental rights. The democratic process, which of course I fully support, obviously is able to be suborned and manipulated by majorities. That is the nature of it. The majority for the time being makes the law which bind people within the jurisdiction through their elected representatives. As was recognised by the Vatican Council, which produced the fundamental constitutional document of the Catholic Church in the present era, it is quite clear that religious liberty is so important that it ought to be secured and entrenched in the Constitution. The proposal that will be before the people on 3 September is to entrench a right, freedom, liberty which is crucial to our being a free and democratic people and which respects the inherent dignity of the individual in making important conscientious decisions without any influence of government being brought to bear.

I believe that, in so far as the framers of our Constitution were 60 or 70 years in front of the bishops of the Catholic Church in putting forward this proposal in the late nineteenth century, with the Church catching up only in the sixties of this century, the Church ought now to take the further step of supporting entrenchment of this important right and freedom so that it binds State and Territory parliaments and governments as at present it binds this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth while asking what the fourth constitutional referendum question seeks to secure. I think one of the best expressions of that appears in the first report of the Constitutional Commission. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The values that underlie our political system demand that every individual be free to hold and to manifest whatever beliefs and opinions that person's conscience dictates. So long as an individual does not transgress the reasonable limits established in a free and democratic society, his or her freedom of religious belief and practice should not be fettered. Religious freedom is the paradigm freedom of conscience.
The report asks why we need this particular proposal. Again, it is worth while addressing ourselves to that report. It states:

We believe that the guarantee of that freedom should be consistent throughout the federation. The same standards should apply in every place and to every Government. There is no case for variation where such a basic human liberty is concerned.

That is the fundamental debate. There should be no variation where such a fundamental human liberty is concerned. Let us be very clear that the Opposition's position is not that. The Opposition's position is that some governments should be able to traduce this particular right when it feels like it. Let us be very clear what the Opposition is arguing. It is not seeking to extend this right; it is seeking to oppose its extension. It is seeking to oppose the rights of citizens to their freedom of conscience when it concerns State governments. That is clear and unequivocal. It has been made clear on every platform on which I have debated. The Opposition has made no bones about it. It is attempting to ensure that State governments control the religious conscience of individuals in this country. It is a pity that when we had the type of rubbish that has been spoken about time and again, it did not put that on the table. It has covered it up. It has come out with all sorts of honeyed words and sweet propositions. But it boils down to a very simple proposition: it wants the States to be able to control people's freedom of conscience. It is fascinating that individuals such as Sir Maurice Byers are attacked for entering the political arena, but when the churches say something they are not attacked for entering the political arena. Very cleverly, all the submissions from the churches to the Constitutional Commission are put aside. The National Jewish Commission on Law and Public Affairs stated:
Whatever the rationale of the framers of the Constitution in restricting the ambit of section 116 to the Constitution-
That is one of the items we are dealing with here-

it is submitted that no valid distinction may be maintained in the latter part of the twentieth century, and that there is no good reason why the States too should not be subject to the constitutional safeguards currently enshrined in the Section.

That is the major objection I have to the document that was circulated by the Australian Catholic Bishops' Conference. I am not speaking out of turn here. I wrote to the Catholic bishops. I took the time and trouble to analyse each section of their misleading statement. It is a partisan, political document. They have to accept that it is a partisan political document.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a QC's opinion.
—It is not a Queen's Counsel opinion, it is the catholic bishops' opinion. They stated quite clearly that it is their opinion. The first proposition in the Catholic bishop's statements reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The alteration of the Constitution is a matter so significant that all voters have a clear moral responsibility to inform themselves of the issues.
That is something with which I totally agree. It goes on:
Each voter should vote according to conscience rather than simply through loyalty to any political party.

It has been extremely unfortunate that we have seen yet again in our constitutional debate something that we have seen so often in this country. If those people would like me to rehearse the whole 1974-77 situation I would be glad to do so. It is unfortunate that we have not been able to disentangle our constitutional debate from our petty partisan political objectives on a day to day basis. I support totally the first proposition. It is a very important statement. The second proposition states:

The Central Commission is concerned about the manner in which the issues in this referendum are presented. Indeed, the issues have been selected not by any pressure from the electorate but rather by the Government.

I have no idea where the Catholic bishops get that from. I have gone to innumerable conferences, conventions, meetings and branch meetings-not of my own party but of various associations-throughout my own State and throughout Australia in the last 10 years talking about constitutional change. I said to the bishops that I am unable to see how they have the faintest idea what the electorate is thinking on constitutional matters. I have been involved in a score of conferences and, frankly, the proposition carries no weight at all. The Catholic bishops go on to make an extremely disingenuous statement. They state:

The Australian legal and political system involves a federation with separate tiers of government. The principle of subsidiarity demands that there should not be undue concentration of political power in the Commonwealth.

Why mention that with regard of this item? It actually does not give any power to the Commonwealth; it takes power away from the States. In fact, it takes additional power away from the Commonwealth because to date the Commonwealth, in terms of administrative action, has had these capacities. It loses power, so why is this item in this statement other than to be misleading. There is no basis for that in this question. I argue that it is not a basis for any other question either. The fourth proposition states:
Of particular concern is the grouping in one question of three distinct issues . . .

That is reasonable but if they had actually addressed themselves to the issue a little more closely they would have seen that these are the rights which are currently enshrined in the Constitution, that they are areas that the Commonwealth is not able to trample on, and that these three questions are an attempt to remove from the States that power to trample on the rights of citizens, to take away their rights to trial by jury, to take away their property as the States have done. I am sure Senator Chaney from the Liberal Party agreed with his Party's fight in New South Wales with regard to the coal acquisition Act. It took away land and it took away property without compensation. States are quite capable of doing that as is its creature, local government, which does it time and again, day in day out. The Opposition is saying, `Let them do that. We're quite happy for States to take away your property without compensation. We don't want any constitutional guarantee of that proposition. Neither do we want a constitutional guarantee of a right to trial by jury. We don't like that. We don't want that to be a citizens' right in this country. We want to trample on that right of a citizen'. That is what it is saying. That is what it has been arguing throughout the community on every platform that I have been on. The Catholic bishops go on to say:
On the issue of freedom of religion the bishops have obtained specialist advice from a variety of experts.

It is interesting that they have not been able to tell me yet who their experts are. It is keeping them carefully under wraps. Proposition No. 6 is even more interesting because it shows an abysmal ignorance of why the United States of America Supreme Court decided the way it did with an item which is not in our Constitution. That ignorance of history, the ignorance of Jefferson's letter, displays an extraordinary proposition for a group which should know. That they put out this statement and do not refer to Jefferson's letter is extraordinary. Proposition No. 7 states:
In particular the now settled question of government funding of non-government schools and other educational institutions may be re-opened . . .

They do not actually say that it could be reopened without any change. They ignore that point; they do not tell anybody that. That is, of course, the proposition. Anybody who knows anything about constitutional history knows that that is so. But that point has been left aside. Proposition No. 8 reads:
The long tradition of freedom of religion which our country has enjoyed is best protected through the democratic process . . .

Again, I reiterate Senator Tate's comment: they have forgotten their church history. They have certainly forgotten it with regard to the British Commonwealth. They have certainly forgotten the persecution of the Catholic Church that has occurred in country after country. They have decided to put that aside. They have also forgotten the persecution of the church in so many countries in the world today. I find it extraordinary that a group of people who are supposed to be the pastors of their faith in this country should put aside the interests of their own religious confreres in other parts of the world. Proposition No. 9 states that voters need to be particularly cautious in looking at this proposal and that it is vague. It is in no way vague; it is a very clear proposition. It is extraordinary that the bishops then claimed, in a letter to me, that their statement should not in any way be seen as partisan or political. That is silly, and it does them no credit.

It is interesting that such a statement should have been made in the context in which it was made. It is interesting that the newspapers gave this statement such a long run when so many spokespersons from a variety of religious backgrounds in this country who opposed the statement were not given the same media coverage. I think it is a pity that when such statements are made, they are not more balanced. I have debated the matter on a number of platforms with people who have presented a balanced case. There are pros and cons to any proposition. I think it would have been far more worth while, in terms of making a contribution to the debate, if the bishops had presented a more balanced case and argued their position in a more balanced way.

The exercise in which we are engaged represents an attempt by the Opposition to make sure that the States do not have taken away from them the power to trample on people's rights. The Opposition wants to protect the States' and State government's power to introduce or establish religions. It wants to protect the so-called States' right to have religious tests for people entering the Public Service. It wants to protect the States' right to deny citizens the right to trial by jury. It wants to protect the States' right to be able to take away property from individuals without giving them due compensation. That is what the Opposition is arguing: the State governments are to be supreme in these areas. Quite frankly, I belong to a political party that espouses a liberal philosophy. The philosophy espoused by the Opposition in this regard comes directly from Marx, because it suggests that the States have those types of supreme powers over individuals. I will continue to fight for the enshrinement in our Constitution, within our fundamental document, of the rights of individuals. I believe that those rights will only be secure when they are finally enshrined in the Constitution, under the control of people and not of politicians. I do not happen to trust politicians. I suggest that those people who do not trust politicians take the power away from them and put it in the Constitution by voting yes on Saturday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of public importance proposed by my colleague Senator Bishop. I do so knowing full well that many people are concerned about the referendum questions that will be asked on 3 September. Many people in the Christian community are certainly concerned about the fourth question, which is: `Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms to persons whose property is acquired by any government?'. That question, and all the other questions that will be put to the people, are misleading, dishonest, and blatantly biased, and they are framed in such simplistic terms that they deceive the voter into believing that the questions are innocent. Nothing can be further from the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: These questions did not merely appear on the ballot paper by accident; they are part of the Government's political agenda-an agenda that will become apparent further down the track. They add 732 words to our Constitution; they remove 609 words; they change 33 clauses. More changes are proposed to the Constitution than have been put to the people of Australia in 87 years. This Constitution that has guaranteed our democracy, our freedom and our way of life, will be altered 33 times if these referendum questions are carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not an argument in itself why you shouldn't do it, is it?

—Certainly. I take up that interjection. The Australian people may perceive that there is a need for a change. This has occurred three times, in my memory. There was the question of Aboriginals being given the right to vote. No one would concede that Aboriginals should not be allowed to vote. The other changes involved the replacement of senators from various parties and a retirement age of 70 years for judges. They were clear and concise questions that could be understood by the majority of people in Australia. They had no hidden agenda and no hidden meaning. The people could see the need for change, and they responded to it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are being offered a totally different proposition on Saturday. We are being offered 33 changes. One would have to be a constitutional lawyer even to understand them. I think the Government should be condemned for proposing 33 changes to the Constitution under the heading of four simple questions that no one can understand, and which have the capacity to change our Constitution, our democracy and the way of life that we have been proud of for the last 200 years. I do not believe that anyone in Australia, or the rest of the world, for that matter, would say that we do not have freedom of religion or that we have any constrictions on our freedoms. We are the freest nation in the world. We are the envy of every country in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are the luckiest country.

—As Senator Bjelke-Petersen says-and I acknowledge it-we are the luckiest country in the world. We are guaranteed our constitutional freedoms under the present constitution. But the Government wants to change that. It wants to wreck it by bringing in 33 changes which no one understands and upon which people will be called to make a decision on Saturday.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the government has pushed these referenda questions its support has evaporated by the moment. Big business has deserted it and small business is getting off the boat. Local governments were gung ho about the proposal when it first appeared. Two or three weeks ago when I travelled around Queensland, many local governments were refusing to pay their levy. More local governments were proposing that the no vote be carried than there were proposing that the yes vote be carried. A few Labor town councils were still supporting it. Churches are not supporting the referendum. The Catholic bishops have refused to support it, as has the Anglican Dean of Sydney, the Very Reverend Lance Shilton. Eminent legal groups are putting advertisements in newspapers, urging and pleading with people to vote no.

Senator Macklin made a fairly determined, hard and unwarranted attack on the Catholic bishops. I certainly dissociate myself from his words. The church leaders do not have any political axe to grind. The Anglican Dean of Sydney, the Very Reverend Lance Shilton, called for a no vote and the bishops have called for a no vote. They are not aggressive towards the Australian Labor Party. They are not pro National or pro Liberal. They are concerned to act in the best interests of their own Christian community. They are concerned about freedom of religion; they are concerned about the widely supported principle of State and Federal funding of independent schools and hospitals; and they are concerned about Federal laws overriding State laws on abortion. A case involving this matter was heard in the Canadian Supreme Court recently. Senator Gareth Evans has acknowledged that the proposed Australian Bill of Rights would follow the Canadian principle and that is what we are getting. If this fourth question is answered in the affirmative we will get a Bill of Rights. They are concerned, under the proposed changes to the Constitution, that Australia will follow the American pattern of not only freedom of religion but also freedom from religion. That is why the bishops and church hierarchy throughout Australia are advocating a no vote. There is no political bias for the National Party of Australia or the Liberal Party of Australia. There is no aggression towards the Labor Party. There is a fundamental concern that as leaders of their churches they are entitled to express an opinion. Not to do so would be an abrogation of their responsibility. Yet they are attacked in the Senate by Senator Macklin-and it is a very vicious attack too, I might add.

If question 4 is carried it is going to be a threat to independent education. I want to go into this because I too have gone and sought a Queen's Counsel opinion. There are plenty of them floating around here, but I too sought one. In 1980 there was a challenge by a group calling itself the Council for the Defence of Government Schools (DOGS) and Senator Bishop has certainly picked that up and carried the argument very well. The challenge was thrown out of the High Court of Australia. The High Court made its ruling on the basis of the words `make any law for'. These are the very words that are being removed by the Government proposal-the very words that safeguard the funding of independent schools. No wonder we saw yesterday-I would love to know where this organisation gets its money from-a two-page advertisement in the Age newspaper. I am told from a reliable source that that advertisement would cost over $20,000. The Government is being encouraged by a $20,000 advertisement to push for question 4. These are the very people who wanted to undermine funding for Catholic schools, for Methodist schools, for Church of England schools and for hospitals-for all independent schools. These were the very people who wanted to undermine that funding and here they are, three or four days away from a referendum, supporting the Government with a $20,000 advertisement. That commitment by the DOGS council should warn every fair-minded Australian who believes in an independent schools system or supports assistance for church hospitals, and homes which are run by church organisations, that assistance to these very institutions will be challenged in the High Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish.

—It is not rubbish and the honourable senator knows it is not rubbish. That $20,000 advertisement proves that it is not rubbish because he has encouraged these people to come out and support him. I do not know what the High Court will decide. Senator Tate who has the respect, I believe, of both sides of this House does not know what the High Court will decide. Who knows what the composition of the High Court will be in five, 10 or 15 year's time. They are the people who will be making the decision, not the elected representatives of the people. They can be dismissed, can be appointed and can be voted in. We are taking democracy out of the hands of the people's elected representatives and we are putting in a High Court that cannot be dismissed, it cannot be recalled, and it is stuck there till those judges reach the retiring age of 70 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia would be in a far worse state if the contributions to schools, to nursing homes, and to all these institutions that the churches provide, were removed. I say to the Christian charismatic church groups that they would do well to consider what would happen if the provision in question 4 were applied to their Bible colleges and their universities which they are looking forward to building. All of these things would be put in jeopardy under section 116. If this referendum question is carried on Saturday the new section 116 will impose four constraints which I will nominate. No government may: establish any religion; impose any religious observance; prohibit the free exercise of religion; or require a religious test as a qualification for office. The United States Constitution contains the first, third and fourth of these constraints and the Canadian charter only the third. The Australian High Court will be required to interpret section 116, should the vote on Saturday be carried as a guarantee of religious freedom.

The Canadian authority as well as the American authority will probably become relevant and be applied in Australia. This is the advice I get from the opinion of my Queen's Counsel. Not only will foreign precedents be considered but the history of constitutional interpretation in both the United States and Australia shows that the interpretations change markedly over time. One only has to look at the present scope of our external affairs power as compared with its original influence. This is the other reason why it cannot be confidently predicted that the United States jurisprudence will not, in the future, be held to be applicable to the interpretation of proposed section 116. In fact, one could be highly confident that the proposed alteration provides a strong logical basis for our High Court to apply the United States and Canadian precedents. It is not good enough for Senator Tate to dismiss legitimate concerns about the relevance of the United States record of freedom of religion by saying, `It is okay. The Deputy Prime Minister is a Catholic and he has seven children'. He will not be here in another three year's time. Senator Tate might not be here either. The fact is that if we follow the Labor line on this issue our section 116 will be similar to both the American and Canadian related amendments.

In the short time that I have left I want to just read out some of the things that have happened under the American amendments. In America the courts have ruled against displaying the Ten Commandments in public schools. A public school principal demanded that a picture of a school club that used the Bible for development exercise be excised from the year book. Many things like that have happened. Is this what we want to risk happening to Australia after 200 years of hard slog? Do we want to hand over so much power to an unelected, appointed body such as the High Court? Do we want to entrench this potential for freedom from religion so deep in our Constitution that we can never get it out? Do we want the Federal Government interfering in our States' legislation? This is what we risk if we accept the Government's proposal for the new section 116. This is the year of our bicentenary. We should be looking to consolidating our gains that we have made over 200 years in this nation. We should not try to experiment with something that no-one understands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The arguments put by the Opposition in relation to all these questions are, I believe, the most convoluted, misleading and distorted set of arguments that I have ever heard. It has scraped the bottom of the barrel with all four questions. Nowhere has it scraped the bottom of the barrel more thoroughly and nowhere is it so shameless than in its arguments in relation to this question of the freedoms. How can it argue against such fundamental rights as the right to trial by jury? The right to just compensation for the acquisition of property and the right to freedom of religion are unarguable. Yet we have trotted out by the Opposition a set of propositions that are not related to the argument at all but are simply designed to inject fear into the debate so that those who are feeling insecure will feel a twinge of paranoia and vote no to the propositions before them. There is very little concern for truth. I do not think I have ever heard such nonsense in any debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer particularly to the debate that has raged around the country. I notice that people are a little more constrained in this House because their remarks go into Hansard, but around the country some absurd things have been said. Such remarks have been quoted here by other speakers. I will come to some of them shortly. The debate here is not designed to achieve an objective analysis of the issues, as people are claiming; rather, it is to engender fears where none exist, to whip up hysteria around a set of proposals which, to reasonable people, by any standards are modest and in any other circumstances unexceptionable.

Let us look at some of the outlandish things being said. The matter of public importance refers to threats to rights and liberties, when each of the proposals is designed to extend rights and liberties. No argument I have heard so far has cast any doubt at all on that extension. We have also heard around the country the most outlandish claims. Some of them have already been alluded to. I refer to such things as almost compulsory clitoridectomies through to the suggestion that no more prayers will be allowed in schools and the observance of Christmas and Easter will no longer have a religious content. Those are the nonsensical things that are claimed. Best of all was a letter in today's West Australian by the redoubtable Sir Charles Court which takes the whole question a step further. He argues that this is all an insidious plot and that what we are trying to do is return to Roman times; that this is comparable to the rebellion of Christians under the Caesars which caused two centuries of martydom and repression. He referred to the Russian Christians who want unlicensed worship. He talked about that being one of the dark stains of the twentieth century. By juxtaposing those concepts with the proposals that we are putting on religious freedom he has tried to make out that we are supporting those 200 years of martyrdom or the Russian system of licensed religion. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is another rather sad example of how far out of touch with realities Sir Charles Court now is. He is one of those politicians who did not learn the rule that all politicians should learn: when they retire they get right out of politics and not try to keep involved because ultimately they degenerate into the sort of absurdities that he has.

On the question of trial by jury, section 80 of the Constitution is intended to be a safeguard for individual liberty. In fact, it applies only where trial is on indictment for an offence against the Commonwealth. Thus the vast majority of people are not covered by that provision. It does not apply to States or Territories and the parliament-in the States and Territories and at the Commonwealth level-is free to decide whether offences should be tried by indictment or by other forms of trial. What we are saying in this proposition is that we should replace the threshold test of trial by indictment, which is a parliamentary thing and decided by parliament and which is governed, as Senator Tate has already said, by the majority at any time in parliament. Surely that is far more dangerous than something written into the Constitution and subject to case law following on from that. We are saying that the threshold test of trial by indictment where the accused is liable to two years imprisonment or corporal punishment should be written into the Constitution. The provision also extends to States and Territories. So it is an extension of the right of trial by jury.

I would have thought that that was totally unarguable. Judging from the level of argument from the other side, that seems to be the case. Honourable senators opposite enter into a convoluted set of arguments that raise fears and furphies; they do not get close to the substance of what the arguments are all about. I think Senator Bishop earlier talked about this being a Government-driven referendum but the Opposition's policies make it clear that such a right should be written into the Constitution. In its policy manifesto before the 1987 election, under the heading `Constitutional reform', it states:
2.1.1 The right to trial by jury in serious criminal cases should be guaranteed by the Constitution.
It goes on to say:

The right to jury trial for serious offences against Commonwealth laws, once thought to be provided by section 80 of the Constitution, has been greatly diminished by judicial decisions. The right to trial by jury is so basic to our common law system and as a defence against arbitrary punishment that it should be entrenched in our Constitution. This protection should apply to trials for offences against Commonwealth, State or Territory laws:

In other words last year the Liberal Party, in its manifesto before the election, put up a proposition which is identical to the one that we are now proposing. Yet it says there has been no movement from outside. The fact that the Constitutional Commission recommended this change seems to the Liberal Party to be irrelevant. The fact that successive Constitutional Conventions have suggested it seems to be irrelevant to the Opposition. The fact that various legal bodies have from time to time suggested it is also considered irrelevant. It is far from being a Government engendered proposition; it is a proposition that has been floating around for many years now and it was supported by the Liberal-National Party Opposition as recently as last year. In fact, the recommendation of the shadow Cabinet was that this proposal be supported, so it was supported far more recently than July of last year.

The second proposition is related to the acquisition of property. The Constitution provides in section 51 (xxxi) for the Commonwealth Parliament to make laws for the acquisition of property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Parliament has the power to make laws. The emphasis is on `just terms'; that is, there should be reasonable compensation within the standards appropriate at the time if the Government-in this case only the Commonwealth because that is the only government to which this provision in the Constitution applies-acquires property for whatever purpose. That seems perfectly appropriate and it seems quite inappropriate too that that provision does not apply to State or Territory governments.

The Liberal and National parties are the champions of private property. They bend over backwards at times to defend that right against the right of individuals who are caught up against that right. To me, the Liberal Party stands far more for property law than it does for the rights of individuals, despite painting itself otherwise. Yet the champions of private property deny the rights of individuals to receive just and reasonable compensation. I wonder how they will explain when a farm, a business or a domestic property is acquired by a State or Territory government-if this constitutional provision does not apply-for a road or for power transmission, water supply, irrigation or mining purpose. I wonder how they will explain why it is that those people do not receive any compensation; why it is that they do not have a right to compensation; why it is that they did not support that right when they had the opportunity of supporting this fourth proposal in the referendum.

But it is on the question of religious freedom that the most absurd flights of fancy have been exercised. I wonder how intelligent people who have some pride in their capacity for rational analysis can lend themselves to some of the arguments that have been presented. The Opposition's campaign would have us believe that the proposal, as I have indicated, will somehow weaken the right to religious freedom rather than strengthen it, as it so clearly does; that it will somehow abolish the religious associations of public holidays such as Christmas and Easter; that it will somehow lead to the elimination of prayers in Parliament, at state funerals and other state occasions. How in the world one can argue that I will never know. It is the most illogical proposition, but it is not substantiated so it does not have to be logical. I worry about people who are able to lose whatever pride they have in their own capacity for self-analysis and honest expression of ideas and who lend themselves to that level of argument. They argue that it will lead to a plethora of unacceptable behaviour such as clitoridectomy, stoning of adulterers and so on by fringe religious groups. The nonsense in all of those arguments is patent. It has been dealt with by other speakers and I will not go into any more detail on it here.

The most elaborate and deceitful furphy of them all is that it will reopen the bitter and divisive state aid debate. I have already read from Sir Charles Court's letter, in which he makes much more out of that than most others would, even the Opposition in this chamber, despite the fact that honourable senators opposite have gone to some pretty absurd lengths. Sir Charles goes even further than most of them would. Some of them would be red faced, I imagine, at the sorts of propositions he put. At least I hope so. It is a sad reflection on a man of some standing that he has sunk to that level. All of these claims are clearly utter nonsense, and I think successive speakers have proved this to be so.

On the question of state aid for independent schools, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the article by Xavier Connor, QC, in today's Melbourne Age, which has already been referred to by previous speakers. I am not going to get into this argument about my QC versus your QC.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing it for then? Why are you quoting him?
—I am quoting him because what he is saying--
—He agrees with what you say.
—Is that not what Senator Chaney and others have been doing?
—Why are you taking the high moral ground on it?

—If Senator Short will listen I will show him that it goes through the various opinions that have been given and analyses those opinions, which is of interest. Mr Connor talks about the bishops' decision, which was based on an analysis by Peter Bennett, QC, and about the terms of reference he was given. Mr Connor says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have read the opinions of Mr David Bennett, QC, Dr G. D. Woods, QC, and the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers, QC, on this matter. The terms of the brief to Mr Bennett are remarkable. He was not asked to express his opinion as to the probable outcome of any future challenge to state aid. The questions that Mr Bennett was asked to answer were very artfully contrived. They asked only whether there was `any doubt beyond that presently existing that the decision in the DOGS (Defence of Government Schools) case would no longer be applicable'. Keeping within his brief--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Bronwyn Bishop on behalf of the Opposition in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The serious threat to rights and liberties posed by the Hawke Government's fourth referendum proposal, including the traditional notion of freedom of religion in Australia and in particular the widely-supported principle of State-aid to independent schools.

I have sat and listened to honourable senators from the Labor side of the House, and the one Australian Democrat who contributed. I have been reminded of why the reputation of politicians runs somewhere behind that of used car salesmen, and I say that with some apology to used car salesmen. The arguments which have been brought forward have been breathtaking in their arrogance, if not in their foolishness.

The simple proposition that the Opposition is asserting in this matter of public importance is that the amendments which are being put forward by the Government pose a serious threat to existing rights and liberties. That is a matter which is based upon the confession of uncertainty that has been made by representatives of this Government. The public could be excused for not wishing to listen to any politician on these subjects. But the public might follow the rule of the courts and accept that where statements are made against interest-in other words, if one makes a statement which does not actually go to one's own interest-there is an increased possibility that one is telling the truth. Two very senior people in the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), have made it absolutely clear that they cannot give guarantees with respect to the interpretation that will be put on these changes by the High Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot do that with the existing section.

—Senator Collins interjects that it cannot be done with the existing section. The truth is, of course, that the existing section has been subject to challenge in the High Court of Australia. The High Court by a majority of six to one-the minority of one being Mr Justice Murphy, who adopted very much an American style approach to this, an American type interpretation-gave a certain meaning to the existing section of the Constitution. These changes must raise the possibility of new interpretations being given. We have it on the public record that those people who challenged state aid to church schools-which is supposedly supported by every honourable senator in this chamber, including Government senators-the very people who challenged it in 1981 have made it quite clear that if this referendum is carried they see the possibility of challenging again. They are not the statements of politicians but the proper admissions by the Prime Minister and Senator Tate that they cannot say what the High Court might do. When one allies it with the already existing threat of a new challenge, it is an indication of the uncertainty which necessarily exists if this constitutional referendum is passed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me quote another non-politician, the recently retired Chief Justice of the High Court, a man who until very recently led the Court that had the responsibility for the interpretation of our Federal Constitution. Sir Harry Gibbs in a paper given in July this year said: This history of constitutional interpretation in Australia and the United States shows that it is impossible to predict what meaning will, in the future, be given to any provision of the Constitution which is expressed in words of generality. That is not necessarily bad but gives the Court room to adapt the Constitution as philosophies and situations alter. But it also means that one cannot safely assume that any general provision will have no more than a symbolic effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—Senator Collins says that it is right, and it is right. I am glad he makes that concession. Sir Harry Gibbs says it is possible that the High Court could change the interpretation of the existing section at some future time. Senator Collins is nodding his head again. I agree with him: it is possible but it is very unlikely. The majority of six to one is there. We have varying opinions from learned lawyers, lawyers far better than those who inhabit this place, except perhaps for Senator Durack, who is unfortunately not with us today. There are many learned lawyers with conflicting views, but a significant group of significant lawyers says that the risk of an adverse interpretation is greater given these changes. Senator Bishop has tabled in this place an opinion from Mr Bennett, QC. That, in turn, has been criticised by Xavier Connor, QC. I do not pretend that both lawyers are not respected QCs. What I say is that the High Court has made an interpretation, which most Australians would support and be happy with, and we are changing the words in a way which must give an opportunity for a further reconsideration of that section. That is the concern which is at the heart of our opposition to this part of the referendum.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back over the quite extraordinary contribution by Senator Beahan. The one value in what Senator Beahan had to say to this chamber is that he made it quite clear that we are dealing with three quite disparate propositions. One might have strong feelings about the question of property and its possible confiscation by government. One might have strong feelings about the risks to trial by jury in this amendment. It is clear that the size of juries, the question of majorities, is capable of virtually endless variation under the provision the Government is putting forward. One might have objection to the provisions with respect to freedom of religion. But the fundamental dishonesty that cannot be escaped is that all of the Australian people are being told that they must vote yes or no for all of these three propositions. They are given no opportunity to pick and choose. That is one of the great succession of dishonesties that we have seen in this whole approach.

We start with a $6m Constitutional Commission, which fundamentally was used to soften up the people with the idea that our Constitution was in some way out of date. The Government did not even wait for its final report before bringing forward these referendums. We then had $3m spent on softening up the people on the need for constitutional change. We have moved into a wonderful new building. Does that mean that we also need a new Constitution? What a wonderful piece of logic and reasoning for the Australian people! It is emotional cant. It is salesmanship done at the public expense to soften up the people to what the Government believes is the need for constitutional change.

We have these questions, condemned by observer after observer as thoroughly dishonest. I do not have time this afternoon to go back over that ground. There are 33 changes to the Constitution to be made by the answering of four simple and misleading questions. When the Senate sought to put in questions which truly described the changes being made by these referendums, those questions were voted down by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. There is no end to the attempts that have been made by this Government, including the attempts made by the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, to keep the argument low key, to keep politicians out of it. What an absurd proposition Mr Bowen has advanced. He has tried to still the debate, to get it through under cover of a public relations campaign carried out at the public expense.

In the limited time I have, let me say that I found the arrogance of the attack on the views of the Catholic bishops by Senator Macklin quite extraordinary. I have always believed that when bishops enter these areas they are open to debate. They are participants in the debate, like everyone else. I accept the right Senator Macklin has to differ from their views. But Senator Macklin's attack was on the basis of an arrogant assumption by him that his interpretation of the law is correct and that the bishops are wrong. I believe that that is not a firm foundation for an attack on the bishops, which has been made on their views here this afternoon. I quote again the opinion of David Bennett, QC, that has been tabled by Senator Bishop. He comes to the view that there is a greater risk in the amendment which is being put forward. The question is asked:
Would the proposed amendment give rise to any doubt beyond that presently existing that the decision in the DOGS case could no longer be applicable?
His answer is:
Yes. In other words, there would be a doubt as to whether grants of state aid to church schools would continue to be permissible under the Constitution.

One could go on quoting authorities. It becomes-as Senator Beahan tried to avoid-a question of your Queen's Counsel or my Queen's Counsel. Bevan Lawrence, who in our State as a lawyer has been active in campaigning against issues such as the identity card and the Bill of Rights, no doubt would have joined issue with the embracing of the whole concept of the Bill of Rights that was implicit in Senator Beahan's speech. People such as Bevan Lawrence, members of the Association of Heads of Independent Schools of Australia and sundry churchmen, including the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference, have come out and warned that there are difficulties and dangers in this proposal.

It is possible that the advice that anybody has received in this matter, including the bishops, is wrong. But I believe that there must be an increased risk of a different interpretation, given the differences of wording which exist between the Government's amendment proposal and what exists now. I believe that the caution which has been issued by the Catholic Bishops should be carefully heeded. They express their concern that a yes vote on this question could-and they use the word `could'-end up seriously restricting freedom of religion. They refer to the American experience and to the possibility that the interpretation of the Constitution in the DOGS case could be affected by the removal of the significant words `make any law for establishing' from this provision. I welcome the fact that the bishops have uttered that caution.

In the context of a series of debates in this chamber where accusations of whipping up public fervour and concern have been made, I refer, as Senator Boswell did, to the advertisements taken out in the Age newspaper on 30 August. John Howard in the House of Representatives expressed his concern about the tone of those advertisements. I believe that in their tone they are totally unrepresentative of the views of the majority of Australians. The element of sectional conflict, of conflict between religious groups, that is represented in those advertisements is a matter that is a minority interest in Australia. But it is a matter of great regret that the Government, in bringing forward this referendum, has clearly raised again the hopes of those who believe that the revival of this sort of sectarian attack has a future. The Government has re-opened that debate.

Within recent days we have been accused by the Government of opening up a difficult and divisive immigration debate. I throw that accusation back to the Government in this context because I believe that it has opened up a divisive debate in the area of religion and aid to schools. The last time I checked, the substantial growth in new schools numerically was in small Protestant schools. I welcome that. I welcome the fact that many different groups, some of them not religious, have taken advantage of the systems of aid which are available to widen educational choice in this country. Why in the world should we be putting it under any threat or doubt?

There are few opportunities left to us to debate these referendums in this place. The people go to vote on Saturday. I hope that they will heed the warnings which have been issued. I hope that they will acknowledge the uncertainties which exist about the real meaning and the full and final import of these changes. I hope that they will throw all of them out. Indeed, I believe that they will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —With that last prayer to the Senate, Senator Chaney is on fairly firm ground in terms of political history. There is no doubt-and the conservatives in this country are playing on it-that, on a question of changing the Constitution, Australians are so naturally conservative in their outlook and behaviour that, when one or other of the major political parties determines to make a political campaign of the issues, the success rate for getting some change to our outdated and outmoded Constitution is not very high.
