SPEECH.PARA: The thing that has always puzzled me about these debates, as I think it puzzles others, is the extraordinary degree of wisdom and prescience that is attributed to the founding fathers who put this Constitution together. They were simply a collection, as we all are, of politicians of the day, from the various crown colonies that are now the States of Australia, who did the best job they could of putting together the basis for this nation-and a pretty good job, in my view, considering the problems that existed at the time, which were largely unrelated to the political history of the United States and certainly of Great Britain.

A number of points need to be made about some of the matters that Senator Chaney has raised. It is perfectly true that there is a division among lawyers as to their interpretation of what effect the amendments to section 116 would have. Of course, lawyers grow rich on such division. If lawyers agreed on every matter that came before the nation, they would be very poor indeed. As we all know, they are very rich and they grow rich on disagreeing with each other and of course, finally, a court has to be the arbiter as to which view is correct. But lawyers do not have a mandate on the law. Some lawyers think they do. Some lawyers are very precious about the law. In fact I notice the other day when I had the hide to use the words `ratio decidendi' in a speech that I made, Senator Hill nearly had apoplexy. The reason I used the words is that I do not know of a quicker way of saying the legal principle upon which a court decision was based. It is a lot easier to use the word `ratio'. But Senator Hill nearly had a fit because I am not a lawyer and it was a dreadful thing for me to use lawyers' words. But lawyers do not have a monopoly on the law and I, like every other Australian on Saturday, will simply have to determine, basically on the grounds of commonsense, whether I believe that the changes to section 116 will destroy state aid overnight. It is an important question for me--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not overnight. No-one is arguing that.

—That is the basis of the scare campaign-perhaps next year or the year after; certainly in my lifetime. It is an important question for me because my children attend Catholic schools, I am a practising Catholic and, as I said the other night, I am also a member of the Northern Territory Catholic Education Council. So I can assure honourable senators that it is a matter I have given considerable attention to and, on balance, I am absolutely persuaded that I can safely vote yes to question four on Saturday without endangering the education of my son, the education of all other Australian Catholics and all those other children who are attending independent schools run by the Uniting Church in Australia, the Anglican Church and all the other churches.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to quote from Xavier Connor's article but not to quote the legal points that he makes-I agree with Senator Chaney that for every Queen's Counsel that says aye we get two Queen's Counsels who say no; there is hardly anything new or revolutionary about that. I want to quote from this article purely because of the philosophical point put by Xavier Connor as a Catholic layman because, frankly, I could not say it better myself. He stated:

As a Catholic layman, I am profoundly disappointed at the way in which the bishops of my church have handled the issue of freedom of religion in the referendum debate. When I went to Mass last Sunday every parishioner was given a copy of the bishops' statement. The message in it is loud and clear-vote No.

The view of the bishops is not based on Catholic theology or doctrine but on a seriously flawed view of Australian constitutional law. The vice of the bishops' presentation is that it completely and unfairly ignores a strong case for voting Yes which is entirely consistent with the teaching of the Catholic Church.

I could not say it better than that. In fact, I am ashamed as a Catholic layman when I put the actions of those bishops against what has been done in churches such as the Anglican Church and the Uniting Church, where senior clergy have put both cases and have argued strongly in some cases for the matter to be answered in the negative, but at least have conceded that there is another side to the question and allowed the laity of their churches to make a considered decision. The bishops have chosen not to do that and I, as a Catholic layman, condemn them as Xavier Connor has done, not for any flaw in their legal arguments-we will not get bogged down in that again-but from the way they have acted in this matter, which is certainly a reflection of the dreadful sectarian arguments that affected both the Catholic Church and my Party years ago. As an Irish-Catholic-Labor person, part of that great Irish family in the Australian Labor Party, it is a history of the Labor Party with which I am very familiar.

We then get on to this question of inability to provide a guarantee. Senator Chaney quoted the former Chief Justice of the High Court as saying, correctly, that a guarantee cannot be provided. Of course we cannot provide a guarantee that the interpretation that this High Court, currently constituted, has placed on section 116 as it is currently worded, is forever going to stay there. Of course, we cannot guarantee that; we cannot guarantee that about any section of the Constitution. It is all subject to the possibility of future reinterpretation. No lawyer in the country would stand up and say that we can offer a guarantee that there will never be a reinterpretation of any section of the Constitution or, indeed, any other law. If lawyers did that, they would be out of business overnight, because it is on those various interpretations that the entire practice of lawyers is based. As Australian citizens, all we can do is use our own intelligence that God has given us and, on the balance of everything that is in front of us, make our own decision about whether we think the change in the referendum proposals will weaken or strengthen the section as it currently stands.

I believe that there is no compunction to vote yes to question four if it did not change the effect of section 116. If it is simply left as it currently is, what would be the point of agreeing to it? I believe, and I am sure a lot of others in my church believe, that it does precisely what the drafters of the change have tried to do-that is, strengthen the section and not weaken it. Not only does it maintain the prohibition of parliaments interfering with the practice of religion; it extends that prohibition to the Executive doing precisely the same thing, and it extends that prohibition to the States.

On the question of some sinister plot being attached to lumping those three questions together, I say again, as I said in the debate the other day, that the questions are connected in the sense that they are all matters where the Commonwealth is prohibited from acting but the States are not, and they are all some of the very few sections of the Australian Constitution, which does not contain a Bill of Rights, which affect individual liberties, freedoms and the rights of citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are totally different subjects.

—I point out the bleeding obvious to the honourable senator that, in terms of some sinister plot being attached to this, as Senator Beahan quite correctly interjected, when the original Australian Constitution was put to the people all 128 sections were canvassed in one question.
—That is totally different.
—Of course it is a different situation because it does not happen to suit the honourable senator's argument.
—That is totally irrelevant.

—Again it is irrelevant because it does not happen to suit the honourable senator's argument. I turn now to the appalling misinterpretations-deliberate misinterpretations in my view because the people who are putting them are not entirely mugs-of the judgments of the High Court of Australia in the Council for the Defence of Government Schools (DOGS) case. Senator Bishop, who launched this debate-just one of the many bishops who are putting forward a view on this matter, to vote no-read out part of the judgment of Sir Anthony Mason in that case, but she stopped at the crucial point and, for the sake of the record, I would just like to continue where she left off. Senator Bishop said that the term `any law for' was the basis for the decision in the DOGS case. It was not. She read out Sir Anthony Mason's judgment in support of that view. In fact, the substance of that case, the legal principle upon which the decision was based-I do not want to upset any more lawyers by using legal terminology-was the words `the establishment of a religion'. Sir Anthony Mason's judgment makes that clear when he goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is altogether too much to say that a law which gives financial aid to churches generally, to be expended on education, is a law for establishing religion. The mere provision of financial aid to churches generally more particularly when that aid is genuinely linked to expenditure on education, falls short of `establishing' a `religion' as we understand the expression. By it we mean the authoritative establishment or recognition by the State of a religion or a church as a national institution.

I could not make it much clearer than that. Sir Ninian Stephen and Sir Harry Gibbs said precisely the same things in that case with a 6 to 1 decision, Justice Murphy dissenting. With the greatest respect for Mr Justice Murphy, I say that his judgment in this case was as idiosyncratic as his judgment in a number of other cases. He had strong views on this matter and he argued with legal principles to support that view. That is hardly a revolutionary thing for a Justice of the High Court to do-they do it all the time. Personally, I felt that there was more than enough room for a reformist judge like Mr Justice Murphy on the High Court. There is no getting away from the fact that Mr Justice Murphy had a strong view opposing state aid to non-government schools, and he chose that opportunity, as the sole dissenting judge, to make that point. I point out again the bleeding obvious-so much weight has been placed on Mr Justice Murphy's dissent, but it was based on the existing section 116 and not on any amended section 116. So I hardly understand the relevance of that.

The one thing that the coalition wants to smother or ignore is the dissension in its own ranks on this subject. There is dissension in Opposition ranks on this question, as there is with respect to immigration, because those opposite have sold their souls to the devil-and a very high price they have paid indeed. In order to maintain-and this is what it is all about-this ramshackle coalition with the Nationals, which is what it has become, a high price has been paid for their so-called liberalism, and the Liberal Party is continuing to pay that price.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! We are off the immigration debate.
—I will tell the honourable senator-
—Oh come on! You've got to be joking.

—What has the Liberal Party received in return for paying this price? Theoretically, after paying this high price the Opposition should be a mile in front, but at the moment it is in the unbelievable position, half way through a term, of being five points behind. The Opposition has paid this price and sold out its liberal principles but it is still as acceptable socially and politically to the Australian electorate as a pool of dog's vomit. That is not a very good return for the price that it has paid. It is in this position today basically on two grounds: firstly, in terms of the economic management of this country the Opposition cannot lay a glove on us; and, secondly, the majority-the lion's share-of the true liberals in this Parliament are all on this side of politics. That is the real problem. The Opposition is continuing to pay the price for this. However, there are still a few outstanding examples, and I refer to one in conclusion-the circular distributed by the Hon. Ian Wilson MP to his electorate. This Liberal member of Parliament advocates, among other things, a yes vote to question No. 4. I can only say that, like Ian Wilson and probably all the other true liberals in this Parliament, I will be voting yes to question No. 4 on Saturday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Dunn, I remind honourable senators that this is her first speech. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I did not expect to be here. Now that I am I intend to do all that I can to represent those whose major concern is to end the nuclear threat, to ensure as far as possible that future generations will be able to enjoy the beauty and health of an unspoilt natural environment, and to support and promote those measures which add to human dignity and freedom. I have great respect for the Senate, especially because the electoral system of this country makes this chamber the best forum for some widely-held community concerns that can rarely be directly represented in the lower House. In particular, I would like to pay tribute to Senator Jo Vallentine, the Australian Democrat senators, like-minded Government members, and independently minded senators on the other side with whom I share much common ground.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot avoid some reference to the unusual circumstances of my election. Some senators come here after being on major party tickets, after convivial party barbecues and tributes from backslapping party faithful. I came here with a high public profile, in a way that the former New South Wales Premier, Neville Wran, would describe as having `a blowtorch applied to the belly'. The issues involved have been canvassed extensively in the media and it would be inappropriate to raise them here. Let me just say that my decision to enter Parliament as an independent in no way reduces my commitment to the platform of the Nuclear Disarmament Party (NDP). In the short time that my predecessor Robert Wood was in this place, he was engaged in promoting disarmament. His disappointment in losing the seat is understandable. While our differences have been publicly aired, he has also said I was `pretty solid' on the issues and in this respect, at least, I hope not to disappoint him and the considerable body of Australians who are concerned about the nuclear threat.

It is a pleasant duty to thank a few of the people who provided generous support and assistance during a difficult period. First among these I acknowledge my mother, Raisa Dunn, for the dedication with which she laboured for years on a factory production line to ensure that her daughter received a decent education. I would also particularly like to thank the Senate staff and my personal staff, the Warren family, David Shellard, Tom Molomby, Eve Higson and Sarah Ahern, as well as the many others who have given me all the help I could have wished for in recent times. I should also like to acknowledge the voters of New South Wales. Although some may depreciate the results of the preferential proportional system and the quality of the votes, this is entirely unjustified. The preferential vote allows the deep community disquiet about nuclear technology to be reflected in the election of parliamentary representatives whose policies give prominence to these matters.

As for the 287,000 voters themselves, they are not the primitive Luddites that opponents will suggest, but largely well-informed citizens who have given careful thought to the best use of their vote and the possibility of effecting some necessary and constructive changes through this Parliament. Much the same can be said about the direction of Australian Labor Party (ALP) preferences to the Nuclear Disarmament Party in July 1987. Public opinion polls by the commercial pollsters and more specific surveys like that recently conducted by People for Nuclear Disarmament indicate an even broader concern in the community, especially among Labor voters, than is reflected in the NDP's aggregate preferential vote.

The concern of the voters derives not only from a stance of opposition to Australia's involvement in the arms race through uranium mining, the United States presence on our soil and the visits of nuclear warships to our ports. It is also expressing itself increasingly in a desire for Australia to develop an independent and self-reliant defence and foreign policy which emphasises this country's role and future in the Asia-Pacific region. We do not live in isolation, and what we do in Australia affects our neighbours. How can we, with consistency, sign the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and at the same time sell our uranium to the French for tests which spill radioactive rubbish around the Pacific region-rubbish that may contain uranium atoms originally dug from Australian soil?

After the recent Euratom revelations, we can no longer pretend that our engagement in the fuel cycle does not make us a party to the nuclear arms race. The failure of the International Atomic Energy Agency to monitor the non-proliferation treaty adequately and the practice of flag-swapping almost certainly result in Australian uranium being diverted somewhere along the line for bombs. Even if we consider only the civil use of nuclear technology, it is clear that it has been a serious disappointment. Nuclear power does not provide a desirable nor even a satisfactory answer to the energy demands of the future. Even in those countries with a heavy dependence upon fission generated electricity, the net contribution to national energy is relatively small, construction costs are high and reactor waste is a major problem and continues to generate scandals, such as Nukem, as well as radioactivity. Maintenance, repair and decommissioning costs make such programs economically suspect, even without taking into account the additional risks and costs of accidents and sabotage.

Since the commitment of the major powers to nuclear weapons, and the linked commitments of governments and commercial interests to nuclear power, military secrecy and civil misinformation have accompanied a dramatic increase in security and made fully informed debate much more difficult than it ought to be in a democratic society. Despite this security, plutonium is being moved illegally around the world and is being not only mislaid but also pilfered in significant quantities. The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) reported the existence of a `nuclear supermarket' at Khartoum in the Sudan, where quantities of plutonium, allegedly from European sources, and enriched uranium were sold to the highest bidders, including representatives from South Africa, Iraq, Iran and other countries. This sort of corruption is inevitable, but there have been open deals by nuclear technology exporting nations such as France and Germany which have exhibited a cynical disregard for global consequences. We all know, for example, about the `peaceful' Indian nuclear device developed with the help of a Canadian reactor. It is believed that several `peaceful' weapons exist, while the technical ground for denial of their existence may be as little as the turn of a screw away from fully armed weapons. Pakistan's `Islamic bomb' may also have some loose screws. It appears not to be so insistently peaceful.

Mordechai Vanunu's courageous revel- ations about Israel's nuclear arsenal, for which he was tortured and gaoled, were startling not because they disclosed the existence of the weapons, but because of the number and sophistication of the weapons. The minimum estimate is 100 atomic bombs, and there is a suspicion that Israel may be developing not merely hydrogen bombs but neutron bombs, which preserve the real estate while destroying lives. The number of bombs possessed by Israel is symptomatic of the nuclear fever exhibited by the bomb-owning states, where the number of weapons grows out of all proportion to their supposedly deterrent or military uses.

It is scarcely surprising that, despite setbacks, Libya, Iran and Iraq are also seeking nuclear weapons. We are not privy to what progress they have made, although Libya advertised for nuclear bombs on the open market. These developments in the Middle East have a special potential to drag larger states, however reluctantly, into a nuclear conflict. South Africa possesses nuclear weapons; Brazil and Argentina have sought nuclear weapons. There seems little reason to doubt that all nations with substantial nuclear research facilities will eventually develop nuclear weapons.

The failure of the United States Government, especially under President Reagan, to play the promised role of nuclear policeman will only encourage this process. Continued Australian engagement in the nuclear fuel cycle will inevitably make us party to this creeping worldwide affliction. The Government's claim that Australia must be involved in the uranium trade in order to have a positive role in disarmament and safeguards is, in my opinion, casuistry of a high order.

The Australian Labor Party National Conference in June this year pushed through an amendment calling for a review of uranium policy by the National Executive. Proposed changes included the relaxation of the three mines policy and the establishment of a uranium enrichment plant in the Northern Territory, which was proposed by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button. Significantly, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, rejected these proposals on economic grounds. The establishment costs of an enrichment plant would be massive. Radiation hazards in handling and transporting the enriched uranium would be increased, the product would be attractive to malevolent parties in times of international tension, and Australia would be regarded with suspicion, especially by close neighbours who might well suspect that at a later time the level of enrichment might be raised to weapons grade. I hope that this possibility is remote. I also hope that honourable senators share my distaste for the proposal of Mr Barry Coulter, the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, to establish a large nuclear waste disposal plant in the Northern Territory.

Now that Senator Button has let us know that the money is available, let us use it to upgrade some other Australian resources. If we must have a woodchip industry, let us use degraded farmlands for plantations and enrich our own industry, instead of paying Japanese companies to destroy our native forests and take them away. Why not develop our wool products instead of buying them back at a high mark-up in fashion products? Best of all, let us enrich our future by providing for the welfare and education of single mothers and their children who bear the brunt of poverty in this country.

To end my remarks on nuclear energy, I wish to refer briefly to the greenhouse effect, which has led to some suggestions to revive the ailing nuclear power industry. Such a reaction would be foolish. It would be many years before such reactors could be built, and when we examine the total energy use of developed nations it is obvious that merely `cleaning up' electricity generation would have a relatively minor effect on total carbon dioxide production. Most informed people expect that a strategy to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and maintain Western standards of living will draw from a wide spectrum of technologies. One of the most important will be economies in energy use such as occurred dramatically in the United States after the oil crisis of the early 1970s. Many features of energy consumption are more a matter of style than necessity and much more could be done if governments more actively promoted energy conservation.

A major need is a replacement for the liquid fuels in transportation. The cleanest longer term candidate is hydrogen which, when properly burnt, produces only water vapour. Research into the safe high-density storage of this gas is advanced and there are encouraging developments in the use of sunlight with a catalyst to split hydrogen from water, and in the technology of solar cells. Such measures may, in time, help to limit the impact of the greenhouse effect, but we live under the shadow of an even greater catastrophe-the nuclear winter-a threat that totally undermines the defensive philosophy of nuclear weapons. Although there has been some doubt cast upon the exact dimensions of the effect and the influence of seasonal variations, the basic proposition of nuclear winter stands unchallenged. The specially bad news for Australia comes from evidence that there is more atmospheric exchange between the hemispheres than was previously believed. Very shortly, not only the radioactive fallout but also the lethal sunlight obscuring clouds would cover our hemisphere.

We are currently basking in the sunshine of a more optimistic world. There have been gratifying easings of conflict and tensions in Angola, the Persian Gulf and Afghanistan, and a very partial disarmament treaty between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has been signed and is being put into effect. We may think that a nuclear war is unlikely at the moment, that there would be some warning. However, the military forces of both sides still face their respective `evil empires' and the possibility of accident is always present, as evidenced in the case of the Vincennes disaster where, like Chernobyl and Three Mile Island, human error at the interface with high technology broke down the safeguards. Are the ICBM silo crews any less ready today? I think not.

Only a few years ago, to please the United States, a government of this nation of which I am usually proud to be a citizen sent its young men to die in a futile and ill- conducted war. Honourable senators may remember the American boast that the United States air force would bomb Vietnam back to the Stone Age. We now know that, by accident or intent, in an unfavourable season, it may be instrumental in taking us all much further back. With luck, we may begin again at the point where our primordial ancestors crawled out of a green pond. On this issue I willingly risk being seen as another ranting Cassandra for the case against the nuclear arsenals is impossible to overstate.

I have a sympathetic affection for Matthew Arnold, who saw the modern world coming and did not like it much. His image of the `darkling plain' is as apposite as ever, but I have preferred, in times of adversity, some more muscular lines from his short poem The Last Word:
Let the victors, when they come
When the forts of folly fall
Find the body by the wall.

Unfortunately, this hope of posthumous vindication cannot apply here, and we may all be lying by the wall of the fort of folly-some of us with unforgivable expressions of surprise on our carbonised features. Everyone agrees that there will be no victors.

Any fair-minded citizen of a Western democracy addressing the subject of nuclear weapons and the possibility of a major nuclear conflict, finds that she will be directing a lot of trenchant criticism at our ally, the United States. This may seem unjust since the United States is only one of two superpowers that hold the world hostage. But it is also the virtue of United States democracy that allows and invites these criticisms. Indeed, much of our detailed information on nuclear technology comes from the United States because of its deep, if incomplete, commitment to freedom of information, and from the endeavours of United States citizens to keep their governments honest. However, there is a brashness and arrogance that manifests itself in military aspects of United States foreign affairs. To illustrate this, we have only to consider the bullying of New Zealand and the Palauan people as well as the United States reluctance to sign the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. It is still assumed that what is good for the United States is good for the world and, furthermore, that the world should be grateful for the chance to contribute. It is more galling to be in servitude to a professed friend than to an enemy.

Press reports today back up this point. They show that US State Department officials used standover tactics on the former Opposition Leader Bill Hayden by threatening to tear up the ANZUS agreement if a future Labor government insisted that the US indicate whether or not the US ships carried nuclear weapons. This is the sort of alliance we can do without. US Secretary of State, George Shultz, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) may be great golf buddies, but this sort of backyard bullying by a superpower puts Australia in a potentially deadly game where the cards are heavily stacked against us.

Let us consider the role of the so-called joint facilities on Australian soil. No-one denies that they would be targets in any major nuclear exchange and their jointness is very doubtful. Our Government argues that these facilities are necessary for deterrence. But while our Government uses the word `deterrence' to mean `retaliatory deterrence', the US military uses information from the facilities to support a destabilising, war fighting deterrence. The US military uses the word `deterrence' very broadly.

The Government argues that Nurrungar and Pine Gap are essential for verification, but what is presented as verification to us may be strategic war planning for the US. There are very good reasons to support the closure of Nurrungar, in South Australia. Its function in relation to the US war fighting strategy and the strategic defence initiative is inconsistent with the Australian Government's opposition to these strategies. Whatever verification function it presently has will be rendered obsolete by the deployment of nuclear explosion sensors on the new Navstar satellites. These will perform the verification function far more efficiently than the Nurrungar satellites. Moreover Nurrungar's role in providing early warning of missile launches will become redundant with the deployment of satellite to satellite crosslinks, which will relay information directly to the US without the necessity for a ground station. Pine Gap is also generally defended on the grounds of its role in verification, despite the small amount of such work performed at the base.

I support Australia playing a major role in verification. Glasnost has not extended to the Soviet military and there is a need for such activities. Australia should promote international verification efforts by phasing out Pine Gap, as it presently is, and replacing it with facilities which perform the genuine functions required for verification. North West Cape on the other hand has no role in verification. It is used to communicate with US hunter-killer submarines, which under the US Navy maritime strategy would attack Soviet submarines at the outset of conventional superpower conflict. There is no justification for its presence on Australian soil. It may be stating the obvious, but hosting a base that enables the US to fight a nuclear war makes little contribution to disarmament.

The continued presence of the bases is offensive to Australian sovereignty, and the secrecy surrounding the bases is unacceptable. The only way the Australian population can reasonably make up its mind about the issue is to have more information, not less, about the bases. It is clear that, at the very least, there ought to be a full public inquiry into the bases. It is too important a decision to be left to the Government alone.

The visit to Australian ports by nuclear armed warships poses special difficulties for a nation such as ours which is, according to the Government, committed to disarmament. The weapons these ships carry contribute greatly to the risk of superpower confrontation and nuclear war. In the past 10 years more than 2,500 nuclear warheads have been added to the world's naval arsenals, and the provocative naval exercises held by the US and USSR in sensitive areas have the potential for dangerous military escalation.

The most worrying development is the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons such as sea launched cruise missiles. These weapons are not covered by any existing arms control agreements despite being almost identical to the air launched missiles limited by the strategic arms limitation talks and the ground launched missiles banned by the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty. Sea launched cruise missiles are currently the major obstacle to a new strategic arms control agreement, so much so that the senior arms control adviser to the US Government, Paul Nitze, has proposed the total elimination of tactical naval nuclear weapons as a solution to the problem. Such a move would also dramatically reduce the risk of nuclear escalation of a conventional naval confrontation between the superpowers.

Despite the destabilising effects of these weapons the Australian Government welcomes vessels carrying them to our shores. The current series of visits is but the latest example of this. Such an unquestioning acceptance can only encourage the US to continue to resist controls on these weapons. The Government should immediately call on the US to withdraw these weapons from its arsenal. Australia should ban visits by any vessel capable of carrying these destabilising nuclear weapons. Such a decisive move would send a clear signal to the superpowers that Australia, at least, is serious about disarmament. There are also more immediate dangers for Australia in hosting the visits of nuclear warships. The danger of an accident occurring in port has been the subject of considerable interest in this House. The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has been looking at the adequacy of planning for such an accident for nearly two years and is only now preparing its final draft.

I do not propose to deal today with the dangers of a reactor accident occurring in port and the inadequacy of current Australian planning for such an accident. Instead, I refer to the current visit by seven nuclear vessels of the US and UK navies to 19 Australian ports. Accidents in harbours are not rare, and the Falklands war gave us an insight into the ferocity of fires on modern warships. The plutonium that would be released and spread by an accident could, when inhaled, lead to cancers with a latency of seven to 20 years.

In evidence presented to the Senate Standing Committee, US Professor Jackson Davis estimates that the incineration of a single nuclear warhead in a ship fire could cause up to 11,000 latent cancer fatalities, depending on atmospheric conditions. If our Government is determined to persist with nuclear warship visits, there is a moral obligation to put in place and rehearse a comprehensive evacuation plan. There would have to be decontamination stations with trained crews on controlled routes out of each city. In Sydney, perhaps the toll booths on the Sydney Harbour Bridge could be modified to some useful purpose.

We should add to this the feasibility study for the unprecedented multi-billion dollar decontamination of each visited city; the footnotes could consider the cost of shutting down all inner urban activities and the extinction of the tourist industry. This is obviously ridiculous. We run too high a risk for the privilege of pleasuring our great and powerful friends.

I ask honourable senators to cast their minds forward to 26 September, Sydney Harbour. There is a light shifting breeze, and the officially impossible has happened. A nuclear vessel has collided with another vessel and is on fire. The wind is carrying the plutonium oxide laden smoke across the crowds that pack the foreshores. Some members of Federal Parliament might not much care if the wind carried the lethal smoke up Macquarie Street to State Parliament where Premier Greiner and his Ministers are desperately trying to unearth the ancient port safety plan which the Government recently withdrew. Meanwhile thousands of Sydney residents and visitors are trapped at the waterside in a choking radiological cloud. Many of these people will be there to register their protest, but most are there because their political mentors have let them believe that unconfirmed and not denied nuclear weapons are safe. How will we explain why these people have been infected with a sort of nuclear aids? Of course this scenario is an unlikely event. So was Chernobyl. But if it did occur-and it is a possibility-the consequences would be devastating.

The city of New York has, with the cooperation of the US Navy, just released an accident plan for a harbour which receives visits under exactly the same conditions as Australian ports. The Australian authorities dismiss the need to plan for such an accident. No State Government holds a plan to deal with such an accident. No special controls are placed on these ships while they are visiting our shores. The only rational conclusion is that nuclear ships must not be allowed in our ports.

In closing, I must pay tribute to some of the women whose efforts have made it possible for a woman's voice to be heard in this Parliament today. First among these is South Australian Mary Lee, who was largely responsible for gaining the vote for women in Australia. In 1893, she castigated the Labor Party as a `lot of nincompoops' for supporting a suffrage Bill that was encumbered by a referendum condition. When the Constitution Amendment Act was passed on 18 December 1894, South Australian women became the first in the country to gain the vote, as well as the right to stand for parliament. Interestingly enough, when Mary Lee was invited to stand for parliament herself she declined, saying she preferred to work `on the side of right . . . unfettered by pledge or obligation to any party whatever'.

Another suffragist in the movement was the vivid Henrietta Dugdale, who believed that the greatest obstacle to human advancement, `the most irrational, fiercest and most powerful of our world's monsters', was male ignorance. The much maligned writer and newspaper proprietor, Louisa Lawson, founded the suffrage society the Dawn Club so that women could get the vote `to redeem the world from bad laws passed by wicked men'. It is not surprising that many of the suffragists believed that gaining the vote, and parliamentary representation, for women would further the cause of peace. Amongst these was intellectual, feminist and peace activist Marion Harwood, whose criticism of Britain as well as Germany during World War I brought her to the attention of the censors.

History has largely ignored the work of Rose Scott, President of the New South Wales branch of the Peace Society, of Annette Bear-Crawford, of Bella Lavender, who led the Labour Women's Anti-Conscription Campaign during the 1916 referendum, of Mary Fullerton and of Vida Goldstein.

Finally, I come to the inimitable Jessie Street, the centenary of whose birth falls on 18 April next year. Like most of the women I have referred to, Jessie was conscious of the link betwen peace and social justice, especially for women, and she dedicated her life to this cause. I have had the great privilege of serving on the Jessie Street Centenary Committee and, through personal contact with Jessie's family, friends and colleagues, I have become aware of the powerful influence she had on a generation of women who paved the way for the resurgence of feminism in the 1970s. Jessie stood unsuccessfully for Parliament several times. She was a founding member and New South Wales President of the Australian Peace Council, and was the first woman to represent Australia at the United Nations, where she was instrumental in introducing the sexual non-discrimination clause to the United Nations Charter. She was also instrumental in promoting the Aboriginal referendum of 1967 which gave Aboriginal people the vote. Although I never met Jessie, her dedication, humour and compassion have been an inspiration to me, as I am sure they have been to the other women in this chamber, who are the inheritors of a tradition to which Jessie made such a great contribution.

Fate has shown a remarkable consistency today by timing the first inaugural speech in the new Senate chamber with the debut of a revived and strengthened peace movement in Australian political life. Some critics have claimed that political representation for the peace and anti-nuclear cause has become irrelevant in today's hard-nosed economic climate. These critics have, I think, wishfully misinterpreted mere growing pains as chronic illness. Although the figures from the Frank Small and Associates survey have been much quoted in recent months, they are very significant and bear repeating. Support for the presence of the foreign bases has dropped from 60 per cent in 1980 to 35 per cent this year, while support for the visits of nuclear-armed warships has dropped from 47 per cent in 1982 to 24 per cent this year. The growing realisation by Australians that they do not have to be party to nuclear warfare nor feebly accept visits from bullying nuclear powers has shown that the peace movement has well and truly shed its `ratbag' tag and emerged as a full grown force capable of understanding the complex outlook of Australians in the 1980s.

When the Prime Minister opened this futuristic building he asked us all to `understand the awesome obligation that is upon us'. He said that, for those in the new Parliament House, this will be an obligation to recognise always, in the conduct of debate, that whatever our views, ideology or party, we are part of something bigger-an institution which must endure long after the divisive issues of the day have been fought and resolved. This obligation leads me to the timely conclusion that we are the curators, not the exploiters, of this great land. We have 122 days left of the historic bicentennial year. In the days ahead let us embrace this obligation, this responsibility as curators of Australia. It is the greatest indictment of our current bicentennial celebrations that it has taken us 200 years of white history to even begin to talk about some sort of compact or treaty with the Aboriginal people. Words are not important but a meaningful agreement on Aboriginal land rights is.

I place on record my admiration for the indigenous people of this land, people who have lived on this continent for around 50,000 years. Nineteen eighty-eight may be a celebration for us; all it means to them is survival. We are the sons and daughters of convicts, free settlers and immigrants who came here for a freer life. Together with the Aboriginal people-the real Australians-we hold the future of Australia in our hands. For my own part, I know it is better to light one candle than to forever curse the darkness. I will endeavour in my time in this House to shed a little light in the chamber.
Debate (on motion by Senator Walsh) adjourned.

I draw attention to the fact that this statement on the Commonwealth Government sector was prepared by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce on the basis of information provided by agencies of the Commonwealth Government. The preliminary findings and discussion papers of the waterfront investigation of the Inter-State Commission are the most recent results of a long line of inquiries on the waterfront and maritime industries. Some years ago there was a royal commission into the maritime unions. After that there was the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It was diverted into the issue of tax avoidance and its recommendations on the waterfront rorts were never really acted on. In 1986 there was the industry task force on shore based shipping costs; more recently there was the report of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport; there was the Industries Assistance Commission report on coastal shipping; and now we have this report of the Inter-State Commission upon its waterfront investigations. Each of those reports has confirmed what we have all known for a very long time but which successive governments have done nothing about; that is, that the Australian waterfront is the happy home of the greatest rorts in Australian industry. Low labour productivity on the waterfront is the biggest single cost to the Australian economy. It is the exporters and import competing industries which bear the brunt of those costs. It has been estimated that the waterfront and associated industries, because of their lack of competitiveness and because of industrial rorts, are costing the Australian public more than $2 billion a year. The bulk of those costs are borne by exporters. Even the Association of Australian Port and Marine Authorities, itself responsible for administration of the ports, estimates that the cost is more than $1 billion a year. So various estimates of between $1 billion and $2 billion a year confirm the costly nature of the Australian waterfront.

The National Farmers Federation, in a study which it undertook, showed that the cost just to Australian farmers was of the order of $130m a year, or some $800 per farm. It is time that action was taken to overcome this costly impost on Australian industry. More specifically, with regard to the farming community it has been estimated that it costs $1.78 to move just one tonne of wheat across the Sydney waterfront. Sydney, of course, is the worst port in Australia with regard to the wheat industry. The cost is 41c a tonne in Western Australia and 99c in Queensland. All of those costs are excessive but, of course, Sydney is by far the worst. These high costs are the result of overmanning, restrictive work practices, industrial disputes, high unit costs and less than ideal management. We see a usurpation of authority by various trade unions and we see management weakness. That all adds to the costs of our Asian ports.

The Business Council of Australia, in an inquiry it undertook, showed that, compared with our European counterparts, Australian ports are only half as productive and, indeed, are only 40 per cent as efficient as the ports of Asia. How can Australian exporters compete on international markets when they are faced with these additional imposts resulting from the inefficient operation of Australian ports. The Industries Assistance Commission draft report on coastal shipping concluded that Australian coastal shipping adds another $700m to Australia's costs of shipping and transport. The whole area of maritime and port industries is a disaster as far as this country is concerned. The Bureau of Transport Economics estimated that the direct cost of getting cargo on to or off ships was at least 20 per cent higher than necessary, given the other conditions in place in Australia. Of course, the Bureau was looking at only one limited aspect of Australian ports.

In Australia the car industry has to carry some six to nine days of extra supplies in case there are problems on our waterfronts. Compare that with the United States, where containers from Japan can be landed on a wharf in the morning and are unpacked and into the factory by the same afternoon. Again, this demonstrates the incapacity of Australian ports to compete with their overseas counterparts.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the eleventh report of the Senate Committee of Privileges. The Committee received the reference from the Senate on 16 March this year. The reference stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the circulation of a petition containing defamatory material for the purpose of gaining signatures and subsequent submission to the Senate is or ought to be privileged and how the issues should be determined and in what forum.
The Committee asked the Clerk of the Senate for background information and advice. The Clerk in part suggested:
. . . the Committee should assume that it has been asked to determine whether there is or ought to be a legal immunity in respect of the circulation of a petition.
The Committee, in reaching the conclusion that the circulation of a petition should not be privileged, had regard to the following matters:

The burden of the submissions received, as well as the concerns expressed in debate in the Senate when the matter was referred to the Committee, is that the protection afforded by Article 9 of the Bill of Rights should not be used to circumvent the normal protections afforded to persons who might be defamed by a petition purportedly circulated-
I emphasise that-
with an (unprovable) intention that the document be presented to a House of Parliament.
The report of the Privileges Committee records:
Only the person whose case gave rise to the present reference, and the Free Speech Committee, disregarded this concern in their submissions.

I emphasise the reference to the Free Speech Committee because as a member of the Privileges Committee over a period of time I have found that the submissions of the Free Speech Committee have been uniformly poor and not addressed to the references the Privileges Committee has had. I should like to the read the recommendations in the Committee's report to the Senate to show that I believe the Committee's report is a balanced one. I refer to the first recommendation, which states:

That while the question whether the circulation of a petition for the purpose of gaining signatures and subsequent submission to the Senate is privileged is a question of law for the courts to determine, the Committee believes that the circulation is not absolutely privileged and is probably not subject to any form of qualified privilege;
The second recommendation states:
That, if the Parliament were to determine that the circulation of a petition should be privileged, absolutely or otherwise, a change to the law would therefore be required;
The third recommendation states:

That, in the light of the dangers inherent in denying a citizen the right to pursue action in the courts to redress an attack on his or her character or reputation, the circulation of a petition containing defamatory matter should not be protected by parliamentary privilege;
The fourth recommendation states:
That the circulation of other petitions requires no special protection and therefore that no change to the present law is warranted.

I believe that the Committee's report is absolutely appropriate, when the Senate reference is examined. I emphasise that because I believe the Committee has come down with the only recommendations that were appropriate, having in mind the Senate's reference to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the report by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on kangaroos. I sat on this Committee for a number of years, as did other honourable senators. I am afraid that I have to dissent from the majority report. I do so with a heavy heart, because I have respect for those other members of the Committee who have laboured long and hard to come up with their decisions. I share the concern of George Georges, the former Chairman of the Committee, that this report does not truly reflect the steps which will be necessary to save the kangaroo, which is, after all, Australia's animal. It is the animal which appears on our coat of arms. It is the animal which symbolises Australia around the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The report, which is comprehensive, which contains a lot of information and data and which, as such, is a valuable document, does not really change anything in relation to the kangaroo situation. In fact, it maintains the status quo. The report merely says, `Well, there are some problems with the present system of culling kangaroos, of killing kangaroos, but in general we feel that the thrust of the present program should be maintained'.

The majority took pains to frame recommendations which are not politically offensive. Certainly they made recommendations which will not offend the farming community or the kangaroo meat industry. However, I feel that the report should have taken into account the welfare of kangaroos. There are plenty of committees which look after the welfare of farmers and industry, but this is the only committee of the Parliament-in fact, it is one of the few such committees in the world that I know of-that actually looks at animal welfare. That is where the majority of the Committee went astray. They put the welfare of the farmers and industry ahead of the welfare of the animal.

One of the things that bothered me most as we took testimony over the years was that not one person or agency could tell us how many kangaroos there actually were. I worked as a pilot and agent for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in Alaska. It was part of my job to ascertain the amount of feed available for caribou. Then we could set the hunting season numbers. Of course we had to know how many caribou there were, too. So we did research in both areas, on feed and on the exact numbers of caribou. When we found out how many caribou there were we could then say, perhaps, that this year we had to shoot 700 of them.

No such data is available on kangaroos. I maintain that in order to have a scientifically viable conservation program-if we are worried about conserving the numbers of kangaroos-it is necessary to know what the population statistics are. We do not know. The industry and the farming community have said that, as they can shoot the same number of kangaroos every year, the population must be stable. Any wildlife expert can tell you that this is not a good way of measuring wildlife numbers. It has no relevance to the amount of effort that has been put into shooting kangaroos. They kept up the anchovy catch in the fisheries off South America-the tonnages were up every year-until the fishery collapsed because of overfishing. It was merely advanced technology which allowed them to keep their catch up. The same thing could be happening with kangaroos. We simply do not know.

The logical thing to do would be to err on the side of conservatism. If we do not know how many kangaroos we have-and certainly we have no idea how many are being shot-it would seem only wise and prudent to say, `Let us not shoot as many' or, `Let us not shoot any at all'. A number of people have testified that we should simply not shoot any kangaroos at all and I believe that I would lean towards this view because no-one was able to quantify the amount of damage that kangaroos did to farms. We were never given any evidence that farming would suffer to the extent that the farmers said it would. We were never given any hard evidence to this effect.

Of course, the Select Committee on Animal Welfare should be looking at the welfare of the animals, not the farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have the kangaroo meat industry. This was originally set up to take the by-products of the kangaroo kill which, in turn, was supposed to be for the benefit of the kangaroo, to keep the numbers stable and also to help the farmers. But we have had testimony to the effect that the industry has developed its own political clout and is, in itself, now a reason for killing kangaroos.

I feel that, for the welfare of the kangaroos, the industry should be closed. The kangaroos should be left unmolested whenever possible. If farmers can demonstrate crop damage to a responsible and impartial wildlife officer, subsidies should be paid to that farmer for the loss of the crop or for any damage done. Subsidies should also be paid if the farmer finds it necessary to install electric fencing. We have taken evidence on electric fencing. It is effective. In fact, a farmer who testified said that electric fencing was more effective for all the animals, including his own stock, than ordinary fencing. It required a certain level of expertise to keep it going, but it was cheap to operate and it would solve the kangaroo problem. So farmers should be helped financially to install electric fencing if the need arises. If any kangaroos must be killed for crop protection or population management, professional shooters should be employed by the Government. It should not be left to hoons from the cities going out at the weekends and to a handful of professional shooters who, in fact, are quite good. But 90 per cent of the kangaroos in this country are shot by unprofessional or semi-professional shooters and there is a terrible wastage of wildlife in this area.

In most respects Australia is regarded as an advanced and technologically adept nation. However, the continuing decimation of our unique wildlife demonstrates to the world that we are unwilling to address our international responsibilities. The welfare of the kangaroo, our national animal, must be placed ahead of commercial interests and inept bureaucrats. The present slaughter of kangaroos must cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that, after many changes and many starts, the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare was able to come up with a virtually unanimous report on the kangaroos in Australia. I think it is rather sad that Senator Sanders has had to give a dissenting report, because I think he has seen most of the things that other members of the Committee have seen in our travels all around Australia. He has seen the things that former Senator Georges and all the other committee members have seen and he has heard the evidence that we have all heard. It is rather disappointing that he has been got to by some lobby groups and has put out a dissenting report, because that was not quite the feeling that I got from him when he was travelling around Australia with us.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue, as with so many issues involving the welfare of animals, is a very emotive one. I have been on this Committee since the beginning of 1985 and I have found that everything we have investigated has had a very emotive ring about it. But I think the Committee has been very responsible with its report. The Committee has looked at many aspects of the industry associated with kangaroos: we have looked at the properties, we have looked at the parks and we have looked at all the aspects of the kangaroos.

The kangaroo is a special animal and we acknowledge that it has a special place in the history of Australia. The affection that people have for the kangaroo, as an animal, is widespread and the Committee acknowledges that. Nevertheless, I think it is important to acknowledge that the very action of civilisation and the development of Australia's vast regions have also provided improved habitation conditions for the kangaroo, and that is one part of Senator Sanders' speech that I would agree with. As a result, in many parts of farmland Australia the kangaroo is in plague proportions. Better watering places, better pastures and better management of pastures have led to the breeding of quite substantial numbers of kangaroos around Australia. Everyone would agree that it is unpalatable to cull any animal, whether it be a kangaroo or anything else. But I think it is necessary for the economic well-being of Australia and for the physical well-being of the kangaroo population. Senator Sanders has alluded to that and I think he is completely on the wrong hop as far as that is concerned.

I believe that the report strikes a happy balance between economic production and protection of the environment and the protection of the kangaroo as a species. For those who are interested in the environment as well as the animal, that is another reason why it is necessary to cull. It is true that several roo species are extinct and a few more are in danger of extinction. The Committee recognises that fact. However, if no management program is put in place there would be a very real danger of the wholesale slaughter of the kangaroo population.

In essence, the report calls for better aerial surveys for ascertaining the numbers of kangaroos; more research by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service; improvements to present survey techniques; more study into quota limits to reflect more accurately the present and likely roo populations; stricter testing for professional shooters; encouragement of carcass kills; and stricter export controls. If Senator Sanders had read fully those parts of the majority report, he most probably would not have needed to say some of the things that he has just said.

We heard evidence of irregularities in overseas sales but the quality of evidence was not sufficient to make any judgment. Here again, Senator Sanders has alluded to that. Just to recap, the Committee said that there should be a random inspection of consignments of kangaroo products which were to be exported; the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service should establish a fauna squad to investigate the illegal export of fauna; controls should be established over the export of kangaroo skins by appointing inspectors to check kangaroo skins at the fleshing works and to seal containers containing skins for export at those works, and only skins sealed in containers should be exported. The Committee also recommended that skins taken under approved management programs be tattooed or be able to be identified in some other way after being fleshed when the royalty tag has been detached. Again, I think that that answers all the questions raised by Senator Sanders. I think that those parts of the report which recommend fixing these problems are very responsible. Evidence was put to the Committee that there are problems with overseas sales but, as I have just said, the evidence was not absolutely quantified in all cases.

Other evidence showed that the economic damage caused to the rural sector was extensive. Here again, as I interjected when Senator Sanders was speaking, he saw the damage that excessive kangaroo numbers caused in Western Australia, Queensland and even in New South Wales. Even though evidence of this damage has not been documented in any real depth, and perhaps in future it could be assessed more accurately, it is definitely there. There is damage when kangaroo numbers reach plague proportions. Anyone who drives along some of our western roads at night or in some of the highland areas will see definitely excessive numbers of kangaroos compared with even 10 or 15 years ago. This has been caused by the build-up in pastures and improved watering facilities.

There is a view among certain people in the community that kangaroos are fair game. It is important that that perception be changed. I agree with Senator Sanders and his reference to thrill shooters and fun shooters. I do not believe that these people should be allowed to go out and shoot willy-nilly. Here again, the report makes it very clear that only those people who are licensed to shoot kangaroos should be able to do so. I am very sincere in that respect. If people perceive that a strict management program exists for animals such as kangaroos, there is a greater chance of an endangered species surviving. So, if we really analyse it, we must continue to have a cull, we must continue to have a management program, and we must realise that, if they are in danger of extinction, the cull must be continued

I believe that the report strikes a good balance between the need to protect and the need to manage kangaroo populations within our developed farming areas. It is now up to the Government and the various department bodies to ensure that the recommendations made by the Committee are put in place. I thank the secretariat for the at times repetitive work involved in countless hearings and inspections, and for their obvious efforts in the preparation of the report. I note also the work of former Senator Jack Evans, former Senator Hearn, former Senator Scott, former Senator Siddons and former Senator Georges, who were all members of this Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has a high mortality rate.

—I think it was quite a good cull. I do not know whether or not it was a managed cull, but some of those senators definitely played a large part on the Committee before retiring from this place. I think the Committee did its work in a very thoughtful way and I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to speak to the report on kangaroos handed down by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I concur with the remarks made by my colleague Senator Brownhill. I agree wholeheartedly that the subject of kangaroos-and, in fact, all animals-is very emotive, as evidenced in submissions placed before the Committee. We know that kangaroos have been the subject of a motion in the American Congress, they have been discussed in the European Parliament and, of course, they have received a great deal of publicity in Australia over the past few years. Having noted how emotive this debate has been, I point out that during the time that I have been a member of this Committee we have taken particular care not to become involved in emotive matters but to analyse the facts. I reject the criticism and insinuations that have been made against the Committee by some of the emotive animal welfare committees. I certainly reject the criticism of the President of the Australian and New Zealand Federation of Animal Societies (ANZFAS) who stated in a media release:

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt too the kangaroo industry and farmer lobby groups carry political clout. Accordingly, a committee established to examine animal welfare would appear to have moved right away from its initial rationale.

I assure the Senate that I was not lobbied by any kangaroo industry members, nor by any farming groups. However, I note a press release from the National Farmers Federation (NFF) put out after we presented and tabled our report. The press release states:

The Committee's Report will provide the basis for rational discussion of a subject which for too long has been surrounded by misinformation and emotionalism. The NFF concurs with the Committee's general conclusion that a balance must be struck between the need to preserve kangaroos in abundant numbers and the need to use Australia's resources for the well-being of all.
The NFF does not agree with some of our recommendations but, when one tries to take the responsible position which I believe has been adopted in this report, one cannot please anybody.

Senator Brownhill referred to the history of the Committee. The Committee's report has been in production for some four years. Unlike Cecil B. De Mille's classic film making, it has not involved a cast of thousands, but certainly something like 109 people gave evidence to the Committee. As Senator Brownhill has already said, there was also a large turnover of senators on this Committee. I think we should note the Committee's initial statement in the report:

The kangaroo has a special place in the history of Australia and enjoys the affection of people both within and outside the country. It is a national symbol of which Australians are justifiably proud and its status as a protected animal is not in question. It must be preserved in abundant numbers.
The report also states:

The Committee concludes that a balance must be struck between the need to preserve kangaroos in abundant numbers and the need to use Australia's resources for the well being of all. The Committee found that a proper balance involves the development of a strictly controlled management program.

The Committee made a well thought out, well researched and balanced list of recommendations; in fact, I think that there are some 27 in all. Naturally, on the release of the report, we received unwarranted and misleading criticism. Accusations included the statement that the Committee was `faint-hearted and lacked moral leadership'. I totally reject those accusations. I refer to the Australian and a statement by the Treasurer of the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF), Mr Rawlinson, who said that we were faint-hearted. He also states in the article:

. . . the animal welfare movement wanted pest control carried out by professional shooting, under permit, of those animals which could be shown to be doing damage, and the cessation of commercial killing for profit.
Mr Rawlinson is also quoted in the Hobart Mercury of 8 June this year, as follows:

. . . the animal welfare movement did not oppose all kangaroo killing but it wanted pest control done by professional shooting, under permit, of those animals which could be shown to be doing damage and the end of commercial killing for profit.
There was also a joint press release from ANZFAS and the ACF. The joint press release from ANZFAS and the ACF concludes:
Australia needs a national body with uniform national legislation for the proper management of our kangaroo and other wildlife populations.

Having read all the press releases and taken the criticism, I suggest that perhaps those concerned should read our report. In the report we actually recommend the sorts of things for which people have asked. We recommended:
. . . that the Commonwealth and the States and Territories work out on a cooperative basis over time a system for national management of kangaroos.
That was one of our major recommendations. Another recommendation was that:
. . . all methods of killing kangaroos other than by shooting be banned in mainland Australia.
We also recommended that:
. . . as a fundamental principle, the kangaroo remain a protected animal. However, its deleterious effects on human land use must be taken into account.
The major recommendation of the Committee was:
The Committee recommends that commercial shooting of kangaroos continue to be permitted in areas where there is a need to reduce populations of kangaroo for damage mitigation purposes.

The estimated population of kangaroos on mainland Australia ranges from 16 million to 32 million. Senator Brownhill has already referred to a number of surveys of red and grey kangaroos and animal survey numbers that should be taken into account. The range of figures I have just cited has been accepted by past Ministers. It is also estimated that the population of wallabies in Tasmania is about six million. I cannot accept the view of Senator Sanders that kangaroos are an endangered species. How can one accept that these animals are endangered when one comes up with numbers such as 16 million and 32 million on the mainland, and six million in Tasmania? If one adopted that criterion, one would almost have to say that the population of Australia is endangered because this country has only about 16 million people. Therefore, I cannot accept Senator Sanders's argument.

I believe that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare is comprehensive, as has been said by other members of the Committee. A total of 109 people gave evidence to the Committee. I believe that it is a blueprint for the sensible survival of one of our national emblems. I join Senator Brownhill in complimenting the staff of the Committee not only for the very professional way in which they have put the report together but also for their patience and ability in enabling members of the Committee to gain the best possible knowledge of the subject over a period of four years, so that we could give the people of Australia a balanced and very worthwhile report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I offer my congratulations to the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on a balanced and very good report. The report will go out to overseas parliaments, and probably into the European Economic Community and its Parliament. No doubt other countries will use the findings contained in this report as a basis for bringing forward their importing programs. I compliment those people who have made this report possible. Although I am not a member of the Committee, I have on occasion accompanied the Committee out into the field, particularly when it has been in my home State of Queensland. I can well recall taking Senator Georges out into the Longreach-Hughenden area. Unlike Senator Sanders, who obviously saw the devastation and damage caused by the proliferation of kangaroos and who has chosen to ignore completely what he saw with his own eyes, Senator Georges was realistic enough, having been out on field trips, to change his attitude. He realised that the problem was vastly different when one saw it actually in the field compared with reading about the subject in books and magazines.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, as Senator Calvert said, that there are between 15 million and 32 million kangaroos in Australia. It depends on whose evidence one takes; but, whichever way one looks at it, there are more kangaroos in Australia than there are people. Nobody has ever suggested that people in Australia are an extinct race. Certainly, kangaroos in Australia are flourishing because farmers have changed the environment. Farmers have put in crops, stored water and created a different environment from that which many years ago was quite unliveable for kangaroos. Kangaroos are now able to move into those areas and to find food and water that did not exist in earlier years.

In fact, there are more kangaroos in Australia now than there have ever been. Judging by earlier reports of the days when the colony was established, it is true to say that there were very few kangaroos in those days. Now the kangaroo population has exploded and we have to find some way of achieving a kangaroo population than can co-exist with farmers. I have never heard of a farmer who has said that he wants to wipe kangaroos from his area. I have never heard a farmer say, `I want to keep every kangaroo off my property'. I have been on many properties throughout Australia and throughout Queensland and I have never heard that comment made. Farmers acknowledge that they want kangaroos in their areas in proportions that will not bankrupt them.

This report signals that fact to the people of Australia and to people overseas. It is a good, balanced report and gives that message to the various parliaments throughout the world. It is necessary to cull kangaroos, and indeed wildlife, in all national parks. This applies to Africa, including South Africa. Every nation that possesses wildlife has to keep those animals within manageable proportions. The situation is no different in Queensland or in the rest of Australia. Culling or killing, whichever way one looks at it, is an emotional issue; but it is absolutely necessary. Senator Sanders takes the view that we should not cull kangaroos; that we should have no program in this respect; that the kangaroos were here first and are entitled to their share of the Australian land. That attitude is absolutely ridiculous.

The farmers have to provide food for this nation as well as for the people in many nations around the world who cannot feed themselves. Those people rely on our food exports. Senator Sanders is adopting a most unrealistic, indeed dishonest attitude. He has been on all the field trips arranged for the Animal Welfare Committee. To bring down a dissenting report as he did in this chamber is quite dishonest and unrealistic.

Some people have called for professional shooters to cull kangaroos. I say to those people that all that would happen would be that the professional shooters would join the National Parks and Wildlife Service, put on its badge, and go out and do exactly the same job as they were doing before but now they would do it at the expense of the taxpayer. They would not shoot any more accurately. They would not do a better job. They would not provide any better service, but it would cost the nation many millions of dollars. At the moment this business is providing employment. I will certainly not argue in this House that the kangaroo industry should exist to keep people employed. That is not what I want to say. But we have an industry that services the needs of the farming and grazing industry at no cost to the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a very humane way.

—Yes. Humanity is in-built. If a kangaroo shooter is inaccurate and he cannot put the kangaroo down with a direct shot, no-one will buy his skins. Therefore, he will go broke. Only the good kangaroo shooters, the ones who shoot accurately, will remain in business. It will not be profitable for inaccurate shooters to stay in business. It is a good and balanced report. I commend it to the Senate and I compliment the people who were involved in making the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Senator Chaney:
