SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As everyone knows the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material was tabled some time ago in the Senate and there has been much talk about it both here in the Senate and in the public arena. It is to be regretted that there have been misrepresentations, misunderstandings and misinformation arising from the recommendations of the Committee to such an extent that yesterday a seminar was held within Parliament House so that the parliamentarians could be better informed on this issue. The first recommendation in the report which was supported by a slim majority, recommended that a new category NVE-non-violent erotica-be instituted. The reason for this recommendation is that the X-rated material available in Australia is in fact non-violent material. X-rated material in the USA and in the United Kingdom is permitted to contain violence as well as sexually explicit material. This is not the case in Australia, so it was felt by the majority on the Committee that to replace that category by a more explicitly stated non-violent erotica label would be sensible.

SPEECH.PARA: The main thrust of the Committee's recommendations, which has not been caught up by the public at all, is that the R-rated category should be restricted along with the present X-rated category or, as the Committee recommends, the NVE-rated material. The restrictions recommended by the Committee are that both R-rated and current X-rated material should not be available in the ordinary video stores to the general public. Although the provision of R-rated material is supposed to be restricted to those over 18 years of age, there is no doubt that within the video hire stores and video shops people under 18 can see that material. They certainly can see the promotional material which is put up everywhere. So the Committee's recommendation is very sound. The general public does not seem to be aware that the R-rated material is the material that contains the violence and that this violent material may be in conjunction with sexually orientated material.

The general consensus of opinion-and unfortunately in all these matters it is an opinion-by psychologists and by people who work in this area is that it is the violent material that is the most dangerous. I regret the fact that this very strong recommendation has not been picked up in the public arena. The Committee went further and recommended that promotional material for R-rated movies should also be restricted and not put outside cinemas, but only within the areas where the over 18-year-olds are allowed to go.

The Committee also recommended that as there seems to be a great deal of confusion in the public arena as to exactly what the categories PG, G, M and R stand for, all the video covers should state clearly exactly what the ratings stand for. The G, M, R and NVE, or X-rated, movies should clearly state on the cover the reason why the particular rating is there; whether it is there because of explicit language, violence, or sexual material. Many people have said that they hire a movie in good faith with a PG or an M rating, take it home and show it, but are surprised by some of the material in it. In its deliberations the Committee also stated that it believed there should be some upgrading in these categories, that some of the material in the M category should go into the R category, and that some of the material at the top end of the R-rated scale should not be classified at all. One of the recommendations of the Committee was that the Film Censorship Board should be allowed to re-look at all this material and to reclassify it if necessary.

The misunderstanding by the public was demonstrated in a poll conducted by a very well-known newspaper a few weeks ago. It asked the question: Do you believe that in X-rated video material violence should be banned or that explicitly sexual material should be banned? Three per cent were in favour of the sexually explicit material being banned and about 30 per cent said that violent material should be banned. But that question should not have been asked because there is no violent material in the presently X-rated videos in Australia.

Another very important recommendation put forward by the Committee was that it should be an offence to show either an X-rated or an R-rated movie to a person under the age of 18 without the express permission of the person's parent or guardian. Another important recommendation that does not appear to have reached the public arena is that all video outlets, including mail order outlets, should be registered under the ordinance and it should be made an offence to trade without a certificate of registration.

I have risen to speak very briefly to this report to try to correct some of the misinformation and misunderstandings that the public have. I hope that when this matter comes before the Parliament again, as it may well do, members of Parliament themselves will be better informed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present a discussion paper from the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled, `Education for Active Citizenship'. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to that paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The discussion paper which I have tabled today was compiled by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training as part of its current inquiry into education for active citizenship in Australian schools and youth organisations. My Committee believes that the quality of life we enjoy and the quality of the democracy we experience very much reflect the degree to which we are willing and able to pitch in and take control of our lives. The capacity to do this is what we mean by `active citizenship'. It is the mark of a civilised society that it can produce citizens who see themselves as contributors, not takers.

How do Australians measure up as active citizens? Studies have shown that large numbers of Australians-especially the young-know very little about how their country is run, not just at the national level but at the State and local level as well. The dominant source of information seems to be the television screen, which by its very nature, can provide little more than a superficial view of events. A recent survey in the Australian Capital Territory found that, for example, 70 per cent of upper secondary students received most of their information about politics from television. Only 10 per cent said that they got most information from school teachers. It is not just a question of how much people know; it is also how much they care: how much they are prepared to get involved, right down to the level of the local community. Evidence gathered by my committee on this score is not particularly encouraging, especially where young people are concerned. A survey of local government in Victoria recently found that only about one in a hundred local councillors in that State is under 30, despite attempts by councils to involve younger people. My Committee is also aware of the recent report on Australia's youth from the Commission for the Future, which saw evidence of increased political apathy among young people, coupled with a growing tendency to see the world primarily in terms of the narrow perspectives of personal needs and desires.

We cannot assume that this indifference towards our democratic institutions is found only among those who have had a limited education. A professor of politics at a Victorian University told the Committee that students in his first year politics classes have only `a scanty idea' of what a democracy is. He said that, `Very few students can tell you why the Constitution, Parliament or elections are important, or why ideas about participation or citizenship deserve to be taken seriously in our kind of democracy'. This statement is even more alarming when one reflects that, unlike the small percentage of students who take a university politics course, most students may never progress beyond this stunted view of the world. All of this adds up to a combination of ignorance and apathy which does not bode well for Australia's future as a caring society and a strong, healthy democracy. It also adds up to a society in which people regard themselves as powerless to influence what happens in their daily lives; a society in which they see themselves as pawns in the game rather than active participants with views of their own to express.

Young people cannot be expected to remedy this situation on their own. Right across Australia, we have found, school programs offer students only meagre opportunities to learn what it means to be an active citizen, and even fewer opportunities to practise citizenship skills. There is no real debate over whether citizenship education is a legitimate concern of schools. This is generally accepted by education systems, and has been for some time. Official curriculum statements, for example reflect that view. It is a different matter, however, when one looks at the reality of what actually happens in schools.

My Committee has found that citizenship education fares badly in schools and is often the loser where there are competing priorities. In many cases, it is taught by teachers who, at best are only partly trained for the task, since very few teacher education institutions in Australia offer courses to train teachers in this field. The result in the classroom is, all too frequently, that students are simply `turned off' by the topic. To put the matter bluntly, the lesson which is learnt by tomorrow's citizens is that citizenship is not worth bothering about. This appears to apply even in those professions which demand skills and training as essential qualifications, such as law, medicine and engineering. As one submission put it, the ground is being prepared for `the phenomenon of the skilled barbarian-a section of professional or educated society whose attitude towards civic questions is uninformed or crude to say the least'.

My Committee believes that this is not good enough and that more effective educational responses are required. This view is apparently shared by many young people themselves. In the course of our inquiry, my Committee has made a special effort to listen to the views of young people, and our witnesses have included secondary students and representatives of youth organisations. The message we have received is that students believe the education system is short-changing them in the area of citizenship education. Many of them are, or soon will be, of voting age, but they do not see themselves as adequately equipped for this responsibility, or for the other responsibilities which the term `citizen' implies. These problems will not be overcome unless a stronger emphasis is placed on education for active citizenship. Essentially, it is a matter of priorities. As things stand at present, there is little doubt what priority the Australian educational system is placing on the quality of our democracy.

The discussion paper which I have tabled today is part of my Committee's response to this situation. The document is mainly composed of extracts from submissions to the inquiry. It illustrates the range of views which have been put to us. The paper has been widely circulated as a means of generating public discussion. My Committee plans to table its report before the end of the current session. In that report we will put forward specific recommendations to combat the problem we have identified. In the meantime, I commend the discussion paper to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne made all sorts of promises in the course of his last contribution. He would not appear here often if he could get his remarks recorded in relation to this clause. The Government does not accept this amendment which has been moved by Senator Chaney, which seeks to replace object (a), which refers to promoting industrial harmony and co-operation amongst the parties, with an objective of promoting industrial harmony and co-operation between employers and employees. If I might say so without causing offence, many of the Opposition's amendments are couched in terms which one can only describe as `motherhood'.
—Are you against motherhood?

—That is precisely the point, Senator. I am not, in general principle, against children. I am not against some of the fine words in these amendments. I think we have to analyse what they in fact mean because the differences between the two proposed clauses are not merely semantic. If one looks at the objects of the Act clause as a whole, what the amendment, moved by Senator Chaney would do is delete the word `parties' from that clause. Of course that would appear again on a number of occasions in the legislation if it were passed without amendment or passed with an amendment. It is appropriate that the word `parties' should appear in the objects clause.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition amendment referring to employers and employees is not acceptable to the Government because of its narrow focus and because it would be too limited in operation in the context of the Bill. Essentially this Bill is about the function of the Industrial Relations Commission which will be established. It is a nice question how the Commission would discharge its function in pursuing harmony between employers and employees. That is a question which goes very much to the issue of attitudinal change. The Commission's function with this Bill, amended or otherwise, would still be involved in the settlement of industrial disputes. It is not about the sort of broader, nice sounding issue of promoting industrial harmony between employers and employees. I just make the point that the term `the parties involved in industrial relations in Australia' has a wider meaning than merely employers and employees. It refers to all parties whether they be organisations, employers, employees, or other persons. If one looks at the definitions clause of the Bill and of the existing Act one will see that that is the case.

`Parties' here referred to in this proposed government clause is not intended to refer to parties in the sense of a party to an industrial dispute. For example, one can refer to clause 101 of the Bill to see the operation of that sort of provision. As I said this morning when we were having a more general discussion, the Bill will also recognise the crucial role of representative organisations of employers and employees in the Federal system. The proposed amendment is inconsistent with that role and the practice of dispute prevention and settlement. That would be the case if clause 3 (a) referred only to employers and employees. So this amendment is not acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I respond to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) by saying that by referring to employers and employees rather than parties the Opposition is simply seeking to get over the situation where unions or indeed employer organisations can be seen not as agents for the essential people who are involved in the employment contract but as, in a sense, the prime actors in the whole field. As I said before, our objective is to encourage a more productive economy, a more productive culture. That means having more productive enterprises and that means having people working closely together within enterprises. Our concern, and I will not go over the ground completely again because it would be a waste of the time of the committee, is that on occasions-and I gave two quite specific recent examples-the involvement of parties other than the employers and employees themselves can in fact be a barrier to the sort of direct dealing that we would seek to encourage.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the Minister's other fundamental point, `What about the situation for dispute settlement and so on?', I just draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the four objectives refer, first, to a framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes; next to ensuring that in the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes proper regard is had to the interests of the parties; and so on. I do not think that in any sense the change that we are suggesting here takes away from the reality that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is required to deal with disputes. I again commend the amendment to the committee and ask for support.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 2, before paragraph 3 (b), insert the following paragraph:
`(aa) to encourage the growth, development, productivity and international competitiveness of Australian industry;'.

Clause 3 contains a whole series of objects-the promotion of industrial harmony, a framework for the prevention of disputes and so on. Our concern is that the Bill, which already introduces reference to the economic interests of Australia, needs to express the basic economic interests of Australia a little more clearly. The Government has included as one of the objects object (c), in these terms:

to ensure that, in the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes, proper regard is had to the interests of the parties immediately concerned and to the interests (including the economic interests) of the Australian community as a whole;

The Opposition supports that as a worthy objective of this legislation but we agree with the concerns expressed by the Business Council of Australia, which believes that the Government's proposal is not a sufficiently strong signal for the new Industrial Relations Commission about the weight to be given to economic criteria in settling disputes and, further, that it is not a sufficiently strong piece of guidance to the Commission given that Australia's position in the international economy is probably the key economic factor at work. What is necessary is for the parties appearing before the Commission to be able to point to a substantial change in the legislation as a clearer and stronger signal of the Parliament's intention regarding the weight to be placed on economic considerations. In a way, it is a pity that this Bill has been so delayed. It is years now since the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems report was received by the Government. It is well over a year since the Government brought into the Parliament its first try at comprehensive legislation following the Hancock report.

I think it is a pity that this legislation is not being considered in the days before the improvements in our terms of trade masked somewhat the competitive difficulties which still face this country. If we were debating this Bill in 1986 I think we all would be more alive to the point that I am seeking to have inserted in the Bill at this stage. We were all very conscious in 1986 that Australia, if it was to restore its economic health, had to look to international competitiveness as a key concern in its domestic economic management, and that includes in the operation of its labour market. The improvements in the terms of trade over the last 18 months and the restoration in full of the losses which caused the deep concerns of 1986 have temporarily at least masked the urgency of the need to improve our competitiveness. For that reason we think it is important that there be a very clear signal in this Bill that it is a vital matter for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to take into account when it is dealing with industrial disputes and the major wages questions that it will have to deal with year by year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not cover the ground that Senator Chaney has covered. I think that in many respects this amendment goes to the heart of industrial relations. It seems to me that too often one could be tempted to make the mistake of seeing good industrial relations as an end in themselves rather than a means to a more substantial end. There is a temptation to talk about man days lost or the incidence of disputation, which are just symptoms of the failure of the industrial relations system, and not to look at the consequences of the failure of the industrial relations system. Our balance of payments, our foreign debt and our failure to compete in world markets in many respects are symptomatic of the failure by successive governments and by successive Australians to come to grips with the real problems.

SPEECH.PARA: One could pose a fundamental question, and not in a rhetorical sense. This country God has endowed with all the fundamental natural resources that we could want-not only in minerals and metal but in energy-and he has provided us, through our own endeavours, with an intelligent, capable and well-educated work force, with a society presumably with self-respect and ambition. But having all those ingredients, why is it that at the end of the day our standard of living seems to be sliding back? Why is it that we are not able to compete with countries that are not blessed and endowed with those natural resources? Why is it that we do not compete with Singapore, Korea, Taiwan or Hong Kong?

All sorts of reasons are given but essentially-I am sure Senator Button would agree-we have the ingredients to compete. But we do not. We seem to sink back into the mire and the imbroglio of the argument about industrial relations, as to who is right and who is wrong. We argue about for whom the benefits are to be achieved and we do not recognise that at the end of the day if we do not have a system that encourages, as Senator Chaney says in his amendment, growth, development, productivity and international competitiveness for Australian industry we have absolutely nothing; we achieve nothing. If we cannot do that, given our modest population, our standard of living will continue to sink. In many respects this amendment goes to the heart of what this legislation ought to be all about. It should be drafted to aim for the goals which I have mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like in this adjournment debate to continue the remarks I was making earlier this afternoon on the funding of education research and scientific effort in this country. I said this afternoon that in terms of overall funding, the Science and Technology Statement we were then discussing indicated that funding for research and development in Australia had been cut back in the recent Budget by as much as 6.9 per cent and that, compared with most Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, we were not bearing up extremely well. Indeed, we are fifteenth in a list of 22 countries. I indicated then that the role of science in society was being misunderstood both by this Government and, indeed, by the Opposition; that science was being very narrowly confined as the handmaiden of industry; and that all science which did not serve the industrial process was regarded as off limits and would not be supported. I said also that scientific enterprise was of the nature of the activity which marked the classical period of Western civilisation, when music and art flourished and was seen as the creative expression of that society.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation today is that science is the creative expression of our modern industrial society and should be seen in that context. Science should enrich the life of modern people not just in terms of the things, the objects, which science creates but also in terms of the understanding of natural processes. I believe it was Bertrand Russell who said that it was nice to know things. That seems to me to summarise the idea that science in the modern world is the equivalent of religious contemplation in the medieval world and of artistic and musical expression in the classical period of European civilisation.

There are a number of things science serves in society that go well beyond the area of industrial production. I indicated earlier this afternoon that the democratic process itself in an increasingly complex world is served by science. If we are going to make proper, rational and democratically based decisions about complex technology, the use of things such as information technology, the new technology in human fertility, genetic engineering and environmental degradation, we need an informed society and a society which can properly understand those scientific truths and processes. That means that we must have an educational system which is grounded in active scientific research work so that those who teach in our universities are actively engaged in research, indeed are at the forefront of that research, and can convey their understanding of that cutting edge of science to their students. It implies also that those people will be very actively involved in the education of the community at large. They will involve themselves in debates about the philosophy of science and about the application of science to society in general. Through that process society will be able to make proper and democratically based decisions in relation to that advancing edge of science.

That is not what we find in Australian society at the present time. We find that funding is being cut back; we find that where funding is being placed it is constraining science and research effort merely to those areas that serve the technical purposes of society, leaving out completely these other purposes. The consequences of this in practical terms are also serious. I believe that future generations in Australia will look back on this period of the last 15 years-since the Whitlam years-and I include the directions the Opposition took when it was in power, and see it as a retrograde period in the development of education in this country and in the development of the understanding and the role of science in society. To give several examples, one finds that there is increasing understanding that the technology of energy use worldwide in advanced countries is causing the addition of a large number of pollutant gases to the atmosphere that have the potential to change the weather pattern substantially, to cause increases in sea levels and changes in the agricultural productivity of large areas.

If we look at the most recent Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation reports, we find that CSIRO is putting a great deal of money and effort into developing the coal export industry. It would seem that if science and society were to take a longer view of this activity then a great deal more effort would be going into developing alternative energy systems, developing betters ways of charging for energy so that the correct price signals reflecting environmental damage were given to consumers, and developing conservation strategies. On the contrary, we find that this country has cut down its expenditure of money into research into alternatives, the sociological research that is necessary into questions of the acceptability of conservation measures. We are looking in completely the wrong technical direction to solve the problems which are now becoming evident to us.

We could look also at the so-called Button car plan, grounded in a very conventional economic view of making this country more competitive and more able to build cars. No consideration at all has been given in that plan to the problems that face this country in terms of the run-down of fossil fuels, particularly liquid fossil fuels which power cars and, therefore, no consideration has been given to the pricing of fuels which might be reflected in the efficiency of the cars we use, and there is no place to increase the efficiency of fuel use in cars. We find that the most recent Holden cars to come on the market have as a conventional engine a 4-litre engine and as an optional engine a 5-litre engine. These are extremely inefficient vehicles, at a time when we are told that by 1991 this country will be importing $3 billion worth of foreign oil. Surely if we understood anything at all about the interplay of science in society, of where the cutting edge of the understanding of that interaction really is, then we would be addressing this problem of manufacturing in the context of what was happening to fuels, to the atmosphere, and we would be directing our industry in totally different ways.

In the information technology area we find that a great deal of effort is being put into developing new information technology, but almost no effort at all is being devoted to the question of who owns the technology, for what purpose it is used, and who benefits from it. We seem to be bemused by the fact that simply increasing the flow of words or pictures passes for making life better. There is no evidence as far as I am aware that the accuracy of a signal is in any way increased when that signal is beamed to a million or a thousand million people by satellite or whether it is faxed through modern fax machines or sent through modems from computer to computer. We are being bombarded with noise but with very little information. Those important questions, which should be addressed alongside the development of the technology of information handling and information transfer, are simply being left aside.

In regard to the biological control of pests, a very important area, Senator Powell today referred to the substantial cutback in funding for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. There would be no benefit to industry in developing these types of technologies. Therefore, they are not likely to be funded by industry. But the Government, hell-bent on getting out of funding these areas and relying on industry to pick up the tab, little realises that the greatest long term benefits lie in the area of biological control.

Education, particularly tertiary education in our universities and the scientific and research effort, are under severe threat. There is a gross misunderstanding of the role of that effort in our society. We will go down the gurgler unless we recognise this and turn the process around. I see no hope of that occurring, given this Government, this Opposition and the bureaucracy which have entrenched those attitudes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter that is of great concern to people in Western Australia. A special meeting has been called tomorrow evening in the suburb of Kwinana at which representatives of the Kwinana Town Council and people representing the proposed petrochemical plant to be set up in the area will be present. The meeting has been called because of great public concern about the proposed petrochemical plant in the area. A lot has been said, especially in the Western Australian media, about the funding for this plant. The plant will be funded half by the Western Australian Government and half by the Bond Corporation. However, it is not that matter I wish to address this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Concerns have been expressed by two groups of people, scientists and technologists, and the residents of Kwinana. The scientists and technologists are concerned about the process which is proposed to be used in the petrochemical plant. Reports show that the proposed technology is out of date. Way back in the early 1970s the knowledge already existed that such a plant should be an integrated plant and take the processes right through, not stopping anywhere in the middle.

At the proposed petrochemical plant in Kwinana two very dangerous substances, ethylene dichloride (EDC) and vinyl chloride monomer (VCM), will not be followed through right to conclusion to produce the PVC pellets-which are a safe product-but will, at that dangerous stage, be stored in quantities and then exported for further processing elsewhere. The fear is that these two substances will be exported, possibly to Indonesia, to complete the process to the PVC pellet stage. Unfortunately, in Indonesia there are not the same restrictions and safety measures as exist in Australia in regard to industrial techniques. It is believed that the PVC pellets will then be exported to Japan where the manufacturing-the most financially beneficial stage-will take place.

If this plant is to be set up in Western Australia, the whole process should be carried out in one hit. A matter of great concern is that Dr Tingay, the private environmental consultant responsible for the environmental report, does not seem to be aware of the danger of these two substances. For example, he believes that any spill of VCM can be contained. But, as this substances boils at minus 14 degrees centigrade, and immediately becomes a gas if there is any accident and it does make contact with the air, a very dangerous situation could evolve. With the prevailing winds we have on the western seaboard, any gas which is emitted in the Kwinana area will blow northwards and over Perth. As the people of Perth well know, from time to time smelly gases are blown in that direction. So that aspect is a matter of great concern.

The local residents are also concerned because, although Kwinana was set up originally as an industrial area, it has now also become a residential area. The local people are very upset that yet another big, dirty and very dangerous industry is to be set up in the area in which they live. As I looked through material about Bulgaria, because I will shortly be in that country, I was most intrigued to read that one of the problems currently facing Bulgaria is that of pollution which comes from the petrochemical plant situated just over the border in Romania. I quote from the EIV Country Report No. 2:

Clouds of chlorine gas and other pollutant from the Ciurgiu chemical plant in Romania have been drifting across the border repeatedly into the area of Ruse, angering local residents and creating minor problems between the normally very friendly Bulgarian and Romanian governments.

I hope that, as the plant to be set up in Western Australia is newer, it will be somewhat more sophisticated and will not produce those sorts of problems every day. But it does illustrate the fact that it is not a happy situation to have this sort of industry situated within a residential area. An environmental impact statement into the whole proposed arrangement is required. I also firmly believe that, if the proposed petrochemical plant goes ahead in its planned format, the Western Australian public will be entitled to hold Barry Carbon, the Chairperson of the Environmental Protection Authority, personally responsible for any cancers or other conditions attributable to the petrochemical plant which manifest themselves in the surrounding community in the future. There is not a shadow of doubt that if people come into contact with the two substances I have previously mentioned, EDC and VCM, there is a great danger of cancers developing or other unfortunate manifestations, such as prevalence towards spontaneous abortion. In this adjournment speech I wish to give my support to the residents of Kwinana who will be meeting tomorrow night in an endeavour not to have the petrochemical plant set up in their area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.49 p.m.
